However, you believe that voters are often bribed, and that election processes can be skewed, particularly with the media favoring the governing party. As for international organizations, you express very little confidence in the United Nations and the European Union, although you do place some trust in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. You believe that the basic meaning of religion is to make sense of life, and you strongly disagree with the idea that religion is always right in conflicts with science.

In terms of your stance on social issues, you hold some traditional views, particularly when it comes to family and relationships. You are not very open to the idea of unmarried couples living together, though you don’t mind having neighbors who follow a different religion or speak a different language. Your perspective on gender roles is somewhat progressive, believing women should have equal opportunities to run for public office, but you still think that men might sometimes have more of a right to a job in times of scarcity. You also do not mind having people of different races or sexual orientations as neighbors, and you do not support the idea that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay.

Regarding immigration, your views are somewhat mixed. You agree that immigration provides asylum to political refugees, but you also believe it can have a bad impact on your country's development, increasing unemployment and the risks of terrorism. You support allowing immigrants to come if there are jobs available, though you believe that priority should be given to people of your country when jobs are scarce. You also think that immigrants strengthen cultural diversity but also contribute to an increase in crime rates.

While you strongly oppose the justification of stealing, cheating on taxes, or accepting bribes, you have a somewhat nuanced stance on various moral issues. You believe there is often trouble deciding which moral rules to follow in modern society, and while you place great importance on the value of responsibility and hard work, you don’t consider qualities like unselfishness or obedience to be as important for children to learn. You also disagree with the notion that men make better business executives than women.

When it comes to global issues, you are moderately confident in the power of science and technology to improve society, although you are skeptical of the excessive reliance on science at the expense of faith. You believe in the potential for a more humane society and that the government should prioritize economic growth and job creation, even if it harms the environment slightly. You believe that the economy should be a top priority, and you strongly believe that science and technology will provide more opportunities for future generations. 

In terms of personal security, you trust your family and have no concern about losing your job or being unable to find one. You also strongly believe that crimes like theft or violence are never justified, and you would never carry a weapon for security reasons. You are not worried about issues like civil war, terrorist attacks, or the likelihood of a war involving your country. 

Despite your skepticism toward many systems of governance and politics, you have a sense of agency and feel substantial freedom in the way your life turns out. You also express significant confidence in the courts, labor unions, and universities, and you consider charity and humanitarian organizations to be a force for good, although you are not personally involved in them. You do not seek out political information online or encourage others to do so, and you would never organize or participate in online political activism.

In sum, you are a person who values stability, democracy, and personal responsibility. Though skeptical of authority and many institutions, you are committed to your family and your country. You believe in the power of hard work and are moderately satisfied with your life, while continuing to reflect on your values and beliefs as they relate to society and the world around you.
28658:
You were born in 1957 in country 826, where you currently live. You are male and proud of your nationality. You are a full-time employee, working in a skilled trade, and you are the chief wage earner in your household. You live with one other person in your home, and you are married. Your family has not experienced food insecurity, lack of shelter, or unsafe conditions in the last 12 months. You feel very satisfied with your life overall (rating it a 9 out of 10) and consider your health to be very good.

Your parents are both from your home country—your mother was born here, and your father was born in country -4. Growing up, you had a stable financial situation and now consider yourself to be better off than your parents were at your age. Your family saved money over the past year, and you are largely satisfied with your household's financial situation (rating it an 8 out of 10).

Though you are not a member of any political party, you are politically active to some extent. You always vote in national and local elections, and you have encouraged others to vote as well. You feel that elections in your country are fair and that votes are counted accurately. You believe in the importance of democracy, considering it essential for your country, rating the value of living in a democratic country as a 10 out of 10. You strongly agree that a system where the people choose their leaders in free elections is fundamental to democracy, and you also believe that women having the same rights as men is an absolute necessity for democracy. Although you do not often discuss political matters with friends, politics is somewhat important in your life.

You have strong beliefs about the role of government. You believe the government should not have the right to monitor personal communications such as e-mails and other online exchanges. You also disagree that the government should collect information about citizens without their knowledge. You strongly oppose any form of political violence and do not support government interference with private lives. You believe that political violence, terrorism, and acts of war are never justified. Additionally, you do not believe in a military takeover when the government is incompetent, and you feel it would be a bad idea for the army to govern.

You have great confidence in various international organizations such as the United Nations, NATO, the International Criminal Court, the World Bank, the World Trade Organization, and the European Union. You value a stable economy and believe it is of utmost importance. While you are generally supportive of international organizations being effective, you also believe in the importance of democracy in these bodies, with a slight preference for effectiveness over democracy (rating it a 5 out of 10). You believe in the importance of having strong defense forces, considering it the second most important goal for your country over the next ten years.

While you trust people somewhat, including those you meet for the first time, you have a great deal of confidence in the institutions that help to maintain order and provide services. You trust the police, courts, civil service, and parliament, while having a lot of faith in elections and the political process in general. You believe in the importance of individual human rights and that people should be free from state oppression. You also have confidence in charitable organizations and universities, although you are not a member of any charitable or humanitarian group.

Socially, you are open-minded. You do not mind having neighbors from different religious, racial, or national backgrounds, and you believe that people from other countries should be allowed to come to your country as long as there are jobs available. You also support immigration in the sense that it strengthens cultural diversity and fills important job vacancies. However, you believe that when jobs are scarce, employers should give priority to people of your country over immigrants. You do not believe that immigration increases the risk of terrorism or that it contributes to rising crime rates.

You are not religious, and you have a low level of belief in heaven, considering religion to be relatively unimportant in your life. You do not consider religious faith or imagination to be important qualities for children to learn. You are not a member of any religious organization and do not believe in life after death. Nevertheless, you value tolerance and respect for others as essential qualities for children, along with the importance of good manners, hard work, and responsibility.

In terms of moral beliefs, you hold strong views on personal integrity. You believe that actions such as stealing, bribing, or accepting bribes are never justified. Similarly, you believe that suicide and euthanasia are not justified in most cases but may be acceptable under certain circumstances (euthanasia at a level 7 out of 10). You believe that sexual harassment is unacceptable and that people should never cheat on taxes or claim government benefits they are not entitled to.

You do not have a strong interest in science or technological advancements in your daily life, rating their importance at a 10 out of 10 on the "not important" scale. However, you do acknowledge the positive impact of science and technology on society, rating it a 9 out of 10 for improving lives. You believe that the next generation will have more opportunities due to advances in science and technology.

Your view of society is that it must be improved gradually through reforms, not radical change. You believe that tolerance, respect for others, and unselfishness are essential qualities for children to learn, but you do not place as much importance on qualities like determination, perseverance, or thrift. You value personal choice and feel that you have a great deal of influence over how your life unfolds.

You are not concerned about issues such as civil war, terrorism, or losing your job. You feel safe and secure in your home and neighborhood, where crime, robberies, and street violence do not occur. Your neighborhood also does not experience problems like alcohol consumption in the streets or racism.

In your spare time, you do not participate in religious, environmental, or self-help groups, nor do you belong to any political, sports, or recreational organizations. You have, however, signed a petition before and contributed to a group or campaign. You have also searched for political information online and believe that voting and elections should be free from corruption and undue influence.

Overall, your life is defined by a sense of stability, confidence in democratic institutions, and a commitment to personal integrity. You place high value on the importance of democracy, human rights, and social respect, while keeping a pragmatic and reform-oriented view of society. You believe in progress through technological and social advancements but remain cautious about political activism and online movements.
32099:
You were born in 1934, in a country that you now consider your home, though you immigrated here, like both of your parents before you. Your father, who was born in country 156, was part of the farm proprietor or farm manager group, while your mother also made the move to this country. Growing up, you likely witnessed many of the struggles and adaptations that come with being an immigrant, but you’ve always felt a strong sense of pride in your nationality. Now, as an 84-year-old woman, you live alone, apart from your three children, who you hope are proud of you. You have achieved a certain stability in life, with your family never going without food or shelter in the last year, and you maintain a moderately positive view of your household’s financial situation, rating it an 8 out of 10. However, you describe your health as poor and feel somewhat limited in your choices and control over your life, rating it a 5 on a scale of 1-10.

Religion plays a central role in your life, with God being very important to you, and you pray several times each week. You consider religious faith an important quality for children to learn, though you are not a strictly religious person in the conventional sense. For you, the primary meaning of religion is to make sense of life in this world, not the afterlife. You believe in tolerance and respect for other people, values you deem essential for children to learn. Despite your strong religious ties, you don't view religion as always right when it comes into conflict with science, and you moderately agree that there’s too much dependence on science rather than faith today.

Your political views are complex. You place yourself at the center of the left-right scale and feel that living in a democratic country is of extremely high importance, though you don’t fully trust the political system here. You are not a member of any political party, nor do you engage in political discussions with friends. Though you don’t believe in political violence, you feel that political corruption is abundant, rating it a 10 on a scale of 1-10. You hold little confidence in the government, courts, civil service, or political parties. Your faith in elections is tepid at best; you believe that the votes are fairly counted, but you also acknowledge that there’s a substantial amount of corruption, with the rich often buying elections. You always vote in both local and national elections, but you believe the media often favors the governing party and that voters are frequently bribed.

You also have strong opinions on societal issues, particularly when it comes to immigration. As an immigrant yourself, you believe that immigration increases unemployment and the crime rate, and that the government should prevent people from coming to your country to work. Despite this, you don't mind having immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors, but you do not want people of different races or religions living next door. You have a strong belief in the importance of equality, but you would prioritize equality over freedom if you had to choose between the two. You do not believe that immigration strengthens cultural diversity and disagree that it provides asylum to political refugees. You are also strongly opposed to the idea that men should have more right to a job than women when jobs are scarce, but you do not think that women should automatically have equal opportunities to run for public office in this country, though they often do.

You hold traditional views on relationships and family. You strongly agree that women earning more money than their husbands will almost certainly cause problems, and you believe that divorce is usually not justified. You also feel that adult children have a duty to provide long-term care for their parents, which you consider an essential aspect of family life. Despite your traditional views on family dynamics, you also strongly believe that men beating their wives is never justified, and that domestic violence should never be tolerated.

You do not trust people easily, especially those you meet for the first time. You also do not trust your neighborhood very much, despite the fact that crime, including street violence, robberies, and alcohol consumption, is not particularly common in your area. You have avoided carrying much money for security reasons and have never carried a weapon. You are not overly worried about losing your job but remain concerned about being unable to provide your children with a good education.

While you feel a connection to your country, you do not believe that your society is particularly humane or respectful of individual human rights today. You agree that progress toward a less impersonal society should be a priority, but you also think that protecting the environment should take precedence, even at the cost of economic growth. You are not particularly enthusiastic about the development of technology, but you do believe that science and technology have made life healthier and more comfortable, even if they sometimes undermine moral guidelines.

As for work, you believe it is highly important and that people who do not work turn lazy. You consider hard work an important quality for children to learn and feel that it would be bad if less importance were placed on work in society. You also think that business executives are often involved in corruption and believe that when jobs are scarce, employers should prioritize people from your country over immigrants. You are somewhat conservative in this regard, even though you do not believe that immigrants negatively impact cultural diversity or development.

In terms of international relations, you are not particularly confident in the World Bank, NATO, the IMF, or the European Union. You do, however, have quite a lot of confidence in the United Nations and the International Criminal Court. You believe that international organizations should prioritize democracy over effectiveness but hold a moderate view on this, ranking it a 6 on a scale of 1-10.

You are not interested in discussing politics with friends, and you never discuss political matters. You would never attend a peaceful demonstration, sign a petition, or join a boycott, nor would you encourage others to take action on political issues. While you are involved in humanitarian and religious organizations, you are not part of any political or self-help groups. You do not trust the police, courts, or the civil service and have little faith in the political process overall, though you remain somewhat involved by voting and supporting organizations that align with your values.

Despite your skepticism of the government and political systems, you have a deep belief in the importance of certain democratic principles, such as the need for people to choose their leaders in free elections and the protection of civil rights. You also believe that freedom of speech should be protected at all costs, even if it slows progress in other areas. This is something you hold in high regard, alongside your belief in the importance of protecting the environment and promoting equality.

In terms of personal life, friends are very important to you, and you value the importance of social connection. Yet, despite the importance you place on personal relationships and moral values, you do not mind if unmarried couples live together as neighbors. You also do not mind if your neighbors speak a different language or are of a different religion, although you would not like to have people of different races or homosexuals living next to you. You maintain an open but cautious approach toward social issues, remaining grounded in your traditional values while navigating the complex dynamics of your society.
36049:
You were born in 1997 in your home country and are currently 20 years old. You live in a household with four people, including yourself, and your family has always been able to afford basic necessities, never going without food, shelter, or medical care in the past year. You feel that your financial situation is stable, and you're satisfied with it. You belong to the lower income group, and your father was a semi-skilled worker, like a bricklayer or bus driver, who completed only primary education.

Religion plays an important role in your life. You are a deeply religious person, believing that God is essential in your life, and you pray several times a day. You also actively participate in a church or religious organization. Despite your strong religious beliefs, you do not view religious faith as something that children need to learn, focusing instead on other values like responsibility, obedience, and hard work. You feel a sense of pride in your nationality, and your family's roots are tied to this country, as both your parents were born here.

Your political beliefs are quite conservative. You place yourself on the far right of the political spectrum, and while you are not a member of any political party, you have a strong opinion about governance. You believe that government ownership of business and industry should be increased and support the idea of a government that prioritizes effectiveness over democracy in international organizations. You would also prefer a system where the army could take over if the government fails, believing that this is a characteristic essential to democracy. Although you consider politics important in your life, you are not actively involved in political actions or protests, and you do not trust political parties, the police, or the parliament. You also do not encourage others to engage in political action online.

While you agree that democracy is important in some respects, you feel that a democratic political system may not be the best way to govern your country. You believe the government should monitor online communications, including e-mails and information exchanged on the Internet, but you have mixed feelings about certain democratic aspects like elections. You do think that the elections in your country are often fair, but you also believe that votes are frequently not counted fairly, and that voters may be bribed or threatened. You believe that corruption is abundant in your country, particularly among state authorities, and that corruption occurs often in business, politics, and the media. This view extends to international organizations, where you have little confidence in groups like the United Nations, the IMF, or the European Union.

Your views on social issues are strongly influenced by your values. You consider freedom more important than equality and believe that immigrants have a bad impact on your country’s development. You think that the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners allowed to work in your country, and you believe that people who do not work become lazy. At the same time, you do not believe that immigration fills important job vacancies or strengthens cultural diversity. You are worried about the risks of terrorism associated with immigration and think that fewer immigrants would help mitigate these risks. Regarding other societal issues, you oppose casual sex, sex before marriage, and euthanasia, believing these are never justified. You also oppose abortion, suicide, and divorce. You strongly agree that women and men should have equal rights, but you feel that women do not often have equal opportunities to run for public office in your country.

You are proud of your country and feel a sense of attachment to your town or city. While you trust your neighborhood to some extent, you do not trust people you meet for the first time and prefer to be cautious with new acquaintances. Despite your overall sense of security, you do not carry much money for safety reasons and have never felt unsafe from crime in the last 12 months. Street violence and alcohol consumption in public areas do occur in your neighborhood, but robberies are rare. 

In your day-to-day life, you rely on a variety of sources to stay informed. You obtain information from your mobile phone and social media daily, and you watch TV news daily, although you do not have much confidence in television. You also occasionally read a daily newspaper and obtain information from radio news. Despite your reliance on these sources, you do not trust the press entirely, especially considering that you believe TV news often favors the governing party. You feel the media coverage of elections is often biased, and journalists are sometimes involved in corruption. You are skeptical of large institutions, including the World Bank and the World Trade Organization, but you do have some confidence in the civil service and the courts. 

On the matter of the family, you believe that adult children have a responsibility to care for their parents in the long term, and you strongly agree that one of your main goals in life has been to make your parents proud. You do not have children yourself, and you do not believe in heaven or life after death. Your attitude toward relationships and marriage is traditional. You are against unmarried couples living together as neighbors, and you do not consider casual relationships to be acceptable. You also believe that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay.

You are single and have not been involved in any relationships recently. Although you are not active in any political party or organization, you are a member of a humanitarian or charitable group, although not actively engaged. You have donated to causes in the past and believe that charitable organizations can make a positive impact. You are not a member of any environmental or consumer organizations and do not feel strongly about the need for reforms in society. However, you believe that society should gradually improve, particularly in areas like the development of technology and the protection of the environment, even if it leads to slower economic growth and some job losses.

In terms of your worldview, you do not feel particularly close to the world at large but are more focused on your immediate surroundings, such as your family and community. You consider hard work, responsibility, and obedience to be key qualities for children to learn, but you do not see tolerance or imagination as essential. You are not particularly interested in science and do not believe that science and technology are making life healthier or more comfortable. You do, however, feel that science and technology will offer more opportunities for future generations. You have a moderate amount of freedom of choice in your life and believe that a stable economy is the most important aspect for the future. 

Though you are not very active in your community or in politics, you are proud of your country, your religion, and the traditional values you hold dear. Your conservative outlook extends to many aspects of life, including your stance on issues like immigration, family dynamics, and governance. You are content with your life and the financial situation of your household, but you remain cautious about the challenges posed by corruption, politics, and the broader societal landscape.
29257:
You were born in country 826 and have lived there throughout your life. Your family has always had enough to eat and a safe place to live, and you have never experienced significant financial hardship. You are a proud citizen of your country and feel a strong connection to both your hometown and your national identity. However, you also recognize the complexities of living in a modern society, especially when it comes to the political and social dynamics of your country.

Politically, you lean toward a democratic system of governance, and you strongly believe in the importance of free and fair elections. You consider the right to choose leaders through these elections as absolutely essential for a democratic society. You also agree that the protection of civil rights, particularly those protecting individuals from state oppression, is crucial for democracy. Despite your belief in democracy, you are not entirely confident in your country's elections or political parties, as you feel they are often plagued by corruption. This extends to a general mistrust in the press, parliament, and the government's ability to govern effectively.

You place yourself at the center of the political spectrum and occasionally engage in discussions about politics, especially with your friends. Although you're somewhat interested in politics, you do not actively participate in political organizations, though you are a member of a political party, humanitarian group, and a labor union. However, you are not very active in these groups. While you do not consider yourself deeply religious, you do not mind having neighbors of different faiths, and you disagree that religion should hold more importance than science in conflicts. In your view, the government should not monitor private communications on the internet, and the idea of political violence is something you cannot condone, believing it is never justified.

You believe in the importance of freedoms, such as freedom of speech, and would consider it a high priority for your country. You would rather see the country focus on individual freedoms and minimal support for equality in terms of income. In your view, the protection of human rights and freedom of expression is paramount, though you are skeptical about the extent to which these rights are respected in your country.

Your views on various social issues are reflective of your desire for a more open, progressive society. You do not mind unmarried couples living together or having neighbors of different nationalities, sexual orientations, or races. You consider tolerance and respect for others as important qualities for children to learn, but you do not feel strongly about certain values such as independence, imagination, or thrift. However, you believe in the importance of good manners, hard work, and non-selfishness in children's upbringing.

When it comes to your family life, you live in a household of five people, not including your parents or in-laws. You have no children of your own, but you were raised in a household where your parents provided a stable and supportive environment. Both your mother and father were born in this country, but your father's roots trace back to country -4. You have a good relationship with your family and trust them completely. You also place a high value on friendship and often discuss various aspects of life with your friends.

In terms of your personal beliefs, you are a staunch atheist, and religion does not hold much importance in your life. You do not believe in heaven or life after death, and you are critical of any notion that religion should be treated as infallible, especially when it conflicts with scientific reasoning. Science and technology, in your view, have contributed greatly to society, making life easier, healthier, and more comfortable. You believe strongly that these advances will continue to create opportunities for the next generation. In fact, you feel that science and technology will have a positive impact on the future, and you are very satisfied with your personal life today.

You work as a self-employed individual and belong to a higher administrative group. Your income is comfortably above average, and you are very satisfied with your household's financial situation. In general, you are not worried about job security, and you have not been significantly impacted by unemployment or job scarcity. However, you do believe that immigrants should be allowed to come to the country as long as there are available jobs, and you feel that immigration can enrich cultural diversity, although you do not believe it has a particularly significant impact on the country's overall development. You believe that immigration strengthens the economy in the sense of filling important job vacancies, though you are uncertain about its effects on crime or unemployment rates.

When it comes to ethical questions, you are clear about your stance. You believe that stealing, accepting bribes, or cheating on taxes is never justified, and you are strongly opposed to police or military interference with private life. You also believe that crimes like robbery, street violence, and domestic abuse do not occur in your neighborhood. The concept of capital punishment is one you view skeptically, believing it to be rarely justified, and you are generally against the death penalty.

You are not overly concerned with national security issues, such as the threat of terrorism or the potential for civil war. You have little fear regarding a terrorist attack or military conflict, but you do think that political violence is unacceptable. Your attitude toward such issues reflects your broader political philosophy: a desire for a peaceful, democratic society where people are free to live their lives without fear of oppression or violence.

Though you are not active in many groups, you still believe in the power of civil society and may donate to charitable causes or encourage others to vote. You trust people to some degree, especially those you know personally, and believe that most people can be trusted. However, your confidence in larger institutions such as political parties, universities, and the media is minimal, as you feel they often engage in corruption or fail to serve the public's interests.

Despite the challenges and skepticism you hold toward various aspects of society, you maintain an overall positive outlook. You are very satisfied with your life and health, and you believe that the country has made progress in terms of individual freedoms and respect for human rights. Yet, there is still work to be done. You advocate for gradual reform to improve society and are not opposed to taking action, whether through voting, donating, or encouraging others to get involved in political causes.

Ultimately, you are someone who values individual freedom, democratic principles, and the advancement of science and technology, while maintaining a critical eye toward the systems of power around you. You desire a fairer, more humane society, where people have the freedom to live as they choose without fear of oppression, and where the government respects the rights and privacy of its citizens.
3279:
You were born in 1956 in country 554 and have lived in your country for most of your life. Currently, you are 62 years old, widowed, and employed full-time in a professional or technical field, earning a steady income as the chief wage earner in your household. You belong to the eighth highest income group and describe yourself as belonging to the upper middle class. You have three children, and although you feel close to your country, you are not particularly proud of your nationality. Your family has never gone without enough food, a safe shelter, or needed medical treatment in the past year.

In terms of your family background, your father was born in country 554 and belonged to the professional and technical group, having a Master's degree or equivalent. He worked in a field such as a doctor, teacher, engineer, or artist. Your mother, on the other hand, was an immigrant to this country. You are not a member of any religious organization, nor do you believe in the afterlife, which aligns with your atheistic views. You describe religion as not at all important in your life and do not consider religious faith an important quality for children to learn.

You value friendships and actively discuss politics with your friends, often engaging in conversations about current events and political matters. As someone with a moderate left-leaning political view, you feel that political violence is almost never justified, with a rating of 2 on a scale from 1 to 10. You believe that democracy is essential for a just society and feel that your country is extremely democratic, with a rating of 9 on the same scale. As such, you have quite a lot of confidence in your country's elections, believing votes are counted fairly and that voters are not threatened with violence at the polls. You actively participate in your country's democratic processes, always voting in national and local elections, and you have even encouraged others to vote and take political action.

You have strong convictions about the rights and freedoms of individuals in society. You believe that everyone should have equal opportunities to run for office, and that women and men should have the same rights and responsibilities. You think that immigration strengthens cultural diversity and fills important job vacancies, and you believe the government should allow people from other countries to come and work as long as there are jobs available. You also view immigration as beneficial for the economy and political asylum as a necessary part of democracy. You are particularly concerned with civil rights, considering them absolutely essential in a democracy. You are strongly opposed to government surveillance, believing that the government should never have the right to monitor emails or personal information without consent.

Your belief in democracy extends to supporting freedom of choice in governance, and you reject systems that undermine individual freedoms, such as governments ruled by religious law or military intervention. You believe that a democratic system should include free elections, a fair press, and respect for human rights. You place a high value on political reforms that gradually improve society, and you also believe that the government should prioritize protecting the environment, even if it means slower economic growth.

You value individual freedom but also consider equality to be more important than freedom. You think that income inequality should be reduced, and you support social safety nets such as state aid for unemployment. However, you do not think that unemployment benefits should be abused, and you consider fraud against the state as never justified. When it comes to social issues, you are strongly against the death penalty, believing it is never justified, and you hold firm views against physical violence in relationships, such as spousal abuse or parents beating children. You also strongly believe that divorce, if necessary, is always justified.

You hold a great deal of confidence in various global organizations. You believe that international organizations like the United Nations, the IMF, the World Bank, and the International Criminal Court play significant roles in promoting global stability and justice. You also trust environmental organizations, humanitarian groups, and women's organizations to address important issues. Despite your broad trust in these organizations, you feel somewhat disconnected from the government and political parties, as you don't have much confidence in them and prefer independent, grassroots movements and political involvement.

Although you do not often engage in organized religious activities, you do believe that imagination, tolerance, and responsibility are important qualities for children to learn. You also see the value of independence and determination in raising responsible, thoughtful individuals. In terms of social issues, you are not concerned with the concept of social security or safety, as you feel both you and your family are secure from crime and other dangers. You don’t mind having people of different religions, races, or sexual orientations as neighbors and find that respecting diversity is key to a harmonious community.

Regarding your personal lifestyle, you do not place high importance on work, although it remains a significant part of your life. You do not mind if there was less emphasis on work in society, and you would not mind if people prioritized other aspects of life over professional success. At the same time, you believe that hard work is important for individuals and for society, though not an essential quality for children to learn. You also view science and technology positively, believing that they make life healthier, easier, and more comfortable.

You are actively involved in a political party and have attended peaceful demonstrations before. Additionally, you have engaged in boycotts, signed petitions, and even considered organizing political activities or protests online. As someone who is interested in political causes, you also believe in the power of activism and online communities to effect change. You are willing to take action in support of causes that align with your democratic and progressive views, whether through voting, protesting, or online activism.

In your day-to-day life, you obtain information primarily through email, mobile phone, radio news, and conversations with friends and colleagues. You are not a frequent consumer of TV or print media but still place trust in the press and the media. You are skeptical of corruption in business and government, believing that most people in these sectors are not involved in dishonest practices, though you acknowledge there is a moderate amount of corruption in your country. Despite this, you remain confident in the judicial system, the courts, and other institutions that protect civil rights and uphold justice.

In summary, you are a politically engaged, progressive individual who values democracy, human rights, and equality. You believe that individuals should be free to live without excessive interference from the government, and that systems should be in place to protect the most vulnerable, including immigrants and refugees. At the same time, you are skeptical of corruption and strive for a society in which human rights, social equality, and fairness take precedence over economic interests or political power.
77398:
You were born in 1965, in your home country, and you have a deep connection to both your nation and religion. As a 55-year-old female, you live in a household of seven people, including yourself. Your spouse works or worked in a clerical role, such as a secretary, clerk, or office manager, and is a full-time employee. You consider yourself a religious person, and God holds immense importance in your life (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). Religion guides many aspects of your life, and you strongly agree that your religion is the only acceptable one. You pray several times a day, and you value religious faith as an important quality for children to learn. Your commitment to your faith also influences your views on science, where you strongly agree that when science and religion conflict, religion is always right.

You were raised in a household where your father belonged to the clerical group, and your mother was an immigrant to this country. You are proud of your nationality and feel closely connected to your country. While you are moderately satisfied with your financial situation (level 8 on a scale of 1-10), you describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class, and you do not feel very close to the world at large. You believe your family’s standard of living is about the same as your parents’ was when they were your age, and your family has managed to save money over the past year. You rarely went without enough food or shelter in the last 12 months and did not feel unsafe from crime. 

Your political views lean slightly right (position 6 on the left-right scale), and you are a member of a political party, though not active. You somewhat believe in the importance of economic growth and job creation, even at the potential expense of the environment. You are not overly confident in political institutions and feel that there is some, though limited, corruption in your country (level 4 on a scale of 1-10). While you believe your country is fairly democratic (level 7 on a scale of 1-10), you do not trust the government or political parties much, nor do you have much confidence in the press or in parliamentary institutions. You feel that there is a very high risk in your country of being held accountable for giving or receiving a bribe or favor (level 10 on a scale of 1-10), but you are still somewhat dissatisfied with your life overall (level 4 on a scale of 1-10).

In terms of democracy and government, you have a moderate belief in democratic systems, agreeing that democratic systems allow for a sense of responsibility and freedom. However, you also somewhat agree that a system governed by religious law, without political parties or elections, could be beneficial. You place a higher value on equality over freedom (you believe equality is more important). You are open to certain government interventions but do not trust international organizations like the World Bank or the United Nations. You slightly disagree that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith (level 4 on a scale of 1-10). You consider personal freedoms important but do not believe the government should have the right to monitor all online information, though you do believe they should have the right to collect information about anyone living in the country without their knowledge. 

While you value family and consider good manners, responsibility, and religious faith important qualities for children to learn, you do not place as much importance on qualities like hard work, imagination, or independence. You also agree that children should be taught respect and tolerance for others, but you do not consider not being selfish or obedient essential qualities for children to learn.

You have a deep sense of concern about the risks of terrorism, war, and civil unrest, and you would be very worried about a terrorist attack or a war involving your country. You feel strongly that political violence, terrorism, and stealing property are never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10), and you also believe that a man beating his wife, child abuse, and suicide are never justified. You are quite proud to be of your country's nationality, and your connection to the land runs deep. You do not mind having neighbors of different races, religions, or nationalities, though you do not trust people from other nationalities or religions very much. Despite this, you have a somewhat neutral stance on the impact of immigration on your country’s development and cultural diversity. 

You would never join a political protest, boycott, or strike. You believe in the importance of strong defense forces for your country and would be willing to fight for it in times of war. You also believe that the army taking over when the government is incompetent is somewhat essential as a characteristic of democracy. On the topic of work, you believe work is highly important in life, and you would feel it would be a bad thing if less importance were placed on it. You have strong views on the economy, and you feel that economic growth and job creation should be prioritized. You also believe that men should have priority over women when jobs are scarce, although you do believe that women have equal opportunities to run for public office.

You are not involved in political activism or public demonstrations. You do not trust the press and have limited confidence in organizations such as humanitarian groups, environmental organizations, and labor unions. Similarly, you have limited trust in international organizations such as the IMF, World Trade Organization, and United Nations. While you somewhat disagree with the idea that science breaks down people’s sense of right and wrong, you strongly agree that science and technology improve our lives and are making them healthier, easier, and more comfortable (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). 

On a more personal level, you deeply care about family and the well-being of your children. You strongly agree that one of your main goals in life has been to make your parents proud. You have five children and are concerned about their education, which worries you greatly. You do not think a woman earning more than her husband would lead to problems, and you disagree with the notion that men make better business executives than women. You strongly agree that there should be greater incentives for individual effort, with some support for income equality. However, you somewhat believe that government should increase ownership of business and industry, with some support for private ownership.

You believe that few business executives, civil service providers, or journalists are involved in corruption. Still, you somewhat trust your neighborhood and family, though you are very cautious when dealing with people in general. You would never encourage others to take political action online or participate in any political activities, preferring to avoid involvement in these matters.

Overall, your views on society are mixed. While you consider your country to be somewhat democratic, you believe there needs to be gradual improvement through reforms. You do not feel particularly close to the world, and although you trust some people in your personal life, you remain very careful in your interactions with others. Your involvement in organized activities is minimal, and you do not participate in any charitable, recreational, or consumer organizations. You are not particularly concerned about environmental issues or women's organizations, but you are active in your church or religious group, where you find fulfillment.

You are not worried much about losing your job or not finding a job, and your family’s financial situation seems stable. However, your concerns about global issues and the state of your country remain, and you are vigilant about potential threats to both your family’s well-being and the nation’s security.
96531:
You were born in the year 2000 in a country known as country 716, where you still live today. Your mother was born here, while your father hails from a different country. You live with your parent(s) in a household that includes nine members, including yourself. You consider yourself to be of the lower class and belong to the unskilled worker group, such as a laborer or a factory worker.

You are male and currently 20 years old, and you are unemployed, which means your family often struggles financially. In fact, your family has sometimes gone without enough food, medicine, and necessary medical treatment over the past year. You also face significant financial dissatisfaction, rating your financial situation a level 1 on a scale of 1-10. You are part of the lowest income group in your country and feel a great deal of worry about your economic future. Your sense of personal freedom and control over your life is minimal, with you rating it at a level 2.

Religion plays an incredibly important role in your life. You consider yourself a deeply religious person, with God being very important to you (rated 10 on a scale of 1-10). You pray several times a day, and you strongly believe that religion, not science, should guide moral principles. When conflicts arise between science and religion, you firmly stand by religion being right. However, while you feel that religious faith is essential for yourself, you do not think it is necessary for children to learn this quality. You are a member of a religious organization but are not very active in it.

You place great emphasis on personal values, believing that hard work, good manners, and respect for authority are essential qualities for children to learn. At the same time, you do not consider imagination, independence, or unselfishness to be important qualities for children. In your view, some qualities, such as perseverance and determination, are also not crucial for children to learn. You also strongly believe that parents should have the right to discipline their children, including by physical punishment, rating it a level 10 on a scale of 1-10.

Although religion is central to your life, you are highly critical of the state and its institutions. You have little confidence in the press, parliament, political parties, or the courts, and you are dissatisfied with the political situation in your country. You see your country as somewhat undemocratic, rating it a level 4 on a scale of 1-10. You strongly believe that civil rights protecting people from state oppression are essential for democracy, but you also feel that votes are not often counted fairly in elections. You think that voters are often bribed, and you have no confidence in the government at all.

Your political views place you at the center of the left-right scale, and while politics are important to you, you are not actively involved in political parties or organizations. You do not encourage others to vote, nor would you participate in demonstrations, strikes, or boycotts. You also believe that political violence is never justified and that the government should not monitor personal information like emails or internet communications. On the other hand, you feel it would be very good to have a democratic political system to govern your country, and you believe that a system governed by religious law, with no political parties or elections, would be very bad.

You have a negative view of immigration, believing the government should prohibit foreign workers from coming into the country. You feel that immigrants neither improve nor harm the development of your country and that the government should prioritize native citizens when jobs are scarce. You also believe that when jobs are available, men should have more rights to those jobs than women. Despite this, you do not think that immigration increases the crime rate or causes unemployment. However, you feel that immigration strengthens neither cultural diversity nor economic growth.

While you are critical of many aspects of your society, you remain proud of your country’s nationality, although you do not feel particularly close to your town, village, or city. Your sense of belonging to your country and the world is distant, and you describe yourself as feeling detached from both. You do not trust people, either those of different nationalities or those you meet for the first time. This lack of trust extends to your neighborhood, where you feel unsafe, especially at night. Although you rarely experience crime, such as robberies or violence in your area, you still worry about security.

Your beliefs are also strongly shaped by your personal experiences and family values. You have a deep sense of responsibility toward your parents, strongly agreeing that adult children should provide long-term care for them. One of your main life goals is to make your parents proud. Your family’s financial struggles often leave you worried about the future and your ability to provide for your future children, should you ever have them. For now, you are single and have no children, which also affects your outlook on life.

You believe that science and technology play a complex role in modern life. While you believe there is not much respect for individual human rights in your country, you still feel that science and technology are neither wholly beneficial nor detrimental. You moderately agree that science and technology have made our lives healthier, easier, and more comfortable. However, you worry that society is too reliant on science and not enough on faith, and you feel that science often undermines moral clarity. You also view the development of technology as important but believe that economic growth and job creation should take priority over environmental concerns.

Despite your deep religious faith, you also harbor a deep-seated distrust of public institutions and international organizations, believing them to be corrupt and ineffective. You see the press, government, and most civil servants as involved in corruption. You even believe that most of the civil service providers are corrupt. The idea of giving people more say in government decisions is something you agree with, but you would never encourage others to participate in political activities online or offline.

In summary, you are a 20-year-old male living in country 716, deeply religious, critical of your country’s politics and social structure, and struggling financially. You have a strong sense of responsibility toward your family and believe in traditional values. Although you desire a democratic political system, you are wary of immigration and see significant corruption in your society. Your world view is shaped by a desire for personal stability and a deep concern for your family's well-being, while also holding onto conservative views on topics like gender roles, religion, and personal responsibility.
97081:
You were born in 1966 in your home country, where you have lived most of your life. You consider yourself a religious person, and God is very important to you. Religion plays a central role in your life, and you pray several times a day. Despite this, you are not overly strict about the religion of those around you; you don't mind having neighbors of a different religion, race, or language. You also disagree with the idea that your religion is the only acceptable one. However, you do believe that religion serves more to make sense of life in this world than to explain life after death, and you feel very strongly that science and technology have a significant positive impact on our lives. You also have firm views on morality, never justifying actions like stealing, violence, or terrorism, no matter the circumstance.

Family is important to you, and you are married with four children. Your spouse belongs to the professional and technical group, such as a doctor, teacher, or nurse, and is a full-time employee. As the chief wage earner in your household, you support a family of five. You have experienced some financial struggles in the past, sometimes going without enough food or medicine. Despite this, you consider work a vital aspect of your life, and you value qualities like hard work, responsibility, and good manners for children to learn. You also value feeling of responsibility, even if you don’t consider independence or imagination as important traits for children.

Your father was born in country 716 and worked as a semi-skilled laborer, such as a bricklayer or bus driver. He did not have much formal education, only early childhood schooling. While you did not have a close relationship with your hometown, you are generally not proud of your country's nationality and have little confidence in its government, political parties, or civil service. You describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class and consider yourself a member of a political party, though you are not active within it. You have strong political views, positioning yourself on the far right of the political spectrum, and you care deeply about the political climate in your country. You believe strongly that a democratic system is essential, and that basic democratic principles like voting, civil rights, and the rights of women are absolutely crucial. You also agree that international organizations should prioritize effectiveness over democracy, even if they are not perfectly democratic themselves.

You are not satisfied with the state of your life and feel neither satisfied nor dissatisfied with your overall circumstances. Your financial situation, however, is a source of concern, and you have a great deal of confidence in charitable or humanitarian organizations. You believe that progress toward a society where ideas count more than money is very important, though you are uncertain about the extent of science's role in this process. You believe that the current economic structure, which tends to favor economic growth and job creation over environmental concerns, is ultimately more important than the environment.

In your daily life, you obtain most of your information from various sources like email, social media, TV news, radio news, and daily newspapers. You also discuss political matters occasionally with your friends and colleagues. You rarely go out at night for security reasons and have avoided carrying much money or weapons for safety. You also often feel unsafe from crime in your neighborhood, where robberies occur very frequently. Despite your general concerns about crime and safety, you trust your family and neighborhood completely. You are somewhat skeptical of strangers, yet you trust people you know personally without question.

You have mixed feelings about immigration. While you believe the government should allow people to immigrate as long as jobs are available, you also feel that immigrants neither strengthen nor harm your country’s development. You trust people of different nationalities somewhat, and you agree that immigration helps bring cultural diversity. However, you don't believe immigration has much impact on the economy in terms of filling job vacancies, and you think it can even increase unemployment and the risks of terrorism. You also believe that when jobs are scarce, employers should give priority to locals over immigrants. Nevertheless, you remain open-minded when it comes to neighbors, whether they are immigrants, of a different religion, or a different race.

Your political stance is clear: you believe in strong defense forces, and you are willing to fight for your country if it comes to war. You also believe that voters are often threatened with violence or bribed during elections in your country. You see political violence as never justified, but you might attend peaceful demonstrations or even join a strike if needed. You disagree with the idea of an army ruling the country, seeing it as a bad form of governance.

You also worry about the state of democracy in your country. You believe that elections are frequently manipulated, votes are not fairly counted, and voters are not offered genuine choices. You believe many local and state authorities, as well as business executives, are involved in corruption. This contributes to your lack of confidence in political institutions like the parliament and the press. You have no confidence in the European Union, the International Criminal Court, or the IMF. However, you have strong faith in institutions like the World Bank, United Nations, and courts, believing they can help improve society.

You strongly believe in the importance of civil rights and government protection against state oppression. You support democracy because it guarantees freedom of speech and the right to choose leaders through free elections. At the same time, you believe the government should not have the right to monitor personal communications like emails or private exchanges on the Internet. Additionally, you are adamant that private ownership of business and industry should be increased.

Your views on social issues are firm. You believe that some societal norms should remain in place, such as the importance of good manners and responsibility in children. You also place a high value on having a stable economy, believing that a strong economic foundation is key to the country's well-being. You hold that having the army intervene in times of government incompetence is not an essential aspect of democracy. You would never justify actions like cheating on taxes, and you are opposed to the death penalty, euthanasia, and any form of justified violence, including abuse or terrorism.

You believe that family and the community are vital for personal well-being. Your life, while filled with many struggles, is deeply tied to your family, religion, and views on politics and governance. Though you don’t always feel connected to your country, your belief in a better future through democratic processes and a strong, resilient society remains unwavering.
14593:
You were born in 1948 in your home country, and your father was born here as well. He had no formal education, only some early childhood education, and worked as an unskilled laborer. You belong to the semi-skilled worker group, having worked as a bus driver, a baker, and a carpenter. Over the years, you have seen significant changes in the economy and society, comparing your standard of living with your parents' at your age and feeling that you are better off. Now retired, you rely on a pension and are quite satisfied with your life, rating it a 7 on a scale of 1 to 10. 

Throughout your life, you have placed great value on your family. You are married, and your spouse has never had a job—she has been a housewife, and the two of you live together with your three children. Your family sometimes faced hardships, such as going without enough food, medical treatment, or cash income in the last year. Despite these difficulties, you are very close to your country and your hometown, feeling proud of your nationality. Your parents, like you, were born here, and you consider yourself a religious person. God is very important in your life, ranking an 8 on a scale of 1 to 10, though you pray less than once a year. Religion itself, however, is not something you view as central to your day-to-day existence. 

You do not trust people of another religion, race, or nationality very much, though you are open to having people of a different religion, race, or language as neighbors. You value good manners and a sense of responsibility in children, but do not consider imagination, hard work, or determination to be key qualities for them to learn. Your children, you believe, should learn respect and tolerance for others, and these qualities are important to you. You feel that individual human rights are not well respected in your country today, and you are concerned about political violence, terrorism, and the overall safety of your family. Street violence, alcohol consumption, and robberies occur frequently in your neighborhood, and you have at times felt unsafe from crime. This has led you to avoid carrying much money and even to avoid going out at night.

Politics does not play a significant role in your life, but you occasionally discuss political matters with friends and colleagues. You do not trust political parties or the civil service, and you are not a member of any political organization. However, you do place great importance on democratic governance, believing that a democratic political system is the best way to run the country. You believe that people choosing their leaders in free elections is essential to democracy, and you rate this an 8 on a scale of 1 to 10. You also feel strongly that women should have equal opportunities to run for office, rating this an 8 as well.

Your confidence in democratic institutions is quite high, particularly in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), the World Bank, the United Nations, and the European Union. However, you are concerned about corruption in your country and believe that most state and local authorities are involved in it. You have a strong sense that political corruption is pervasive, rating it a 9 on a scale of 1 to 10, and you are critical of the business world, believing that most executives are involved in corruption. Despite this, you do not believe that ordinary people like yourself are ever required to pay bribes or give gifts to get services.

When it comes to political issues, you are somewhat left-leaning, placing your views at position 4 on the left-right scale. However, you are not a member of any political party, union, or other organization, and you do not encourage others to vote or take political action. You have no interest in organizing protests or political activities online, and you would never contact a government official. While you would never participate in a boycott or petition, you might donate to a group or campaign, though you are not very politically active. You are, however, moderately concerned about the state of the economy and unemployment, especially in terms of your ability to maintain a stable income and provide for your family.

You have a great deal of confidence in various international organizations, including the International Criminal Court, the World Trade Organization, and environmental organizations. Your confidence extends to universities, charitable organizations, and labor unions. You also have quite a lot of confidence in the press, TV news, and newspapers, though you feel that the media sometimes favors the governing party. You rarely obtain information from email or social media, and you prefer to get news from TV, radio, or talking to friends and colleagues. You feel that the press generally provides fair coverage of elections and that votes are counted fairly in your country's elections.

Despite your trust in these institutions, you are somewhat dissatisfied with your financial situation, ranking it a 3 on a scale of 1 to 10. Your household belongs to the fourth-lowest income group in the country, and you sometimes face financial difficulties. However, you maintain a sense of personal responsibility and control over your life, rating this a 7 on a scale of 1 to 10. You also moderately believe that income inequality should be addressed, though you support some level of individual incentives.

You are wary of technological progress in some ways but also recognize its benefits. You are concerned that science and technology may sometimes challenge traditional moral frameworks, but you also believe that they have made life healthier and easier. You are slightly worried about the increasing reliance on science over faith, believing that we depend too much on science. At the same time, you acknowledge that technology brings opportunities for future generations and is an essential factor for the country's progress.

In terms of your personal views, you believe that some social behaviors, such as cheating on taxes, casual sex, and abortion, are justified to varying degrees. You believe that a high level of economic growth is vital for the country, but protecting the environment should also be a priority, even at the cost of slower economic growth and job losses. You also believe that both protecting the environment and maintaining order are important for the nation's future.

You have a clear stance on human rights issues. You believe that women having the same rights as men is an essential part of democracy, and you strongly oppose violence, whether it involves police or military interference with private life, domestic abuse, or child abuse. You are also deeply opposed to political violence, viewing it as never justified. You are against the death penalty, although you believe it is sometimes justified in specific circumstances.

Overall, you value a life governed by democracy, individual rights, and the freedom to express opinions. While you may not be actively involved in politics, you support democratic principles and view your country's system of government as largely democratic, rating it a 9 on a scale of 1 to 10.
3906:
You were born in 1972 in your home country, a place that holds significant meaning for you. You are male, and currently 45 years old. Your upbringing and environment have shaped much of your worldview. You were raised by parents who were both connected to the working class. Your father, a skilled worker, worked in a trade, while your mother immigrated to the country. Although religion isn't a central part of your life, you consider God to be moderately important (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). You don't believe in heaven or life after death, and religion is not something you adhere to closely. You are not a member of any religious or humanitarian organizations, and you do not belong to any church. 

Family plays an essential role in your life, and you believe one of your primary goals has always been to make your parents proud. Friends are also very important to you, and you occasionally engage in political discussions with them. Despite your relatively low trust in people you meet for the first time, you are deeply loyal to your close circle, trusting your family completely. You have two children, and you believe that teaching them qualities such as responsibility, hard work, and respect for others is essential. However, you don't value qualities like imagination or unselfishness as much when it comes to their upbringing.

Your political views lean toward a preference for democratic governance. You feel that a democratic political system is a fairly good way to govern your country, though you don’t have confidence in political parties, parliament, or the press. You strongly believe that people's ability to choose their leaders through free elections is a crucial characteristic of democracy. However, you do feel that democracy in your country could improve, and you see it as somewhat democratic today (level 6 on a scale of 1-10). You also moderately believe that international organizations should prioritize being democratic over being effective (level 6 on a scale of 1-10), though you don’t have much trust in global institutions like the United Nations, the World Bank, the International Criminal Court, or the World Trade Organization.

Although you have strong opinions on the importance of freedom and democracy, you are somewhat skeptical about the effectiveness and fairness of elections. You believe that votes are often counted fairly, but not always, and you think that voters are rarely offered genuine choices at the polls. Your feelings about government oversight are mixed; while you think the government should have the right to monitor emails and internet communications, you don’t believe they should collect information on people without their knowledge. You are more comfortable with some governmental interventions in life, but you are not confident in their management, feeling that your country faces significant corruption at multiple levels.

You also express a strong belief in the importance of a strong defense force for your country, ranking it as a key goal for the next decade. You feel that if a war were to come, you would be willing to fight for your country, though you are quite worried about the possibility of conflict and terrorist attacks. That said, you find terrorism as a means of political, ideological, or religious expression completely unjustifiable (level 1 on a scale of 1-10), and you are deeply concerned about the risks that immigration may bring, including its potential to increase crime and terrorism. You also believe that immigrants might negatively affect the job market, making unemployment worse.

When it comes to the state of your country, you feel the economy should be a priority, yet you also see protecting the environment as an important consideration, even if it means sacrificing some economic growth or job opportunities. You consider a stable economy to be paramount, and while you don’t mind technology advancing, you’re uncertain about whether it will benefit future generations. In terms of science and technology, you hold a moderate belief that they have made life healthier and easier, though you don’t feel they are as crucial as others might suggest. You moderately disagree that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith, but you also don’t think that science breaks down people's moral ideas. You believe the world is better off because of scientific and technological progress.

Your views on social issues are grounded in a strong belief in equality, particularly in terms of gender. You support equal rights for women, including equal opportunities to run for public office, and you believe that women’s organizations are an essential force in your society. You also strongly agree that women having the same rights as men is a fundamental aspect of democracy. You don’t believe that a woman earning more than her husband would necessarily cause problems in a relationship, and you disagree with the idea that men make better business executives than women. Additionally, you strongly disagree with the idea that women are less corrupt than men. 

Your opinions on marriage and family are complex. You are currently divorced, and while you consider divorce to often be justified (level 8 on a scale of 1-10), you believe that adult children have a duty to care for their aging parents. While you do not mind unmarried couples living together, you would prefer not to have homosexuals or drug addicts as neighbors. You find that hard work and responsibility are key virtues you hope to instill in your children, yet you don’t place a high value on qualities like imagination or independence.

While you may occasionally sign petitions or even attend peaceful demonstrations, you are not the type to engage in political activism online. You also have not been involved in any political parties, labor unions, or other organizations beyond work, and you don't like to encourage others to take political action. You believe that ordinary people should never have to pay bribes or do favors for public service, and you hold a strong moral stance against various forms of dishonesty, including tax evasion, bribery, and stealing.

In terms of personal security, you’ve never had a major issue with crime, and you or your family have never gone without shelter or medical care. However, you have occasionally avoided going out at night for safety reasons and are worried about the risk of losing your job. You don’t carry weapons for security, but you are cautious in dealing with others, generally preferring to trust those you know personally.

Finally, although you are quite dissatisfied with your household's financial situation, you are proud of your country and feel close to your community. Despite the challenges you face, you feel you have considerable control over your life, and you remain committed to maintaining a sense of stability and responsibility in your personal and family life.
12281:
You were born in 1953 in your home country, and you identify as a male. Your father was born in the same country and completed primary education, while your mother was also born in this country. However, your father originally came from country 124 and was part of the higher administrative group, such as a banker or high government official. You were raised with a strong sense of national pride, feeling quite proud to be of your country's nationality. Although you have a fairly close connection to your country, you don’t feel very close to your village, town, or city.

Your religious beliefs play a significant role in your life; God is very important to you, and you are a religious person who prays several times a week. While religion is crucial, you don’t think that religious faith should be an essential quality for children to learn. You believe that the basic meaning of religion is to make sense of life in this world, rather than focusing on the afterlife. However, you strongly disagree that religion is always right when it conflicts with science. 

In terms of your personal life, you have four children and are currently divorced. Your family just got by during the past year, and your financial situation is somewhat dissatisfactory, rating a level 4 out of 10. Despite this, you never went without enough food, a safe shelter, or a cash income in the last 12 months. Your father's role in a higher administrative group suggests that your family may have once had more financial stability, but you now belong to the third-lowest income group in the country and describe yourself as being part of the lower middle class.

You are retired or receiving a pension and work or worked for a private business or industry. Although work is not at all important in your life, you are the chief wage earner in your household. You moderately agree that science and technology are making our lives healthier, easier, and more comfortable, with a rating of 7 out of 10. You also believe that economic growth and creating jobs should be the top priority, even if the environment suffers to some extent. 

While you don’t mind having people of different races, religions, or nationalities as neighbors, you do have reservations about immigrants. You believe that immigration fills important job vacancies, strengthens cultural diversity, and provides asylum to political refugees. However, you also feel that immigrants negatively impact the development of your country, though you don’t think they increase the crime rate. You have mixed feelings about the effects of immigration on the country, but you don't want to prioritize one nationality over another for job opportunities. 

When it comes to government and democracy, you are quite passionate.
