Religion plays a central role in your life. You believe that God is extremely important (level 9 on a scale of 1-10) and that your religion is the only acceptable one. You pray several times a day, and you consider yourself a religious person. You hold the belief that religious faith is an important quality for children to learn, alongside good manners, responsibility, and tolerance for others. You also believe that women should have the same rights as men, and that protecting the environment is a priority, even if it slows down economic growth and causes job loss.

Your spouse, who has never had a job, is or was a housewife. You are not living with your parents or in-laws, and your family has never gone without enough food, medicine, or shelter in the past year. You have four children, and one of your main goals in life has been to make your parents proud. You strongly agree that it is important for children to learn the value of responsibility and respect for others.

In terms of your political beliefs, you strongly lean right, placing your views at position 9 on the left-right scale. You do not belong to any political party, but you occasionally discuss political matters with friends. You are very interested in the democratic political system, believing it would be very good for your country. You place a high value on civil rights, believing they are a very essential characteristic of democracy, with a score of 9 out of 10. You also believe that the government should not monitor personal information online or collect it without consent, which you view as an infringement on freedom. 

You strongly support the idea of democratic elections, believing that people should have the ability to choose their leaders freely, and that it is essential for the government to protect individual rights and freedoms. You believe that votes are counted fairly often, though you feel that voters are not always offered a genuine choice. You also believe that voters are not often threatened with violence or bribed during elections. 

However, you are very wary of the government's power and have little confidence in it. You are not very trusting of political parties, the police, the civil service, or the courts. You believe that corruption is rampant at all levels of government, with local authorities, state authorities, and the media often involved. You also feel that corruption is prevalent in the civil service and believe that most journalists and media people are involved in corruption as well.

In matters of social issues, you believe that freedom and equality are important, but you consider equality to be more important when forced to choose. You feel strongly that people who do not work tend to become lazy, and that strict limits should be placed on the number of foreigners allowed to work in your country. You believe immigration can sometimes negatively impact the economy and society, increasing unemployment and the crime rate. However, you also believe it strengthens cultural diversity and provides asylum to political refugees. You think it would be bad if immigrants were given preference over local workers in times of scarce jobs. You believe that immigration does not fill important job vacancies and that foreign workers should be limited. You trust people from your own country more than you trust immigrants or people from other nationalities.

You strongly agree that there should be less emphasis on work in our lives and that political violence is almost never justified. You also strongly disagree with the idea of military interference with private life, especially in your neighborhood, where you feel no security issues or crimes occur. You have avoided carrying much money for security reasons, but you trust your family completely.

While you don't feel very interested in politics on a day-to-day basis, you occasionally follow news from various sources, including the daily newspaper, mobile phone, and social media. You are not involved in any political organizations or protests, but you might join a boycott, a petition, or even a peaceful demonstration if the cause resonates with you. You also support the idea that people should have a say in how things are done at their jobs and in their communities, which you view as the second most important goal for the country over the next decade.

When it comes to international matters, you place a great deal of confidence in organizations such as NATO, the World Bank, the International Criminal Court, and the European Union. However, you also believe that international organizations should prioritize democracy over effectiveness. You support the idea of a democratic system governing the country and would feel very negatively if a system based on religious law with no elections or political parties were implemented. You are also confident in the role of charitable organizations and the importance of helping others in need, but you are not very active in these groups.

In terms of your views on society, you believe it is essential to radically change the entire way society is organized, but not through violent means. You think that there is extensive corruption in your country and that society would benefit from greater respect for individual rights and freedom. You are not a member of any consumer, sport, or self-help organizations, but you do occasionally participate in some form of political action.

Overall, you describe yourself as someone who feels very much in control of your life and is very satisfied with the way things have turned out. You are satisfied with your financial situation, family, and personal beliefs, although you worry about the potential for political or economic instability, and you hope for a peaceful future.
20380:
You were born in the year 1966 in country 792, and like many immigrants, you have a complex relationship with both your homeland and your adopted country. Your father, also born in country 792, immigrated here and was part of the semi-skilled worker group, such as a bus driver or bricklayer. Your mother, likewise, was an immigrant to this country. You were raised in a household where your father worked as a manual laborer and your mother helped raise the family.

At 53 years old, you are currently employed full-time, working 30 or more hours a week, and are the chief wage earner in your household, which includes four members. You live with your own parent(s) and your spouse, though they have never had a job. Despite the challenges of being part of the working class, you find comfort in your job and in your family life, though your financial situation is only moderately satisfying. You would say that you are better off compared to your parents when they were your age, but still feel the economic pressures of being in the third-lowest income group in your country.

Politically, you describe yourself as being in the center, placing your views at position 5 on the left-right scale. Although politics is not highly important in your life, you are actively involved in a political party and might attend peaceful demonstrations or participate in online political activities. You believe that the democratic system is the best way to govern your country and are strongly committed to living in a country governed democratically. In fact, you consider having a democratic government absolutely essential, ranking it 10 out of 10 in terms of importance. You strongly agree that religious law with no elections or political parties would be a bad system, and you find the idea of a society governed by such a law quite troubling. While you are not overly politically active, you have encouraged others to vote and have even contacted a government official in the past. 

When it comes to your views on society, you believe that it must be gradually improved by reforms. You are not particularly confident in the press or the government, and you believe that corruption is pervasive within state authorities, civil service, and local authorities. In fact, you consider your country to have considerable corruption, ranking it 7 out of 10. You distrust the courts, the police, and organizations like the IMF and the UN, showing little faith in these institutions to enact positive change. Your trust in international organizations like NATO, the World Bank, and the WTO is also quite low. 

You hold certain values strongly, particularly when it comes to issues like family, work, and religion. You consider religion to be a key part of your life and believe that God plays an important role in the world. You pray several times a week, and your faith influences your worldview. You place great importance on having good manners and hard work as qualities to teach your children. You are also deeply concerned about issues like the duty of adult children to provide long-term care for their parents and maintaining respect for human rights. You find it unacceptable for anyone to engage in actions like stealing, cheating on taxes, or accepting bribes, and you strongly believe that domestic violence and child abuse are never justified.

While you place a high value on personal responsibility, you believe that equality is slightly more important than freedom. However, you agree that in times of scarce jobs, men should have more right to work than women, and that women who earn more than their husbands are likely to face problems in their relationships. You also think that men, on the whole, make better business executives than women do. When it comes to immigration, your views are mixed. On one hand, you believe that immigrants can help fill important job vacancies and strengthen cultural diversity, but you also think that immigration increases unemployment and crime rates, and you worry about the risks that it may bring, such as terrorism. In terms of international relations, you are particularly concerned about the potential for war and terrorism, believing that a good deal of worry is warranted in these areas.

Although you are not especially satisfied with your household's financial situation, you feel you have not gone without basic needs like food, medicine, or shelter over the past year. You do not feel unsafe from crime or the lack of security, though you are not someone who avoids carrying money or going out at night for safety reasons. You do not carry weapons for security, but you do remain cautious in dealings with people, trusting them only somewhat. You do, however, trust your family completely and have a strong bond with them.

In your community, you generally do not feel that social problems like street violence, alcohol consumption, or robberies are frequent. You also find that political discussions with friends occasionally occur, though you are not especially interested in politics. You feel a sense of connection to your village or town, and you do not mind having neighbors of different religions, races, or nationalities, but you would not want unmarried couples or homosexuals living next door.

Regarding international matters, you do not have much confidence in the press or in global organizations like the World Trade Organization or the European Union, though you do believe that the EU is somewhat effective. You think that people often make decisions based on financial or material concerns, which detracts from a more humane society. In fact, you consider the progress toward a society where ideas matter more than money to be the second most important goal, after political freedom.

As for your personal life, you do not have any children and have no strong opinions on the importance of work over other aspects of life. You would not mind if there were less emphasis on work in society, though you consider work to be important for yourself. You do not mind if more emphasis were placed on technology or if there were more respect for authority in society. However, you feel strongly that tolerance and respect for others should be an important quality for children to learn. Your relationship with your spouse is stable, but they have never had a job, which has not seemed to affect your satisfaction with life overall, which you rate 8 out of 10. You do not consider yourself to be a member of any religious or humanitarian organizations, though you are involved in a labor union, and you do not mind having immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors.
28222:
You were born in 1988 in country 276, and your father hails from country -4, while your mother is an immigrant to this country. You are currently 33 years old, unemployed, and a single woman. You live in a household with four people, including yourself, and consider your family’s financial situation quite unsatisfactory, rating it a 2 out of 10. Over the past year, your family has sometimes struggled with not having enough cash income, and occasionally went without needed medicine or medical treatment. Despite these hardships, you or your family rarely went without enough food or a safe shelter in the last 12 months, though your family just managed to get by.

You do not currently live with your parents or in-laws, but you are the chief wage earner in your household. Work is fairly important to you, but you believe that less importance should be placed on work in society as a whole. You also believe that equality is more important than freedom, and you see a significant role for immigration in filling important job vacancies and strengthening cultural diversity, though you also think that immigrants have a negative impact on the development of your country. You do not mind having immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors, nor people of different religions, races, or languages. However, you somewhat disagree with the idea that immigration increases unemployment or crime rates.

When it comes to politics, you are not a member of any political party, nor do you discuss political matters with your friends. You rarely engage in political activities and would never encourage others to vote or take political action online. You do not trust politicians, the government, or the press, and you feel that elections in your country are often compromised by corruption and bribery. You also have no confidence in political parties, the International Criminal Court, the European Union, or the World Bank. You are highly dissatisfied with the state of your country’s governance, and you consider it to be somewhat undemocratic.

Regarding your views on democracy, you strongly agree that civil rights protecting individuals from state oppression are essential, but you do not believe that women having equal rights with men is an essential characteristic of democracy. You also hold that voters in your country are often threatened with violence or bribed at the polls, and you have little faith in the fairness of the press in covering elections. You are also quite disillusioned with most of the civil service, local authorities, and business executives, whom you believe are often involved in corruption. 

You have a deep distrust of most information sources. You never obtain information from TV news, email, or mobile phones, and rarely use daily newspapers. Instead, you get news from the radio and social media daily. Despite your strong reliance on these alternative sources, you completely disagree with the idea that science and technology improve life, and you do not find science essential to your daily life. You hold a strong belief that science breaks down people’s moral values and that technology has worsened the world.

In terms of personal beliefs, you value good manners, tolerance, respect, independence, and a sense of responsibility as important qualities for children to learn. You also believe in the importance of making your parents proud, although you do not feel very close to your village, town, or city. Despite these values, you do not consider religious faith, imagination, hard work, or unselfishness important qualities for children to develop. Religion itself is not particularly central in your life, though you do believe in God and heaven. 

You do not trust people you meet for the first time and generally feel the need to be very careful in dealing with others. You trust your family and neighborhood, but are cautious about trusting people beyond that circle. You do not mind having people who speak a different language or have different beliefs as neighbors, though you are concerned about the frequent street violence and fights in your neighborhood. Despite this, you are not particularly worried about a terrorist attack or civil war, but you do feel considerable concern about the possibility of losing your job.

You consider your health to be fair, and though you are moderately satisfied with your life as a whole, you do feel limited in terms of the control and freedom you have over your life, rating it a 3 out of 10. In general, you feel that society needs gradual reforms, and you place importance on improving the nation’s order. You have no confidence in universities, the police, or any media outlets and hold the belief that most journalists and media people are corrupt. 

Your views on various social issues are quite liberal in some respects but conservative in others. You strongly believe that stealing property, terrorism, and cheating on taxes are never justified. You also consider that parents beating children and voting violence should never be justified. However, you consider casual sex and sex before marriage always justified and have a lenient stance on fare evasion. You also believe that living together without marriage and homosexuality are not issues to be concerned about.

Though you are not a member of any humanitarian or charitable organization, you have confidence in such organizations, as well as women’s organizations and the civil service. You are also moderately involved in a labor union and trust in the responsibility of the courts. However, you find your standard of living comparable to that of your parents when they were your age. 

Overall, your life is marked by both personal struggles and a sense of responsibility, tempered with deep cynicism towards the systems that govern you. You prioritize independence and community, but your faith in political and social institutions is minimal. You believe that the nation needs reform and greater respect for authority, but your sense of agency and control over your life remains limited.
13397:
You were born in 1961 in country 372, and you immigrated to this country at some point in your life. As an immigrant, you’ve learned to adapt to your new environment, though your roots remain deeply connected to your birthplace. You hold your country’s nationality with pride, yet feel a strong sense of attachment to your town or city, finding it important to feel close to where you live. You have made this country your home, and in doing so, you have created a family here.

Your household consists of two members, including yourself, and you are married to a spouse who is or was a housewife not otherwise employed. You have two children, and as a father, you consider certain values to be crucial in their upbringing. Among those values, you consider determination, perseverance, and tolerance for others to be especially important for them to learn. However, you don't feel that qualities such as imagination, unselfishness, or obedience are as essential. Additionally, you emphasize the importance of good manners and independence in your children’s education.

Regarding your personal life, you work as a skilled worker, either as a foreman, motor mechanic, or in a similar role. You are self-employed and are the chief wage earner in your household. Despite the importance you place on work, you are not overly concerned about your job security or the possibility of unemployment. In fact, you do not worry at all about losing your job or finding a new one, and you are confident that your financial situation is very stable.

Politically, you tend to lean moderately right, placing yourself at position 7 on the left-right scale. You are not a member of any political party, but politics is rather important to you, and you occasionally discuss political matters with friends. You are a somewhat active participant in political life, having encouraged others to vote, sign petitions, and take political action online. You also support peaceful demonstrations, boycotts, and strikes when necessary. Your belief in democracy is strong: you think a democratic system of governance is the best way to lead the country, and you consider living in a country with free elections and civil rights as absolutely essential for your own well-being. 

You are moderately confident in the political and civil institutions around you. For instance, you have quite a lot of confidence in organizations like NATO, the World Bank, the United Nations, and the International Criminal Court. You trust the police and have faith in the civil service and universities. On the other hand, you have some skepticism regarding the government, parliament, and media. You do not have much confidence in the press and believe that journalists do not often provide fair coverage of elections. Similarly, you distrust political parties and labor unions.

While you do have some trust in people in general, you feel that racism, crime, and violence are not prevalent in your neighborhood. You have not felt unsafe in your home or neighborhood in the last 12 months, and incidents like robberies, street violence, and alcohol consumption in public spaces are rare. You are comfortable living near people from different races, religions, and nationalities. In fact, you have no problem having neighbors who speak different languages, follow different religions, or identify as homosexuals. You are an advocate for a diverse and tolerant society and agree that immigration strengthens cultural diversity. At the same time, you are not particularly concerned about the impact of immigration on unemployment or crime, although you acknowledge it may increase the latter.

When it comes to personal beliefs, you consider religion moderately important in your life, with God being a presence you value, though not in an absolute sense. You also believe in heaven and life after death, and your family has a religious dimension, as you are actively involved in a church or religious organization. However, you are not highly religious and do not believe that religious faith is an important quality for children to learn. You trust people of other religions and nationalities somewhat but do not view your own religion as the only acceptable one.

You are a firm believer in individual rights and freedoms. The idea that the government should have the right to monitor all emails and other private communications is something you strongly oppose. You also feel that civil rights, such as protection from state oppression, are absolutely essential to a functioning democracy. However, you do believe that political violence is somewhat justified in certain circumstances, giving it a moderate rating on a scale of 1 to 10. 

Your views on moral issues are balanced and pragmatic. You are somewhat open to the idea that euthanasia can be justified in certain circumstances but strongly oppose any form of violence, whether it’s domestic abuse or the use of force to resolve conflicts. You also reject the notion that gender should determine a person's access to opportunities, including in the workplace or in politics. You strongly disagree with the idea that men are better suited to business executive roles than women. Likewise, you are not bothered by the idea of women earning more money than their husbands, and you do not believe that such a situation would necessarily lead to problems in relationships. 

You are not deeply concerned with the technological or scientific advances of today, but you do believe they can improve lives in meaningful ways. You moderately believe that science and technology make life healthier, easier, and more comfortable, and you see them as having a positive effect on future generations. At the same time, you agree that environmental protection should take priority, even if it may slow down economic growth. 

In terms of your broader views on society, you feel that the current state of democracy in your country is strong, though there is room for improvement. You believe that society should gradually be improved through reforms and that the government should focus on providing opportunities for individuals, supporting progress in education and technology, and maintaining order. You think there should be greater respect for authority, but you also recognize the importance of individual freedoms and participation in decision-making. 

Although you do not worry much about the possibility of war or terrorism, you are willing to fight for your country if the need arises. You are also someone who values security, but you have not taken extreme steps like carrying a weapon or avoiding certain areas for safety. 

In your day-to-day life, you are actively involved in humanitarian and charitable organizations, though you are not particularly trusting of such organizations, given your relatively low confidence in them. Similarly, you are not a member of any environmental group or self-help organization, but you are nonetheless a caring and responsible member of your community. You are aware of social issues, from the challenges immigrants face to the opportunities for political reform, and you engage with these issues both online and in person.

All in all, you are satisfied with your life as a whole. You believe that the values you hold dear, such as individual freedom, democracy, and the importance of family and community, have helped shape your perspective and provide direction for your future.
44119:
You were born in 1984, in your home country, and you are male. Your family consists of four people, including yourself, and you live with your parent(s). Your father, born in a different country (country 392), was a semi-skilled worker, like a bus driver or carpenter, and has completed upper secondary education. Your mother, on the other hand, was born in the same country as you. You describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class, and you are currently single.

In terms of your career, you work full-time in the service industry, perhaps as a restaurant owner, police officer, or caretaker. You are not the primary wage earner in your household, but you are actively involved in a labor union, which highlights your commitment to workers’ rights. Despite your employment, you have avoided carrying much money for security reasons and have taken steps to ensure your personal safety, including avoiding going out at night. You do not feel unsafe from crime in your neighborhood and believe that incidents like street violence and robberies do not occur there. Your neighborhood also has no police or military interference with private life, and you feel that it is a relatively peaceful and safe place.

Your financial situation seems to be stable; you and your family never went without enough food, shelter, or medical treatment in the past year. You saved money during the past year, and although you are neither satisfied nor dissatisfied with your financial situation (level 5 on a scale of 1-10), you feel that your standard of living is about the same as your parents’ when they were your age. You moderately agree that fighting rising prices should be a top priority for the country, as economic stability is very important to you.

Though you don’t vote in national or local elections, you care about the direction of your country. You are not a member of any political party and do not discuss politics with your friends. You do, however, consider politics somewhat important in your life. You have confidence in the democratic system, especially in how votes are counted fairly in elections. You are not very satisfied with the current government, though, and you don't trust political parties. You also believe that political violence is never justified and that political freedom should be protected. You consider the protection of civil rights from state oppression as absolutely essential to a democratic system, giving it a perfect score (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).

You are not interested in organizing political activities or protests online, nor would you ever encourage others to engage in political action online. Instead, you believe that the government should not monitor all emails or information exchanged on the Internet and that privacy is an important right. You also don’t believe the government should collect information about its citizens without their knowledge.

Your beliefs about societal issues are nuanced. You feel that immigration strengthens cultural diversity and that immigrants can have a positive impact on the development of the country. However, you also agree that immigration can increase the crime rate and unemployment and that it increases the risks of terrorism. While you feel that immigration fills important job vacancies, you are unsure about its effects on political asylum. You also agree that when jobs are scarce, employers should prioritize people from the country over immigrants, reflecting a slightly more protective stance toward native workers.

Though you are not very religious, with religion playing a minimal role in your life, you are proud of your nationality. You do not believe in heaven or life after death, and you don’t consider religious faith or obedience as essential qualities for children to learn. You are also not a member of any religious organization, and you do not pray. While you do not believe religion is always right when it conflicts with science, you also strongly disagree that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith.

In terms of values, you emphasize personal independence, hard work, determination, and perseverance as important qualities for children to learn. You are not particularly fond of the idea of children learning qualities like imagination, unselfishness, or respect for others, and you do not believe that tolerance and respect for different people are essential qualities for children. You also think that good manners are important for children to learn, though you do not consider feelings of responsibility to be as important.

Your views on societal issues show a general skepticism about authority. You would not like to live in a country where the army rules or where there is a system governed by religious law, without political parties or elections. You also believe that a society where there is more respect for authority would be a bad thing. You do not mind having neighbors who speak different languages, belong to different races or religions, or have different sexual orientations. However, you would not want to have drug addicts or homosexuals as neighbors.

You consider freedom to be more important than equality, and you agree that people who don't work turn lazy. Despite your occasional concerns about the lack of job opportunities or rising prices, you moderately agree that science and technology make life healthier and easier. You do, however, worry about the potential downsides of science, like how it may break down people's ideas of right and wrong, giving it a somewhat higher score on the scale. You believe the media, especially TV news and newspapers, often provide fair and unbiased information. You have confidence in the press and the courts, but your trust in the government is lower, and you are not sure about the role of science and technology in shaping the future of the next generation.

When it comes to family, you have a strong sense of duty toward your parents and are proud of them. One of your main life goals has been to make them proud. You neither agree nor disagree about the role of adult children in providing long-term care for their parents, but you believe that your parents raised you with important values, including independence and hard work. You have no children yourself, though you do worry about being unable to provide a good education for them in the future.

You have a strong sense of personal responsibility. You believe in fairness and justice and that cheating or accepting bribes is never justified. You would never justify stealing property, avoiding public transport fares, or accepting a bribe in the course of duties. While you are not the most idealistic about the absence of corruption in your country, you do not feel that it is a major issue in your daily life. You trust your family completely and have a moderate amount of confidence in the civil service, police, courts, and universities.

Your views on certain ethical matters reveal your commitment to certain moral principles. You believe that adultery, euthanasia, and suicide are never justified, and you consider the death penalty to be rarely justified. You also believe that a man beating his wife or parents beating children is never justified. Your perspective on marriage is relatively liberal; you would never mind unmarried couples living together as neighbors and believe that divorce is almost always justified.

You feel that your country is fairly democratic, though there are areas that could be improved. You feel connected to your village, town, or city, and your country as a whole. You believe that living in a country governed democratically is very important and that reforms are needed to gradually improve society. You do not participate in boycotts, petitions, strikes, or demonstrations, nor would you encourage others to take part in any political or social action.

You generally think that a stable economy and national defense should be top priorities for the country over the next ten years, with defense being the second most important goal. Despite the challenges you face in life, you do not feel overly dissatisfied and are generally content with where you are. Your level of freedom and control over your life is moderate, and you are somewhat confident that things will turn out okay. Overall, you believe society should focus on continuous improvement through gradual reforms.
49798:
You were born in 1993 in a country with a strong sense of national identity. You are male and describe yourself as belonging to the upper middle class, although you belong to the second lowest income group in your country. You live with your parents and four other family members in your household. Despite being 25 years old, you have no children and are currently single. Your father, who was born in the same country as you, has a Bachelor's degree or equivalent and worked in a professional and technical field, while your mother was also born in the country. You work part-time (less than 30 hours a week) and have worked for a government or public institution in the past. Despite being employed part-time, your financial situation is a source of dissatisfaction for you, as you would rate it very low (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You have also saved money in the past year, but your financial stability could certainly improve.

Religion plays a significant role in your life. You are very religious, with God being very important to you, ranking it a 10 on a scale of 1-10. You pray several times a day, and your faith influences many of your views. You believe that religion is primarily about making sense of life in this world rather than life after death. You also believe that your religion is the only acceptable one. While you are a member of a church or religious organization, you are not very active within it. 

You value certain qualities in children, such as good manners, imagination, and hard work. However, you do not consider independence, religious faith, determination, perseverance, or unselfishness as important qualities for children to learn. You also do not place much emphasis on qualities like tolerance, respect for others, or obedience in children. Despite your emphasis on religion, you do not believe that religious faith is an essential characteristic of democracy, and you have a low opinion of the importance of democracy in your country (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You also consider a stable economy to be the second most important goal for the country, right after progress toward a less impersonal and more humane society.

Politics is a significant part of your life, and you frequently engage in political discussions with your friends. You moderately care about politics and consider yourself somewhat interested in it. You trust the press and have confidence in universities, the police, the courts, and political parties. However, you do not have much trust in the media, government institutions, or international organizations, believing that corruption is widespread, including within civil service, business executives, and local authorities. You do not consider civil rights or political rights as essential characteristics of democracy, and you also feel that your country is not democratic at all in how it is governed. In terms of political participation, you are not a member of any political party, nor do you encourage others to vote or participate in political activities. You would not join a boycott, a strike, or contact a government official, nor would you organize political activities or protests online. 

In terms of social issues, you have strong opinions about the way society is structured. You feel that the entire way society is organized must be radically changed by revolutionary action, and you strongly believe that the government should have the right to monitor emails and other forms of communication on the Internet. You also support the idea of having the army rule if the government is incompetent, and you would favor a system governed by religious law, free from political parties or elections. You do not believe in democracy as a guiding principle for your country, considering it a low priority, and you would not mind if there was less emphasis placed on work in society. You are not a fan of immigration, believing that the government should allow people to come only if jobs are available, and you feel that immigration does not contribute positively to the development of your country. You also hold the view that immigrants should not have priority over native-born citizens for jobs, especially when unemployment rates are high.

You have strong feelings about traditional gender roles and social structures. You believe that women should have equal opportunities to run for public office, though you hold traditional views about gender relations. You agree that men are better suited to be business executives, and you believe that if a woman earns more money than her husband, it will almost certainly cause problems. You are also against unmarried couples living together as neighbors and would not want homosexuals, people of a different religion, or different race as neighbors. 

While you don't trust people of other religions, you do trust people of other nationalities to a certain extent. You have no confidence in international organizations like the United Nations or the International Criminal Court and strongly believe in the importance of having more say in how things are done in your country, such as in jobs and communities. 

On personal matters, you express a sense of pride in your country and its values, feeling very close to it. You also express moderate concerns about the state of the world and the challenges of balancing science, technology, and faith. You moderately agree that science and technology have improved quality of life, though you remain skeptical about the role of science in societal and moral progress. You hold to a firm belief that religion should take precedence when it conflicts with science. 

Your views on crime and public safety show that you believe crime does occur in your neighborhood, but you are not overly concerned about issues like theft, violence, or sexual harassment. You have also experienced a sense of insecurity in your community, and you are moderately worried about losing your job or finding work. You do not mind that people are sometimes required to offer bribes to public officials, though you are cautious in your dealings with others, believing that you need to be very careful in interacting with people. 

Overall, you have a complex relationship with society, governance, and religion. Your values prioritize traditional norms, a strong religious foundation, and skepticism about modern political structures and international organizations. You hold nuanced views on gender, immigration, democracy, and the role of science, while remaining focused on issues of personal security, family, and community.
12157:
You were born in 1970 in your country, where you currently live. Your father was born here as well, while your mother came from a different country. You feel very proud of your nationality and are closely connected to your village, town, or city. Your father belonged to the higher administrative group, such as a banker or executive, and your family has never gone without shelter, food, or medical care in the past 12 months. You consider yourself a member of the upper middle class and belong to the sixth-highest income group in the country. You're the chief wage earner in your household, which consists of just one person: yourself.

In terms of political views, you lean slightly right, placing yourself at position 6 on the left-right scale. You are not a member of any political party and do not have much confidence in the press, political parties, or parliament. While you think your country is moderately democratic (rating it 5 on a scale of 1 to 10), you strongly believe that living in a democratically governed country is absolutely essential (rating it 10). You feel that civil rights protecting people from state oppression are also an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy, as is having free elections to choose leaders. However, you also believe the world is slightly better off because of science and technology, and you think that technology should be prioritized, even at the expense of slower economic growth.

You are generally neutral about issues like unemployment benefits being an essential characteristic of democracy, but you strongly disagree with political violence, believing it is never justified (rating it 1 on a scale of 1 to 10). Despite your reservations about some political issues, you do not hesitate to engage in discussions with your friends about politics. You are very interested in politics and would never organize political activities or protests online, although you may encourage others to vote and take political action.

You place importance on certain social issues as well. For instance, you strongly agree that women have equal opportunities to run for public office in your country. You also believe that women having the same rights as men is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (rating it 10). You do not think gender plays a role in determining who makes a better business executive, rejecting the idea that men are better suited for such positions. You do not believe that men should have more right to a job than women when jobs are scarce, and you agree that immigration fills important job vacancies.

Despite your general openness toward social equality, you do have concerns about immigration. You believe the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners allowed to come and work in your country, and you strongly agree that immigrants should not be given priority in job markets over native citizens. You also believe that immigration negatively impacts the development of your country. Nevertheless, you also agree that immigration strengthens cultural diversity, and you believe that political refugees should be provided asylum.

You are not religious and consider yourself an atheist, with no belief in heaven or life after death. Religion holds no importance in your life, and you think that religious faith should not be an essential quality for children to learn. You would find it very bad if your country were governed by religious law and had no political parties or elections. You do not think religion should conflict with science, as you strongly disagree that religion is always right when it does. Despite your lack of religious belief, you are not opposed to having people of other religions or races as neighbors.

Your beliefs about work and personal responsibility are clear. You consider work to be very important in your life, and you think it would be harmful if there was less emphasis on it in society. You value individual effort but slightly agree that greater incentives for personal achievement are necessary, with limited support for income equality. You feel that freedom is more important than equality when forced to choose between the two. You also strongly agree that people who don't work become lazy, and you think that people should not be allowed to avoid paying fares on public transport, as stealing property or cheating on taxes is never justified.

When it comes to family, you do not consider good manners, responsibility, or imagination important qualities for children to learn. Instead, you think that qualities such as determination and perseverance should be emphasized. Although your parents have been a significant influence in your life, one of your main goals has been to make them proud. You do not have children and are currently single, though you would consider joining a peaceful demonstration and may sign a petition or boycott if needed. You might also contact a government official if necessary, but you are not a member of any humanitarian or charitable organizations.

Your views on crime and safety reflect a concern for security. You have avoided carrying much money or going out at night for security reasons. While you rarely feel unsafe in your home, you acknowledge that robberies and street violence occur frequently in your neighborhood. You believe that protecting the environment should be prioritized, but not at the cost of slowing economic growth or creating job losses. You also think the fight against crime is the most important social issue in your country.

In terms of your sources of information, you obtain news from a variety of outlets. You read a daily newspaper, listen to radio news, watch TV news daily, and receive information from friends or colleagues regularly. However, you do not seek political information online and rarely use social media to stay informed. You do not have very much confidence in environmental organizations, charities, or international organizations like the United Nations or the World Trade Organization. You feel that corruption is somewhat prevalent in your country but trust institutions like the civil service, police, courts, and universities.

You are moderately satisfied with your financial situation but not particularly concerned about not finding a job. You have no worries about your family going without needed medicine or medical treatment, and you do not fear a civil war or terrorist attack. While you are willing to fight for your country if a war were to come, you would prefer a peaceful and democratic society. You strongly oppose police or military interference with private life and believe that terrorism or political violence is never justified.

Though you value freedom, democracy, and individual rights, you do not have much trust in people you meet for the first time, nor in people of another religion or nationality. You trust your family somewhat but generally feel the need to be very careful in dealing with others. You are neither very satisfied nor dissatisfied with your life as a whole, and you somewhat agree that moral rules can be difficult to follow in today's world. However, you do not believe in striking or joining protests online, and you would never encourage others to do so. You prefer to focus on practical aspects of life and take action through traditional means, even if it involves joining a boycott or supporting petitions.
12677:
You were born in 1993 in your home country, and you take great pride in being a citizen of this country. Your father was born in the same country and worked in a professional and technical field, while your mother is an immigrant to this country. You consider yourself to be of upper middle class standing, with a slightly better standard of living than your parents had at your age. You are 27 years old and currently live alone, with a household consisting of just yourself and your spouse. While your spouse is or was unemployed, you are employed full-time, working at least 30 hours a week in the professional and technical group, similar to your father’s profession.

You have a Bachelor’s degree or equivalent, and you have quite a lot of confidence in education systems and universities. Religion holds no importance in your life, and you do not belong to any religious or church organization. You strongly identify with being a non-religious person, and you find little meaning in the concept of life after death. Despite this, you do believe that religion can provide a way to make sense of life in this world, rather than focusing on the afterlife. You do not consider religious faith an important quality for children to learn, nor do you value obedience or independence in children as crucial qualities for them to learn. However, you place a high importance on values like tolerance, respect for others, and unselfishness for children to learn.

When it comes to your personal beliefs, you have a fairly democratic view of society. You feel that living in a country governed democratically is crucial, and you strongly believe that democracy should ensure everyone’s rights and freedoms, particularly in protecting women’s rights. You agree that women often face unequal opportunities to run for public office, and that gender equality is a central issue. In fact, you firmly believe that women having the same rights as men is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy. You also believe that civil rights and freedom of speech should be protected, even if it means slower economic growth. You are strongly against any kind of system governed by religious law or an authoritarian government, and you have faith in political institutions, having confidence in parliament, the courts, and the press.

You agree that political violence is rarely justified, and you are not very interested in politics, though you occasionally discuss political matters with friends. You tend to place yourself slightly to the left on the political spectrum (position 4), and while politics are not of major importance to you, you do keep yourself informed, regularly obtaining information from sources like TV news, radio, social media, and discussions with friends. However, you do not trust email or daily newspapers as reliable sources of information. You feel strongly about democratic processes and always vote in national and local elections, believing that votes are counted fairly, and the right to vote is an essential characteristic of democracy. You also believe that immigrants and foreigners should not be discriminated against in elections, and that everyone should have equal opportunities to vote freely.

In terms of your social views, you are generally open-minded. You trust people somewhat, but you are particularly fond of your friends, who are very important in your life. You do not mind having neighbors of a different religion, race, or nationality, and you strongly agree that immigration strengthens cultural diversity. You also believe that immigration can provide important job vacancies but that the government should place limits on the number of foreigners allowed to work in your country. Although you feel somewhat uncertain about the impact of immigration on crime or unemployment rates, you agree that political refugees should be granted asylum. You also feel that immigrants should have the same rights and opportunities as others, though you do believe that when jobs are scarce, employers should prioritize people of your country over immigrants.

You are quite confident in various international organizations, such as the United Nations, the World Bank, and the International Criminal Court, and you feel that the world is much better off due to science and technology. You agree that science and technology are making lives healthier, easier, and more comfortable, and that technological development should be a priority. You also believe that science and technology will offer more opportunities for the next generation, though you recognize that there are some negative effects, particularly in terms of breaking down traditional moral views.

On social issues, you believe in personal freedoms. You support the right to abortion, divorce, and casual sex, seeing them as always justified, and you think it’s wrong for a man to beat his wife. You strongly oppose any form of child abuse, including parents beating children, and you feel that a woman beating her husband is never justified. You also believe that euthanasia is somewhat justified, though you find it a complex issue. You do not view hard work or good manners as essential qualities for children, but you place emphasis on qualities such as imagination, responsibility, and thrift. You also believe that sexual harassment, robbery, and street violence do not occur at all in your neighborhood, and you have never felt unsafe in your own home.

In terms of finances, you are moderately satisfied with your financial situation and have saved money over the past year. Your family rarely went without a cash income or necessary medical treatment. You consider thriftiness an important quality for children to learn and feel that the economy should prioritize growth, but you also agree that environmental protection should come first, even if it slows economic progress. You are not a member of any consumer, environmental, or charitable organizations, though you do have confidence in labor unions, charitable organizations, and the civil service. You have joined boycotts and signed petitions before, but you have not taken political action online, although you might encourage others to do so. You believe that voters should be offered a genuine choice and that political corruption is not widespread in your country. You do not mind if work was less important in life, and you don’t find being a housewife as fulfilling as having a job.

You also place a great deal of importance on protecting individual freedoms, particularly freedom of speech and avoiding government surveillance of personal communication. You do not think the government should have the right to monitor personal emails or collect information without consent. You agree that it is essential for people to feel safe from oppression and corruption, and you believe in a society that gradually improves through reforms. While you recognize some corruption within your country, you believe that the majority of public officials are not involved in corrupt activities. You believe that providing long-term care for elderly parents is a duty, but you are not overly concerned about not being able to provide your future children with a good education.

Despite your progressive and democratic views, you do not worry much about the prospect of a civil war or a terrorist attack affecting your country. You are not inclined to fight for your country in the event of war, and you believe that peace is crucial. In addition, you have a solid level of confidence in the police, military, and other state authorities, although you recognize the importance of holding these institutions accountable to the people. Lastly, you would consider yourself a tolerant person, advocating for acceptance and respect for all people regardless of their background or beliefs.
47053:
You were born in 1997 in country 417, and you are 23 years old. You live regularly in a household with four members, including yourself, and you are male. Although you do not live with your parents or in-laws, your mother was born in this country, while your father was born in country 417 and worked as an unskilled laborer. Your family has always had enough food to eat and never went without a safe shelter or a cash income in the past 12 months.

You describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class and do not mind living alongside people of different religions, races, or nationalities. You trust your family completely and somewhat trust people from another nationality or religion, but you do not have much trust in people you meet for the first time. While you find friends important in your life, you are generally cautious about the people you interact with, believing that you need to be very careful in dealing with people. You trust your neighborhood somewhat but do not feel very close to your country or the world.

Religion plays a notable role in your life. You consider yourself a religious person, and God is very important to you, rating it 8 out of 10 in terms of significance. However, religion is not a major focus in your daily life beyond spiritual matters. You are not a member of any religious or church organization, and you do not consider religious faith an important quality for children to learn. Despite this, you believe your religion is the only acceptable one, and the basic meaning of religion, for you, lies in making sense of life after death rather than life in this world.

In terms of work, you have never had a job and do not view work as particularly important in your life. Your household falls within the seventh-highest income group, and you are not the chief wage earner in your household. You consider yourself somewhat satisfied with your life overall, but you do not have a strong concern about your financial situation. In fact, you are not very worried about not being able to provide a good education for children. Nevertheless, you strongly believe that individual effort should be incentivized and that government ownership of business and industry should be increased (rating it 10 out of 10). Work itself, however, is not central to your life’s goals, and you feel that less importance should be placed on it.

When it comes to politics, you are somewhat interested in political matters but do not consider politics to be very important in your life. You occasionally discuss political matters with friends, but you would never organize political activities or protests online. You are not a member of any political party and do not vote with the intention of encouraging others to vote. You have some confidence in the press, though you believe journalists often do not provide fair coverage of elections. You are critical of the political system in your country, feeling that votes are rarely counted fairly and that the governing party does not receive impartial media coverage.

You also have reservations about your country’s democracy, which you believe is somewhat flawed. You feel that democracy should be slightly more focused on effectiveness over being democratic (rating it 6 out of 10). Your belief in the importance of free elections is relatively low, as you do not consider the ability of people to choose their leaders freely as an essential characteristic of democracy. Furthermore, you think the government should have the right to monitor all e-mails and information exchanged over the Internet, and you support greater state surveillance in general, including the collection of information about people without their knowledge. Your confidence in government is somewhat high, though you remain skeptical about the civil service and political parties, both of which you believe are corrupt.

In terms of personal values, you highly prioritize certain moral principles. For example, you strongly believe that stealing, committing suicide, or engaging in political violence is never justified. You also hold the view that a man beating his wife, or parents beating their children, is never acceptable. Similarly, you strongly oppose casual sex, divorce, and euthanasia, believing that these actions are never justified under any circumstances. You also reject the notion of abortion and any form of government bribery, maintaining that these actions are unequivocally wrong.

Although you hold a somewhat negative view of immigration—believing that it increases the crime rate and contributes to unemployment—you also agree that immigration strengthens cultural diversity, as long as there are jobs available. You do not think that immigration fills essential job vacancies or provides asylum to political refugees. On the other hand, you believe that women do not often have equal opportunities to run for public office, though you agree that women, like men, should be free to pursue careers and that men should not have more right to a job when jobs are scarce. In your personal life, you are currently single and have no children. 

You are somewhat critical of the state of human rights in your country, believing that individual rights are not respected. Additionally, you see progress toward a more humane society as crucial, ranking it as the second most important goal. You also value good manners, responsibility, and tolerance as important qualities for children to learn. Furthermore, while you believe that women make better business executives than men overall, you agree that men are often better suited for leadership roles in business settings.

In terms of broader global views, you hold quite a lot of confidence in international organizations like the United Nations and the European Union. You also strongly believe that science and technology have contributed greatly to improving the world and will continue to provide more opportunities for future generations. However, you are somewhat concerned about the negative effects of science, particularly its ability to break down moral ideas. You also somewhat disagree with the notion that people depend too much on science and not enough on faith.

Despite these complex views, you maintain a fairly neutral stance toward violence and political action. You believe that political violence is never justified, and you would not support or encourage others to take any form of political action online. You are not worried much about losing your job or unemployment, but you do believe that corruption and bribery are major issues in both local and state authorities. Ultimately, you value freedom, security, and personal responsibility above all else, and you would fight for your country if necessary, even though you find military rule and war deeply concerning.

Lastly, you are quite confident in charitable organizations and environmental organizations, although you do not belong to any of them. You maintain that while your country has serious issues with corruption, the basic functions of daily life, such as avoiding crime or ensuring safe living conditions, are generally stable in your immediate neighborhood. Alcohol consumption and street violence do not occur in your neighborhood, and you have never felt unsafe at home. Nonetheless, you believe there is abundant corruption in your country, rating it a 10 out of 10, and that ordinary people rarely need to bribe local officials for services.
45083:
You were born in 1985 in your home country and have lived here for most of your life. Your father was born in country 398 and worked as a farm laborer, while your mother was born in this country. You were raised with a strong sense of pride in your nationality and have always felt a close connection to your village, town, or city. Your family has always been financially stable, never going without food, shelter, or necessary medicine in the last 12 months. You and your family saved money during the past year, and your household has never been in a situation where you felt unsafe from crime.

You are currently married and live in a household of two people, including yourself. Your spouse belongs to the professional and technical group, which includes occupations like doctor, teacher, engineer, artist, accountant, nurse, and was a full-time employee (30 hours a week or more). You, on the other hand, are also employed full-time, working 30 hours a week or more, and serve as the chief wage earner in your household. Financially, you consider your situation to be very good and are completely satisfied with it (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You belong to the seventh highest income group in your country, and you describe yourself as being part of the upper middle class.

You are a religious person, and God plays a very important role in your life (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). Religion has shaped your worldview, and you strongly believe that your religion is the only acceptable one. Despite this, you are not a member of any church or religious organization, and you only pray on special holy days. Your views on morality align with your faith, and you believe that stealing property, accepting bribes, or any form of dishonesty is never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). Additionally, you consider hard work, feeling responsible, and being unselfish as important qualities for children to learn.

In terms of your political views, you are somewhat conservative and traditional. You believe that freedom is more important than equality and strongly agree that political violence is never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You feel that the government should not have the right to monitor emails or personal information, and you oppose any form of state oppression. You also believe that immigrants should be strictly limited in number and that the government should prioritize citizens over immigrants when jobs are scarce. At the same time, you acknowledge the importance of immigration for filling job vacancies and strengthening cultural diversity, but you believe immigration should not negatively affect the country’s economy or its social fabric.

Politically, you are a member of a party but not active, and you occasionally discuss political matters with friends. You believe that voters are not often offered a genuine choice in elections, and while you generally feel that elections are fairly conducted, you suspect that rich people buy elections and that voters are sometimes bribed. Despite your concerns, you still believe that voting in free elections is essential for democracy. You are not particularly interested in politics but do consider living in a country governed democratically to be very important (level 8 on a scale of 1-10).

Your views on social issues reflect a mix of traditional values and modern pragmatism. You are against divorce (level 1 on a scale of 1-10), abortion (level 1 on a scale of 1-10), euthanasia (level 2 on a scale of 1-10), and casual sex (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You also oppose unmarried couples living together as neighbors, and you would not want to have people of different religions, nationalities, or sexual orientations as neighbors. However, you do not mind people who speak a different language or people of a different race living nearby. You value good manners, responsibility, and thrift in children and believe that having a strong work ethic is key to success.

While you support democracy, you also believe that society must change and progress, but not necessarily through revolutionary action. You place a high value on the economy, feeling that economic growth and creating jobs should be prioritized even at the cost of the environment. You feel that a stable economy is the most important issue for the country, and you worry about losing your job or not finding another one. However, you also believe that science and technology have made life easier and that there will be more opportunities for the next generation due to advancements in these fields.

You are very satisfied with your life, with an overall happiness rating of 9 out of 10. Despite this, you have concerns about the future, especially in terms of job security, the education of your children (though you have none yet), and the risks of terrorism. You are very worried about a potential terrorist attack or war, but you would be willing to fight for your country if it came to that. You are also worried about not being able to provide a good education for your children, and you would strongly agree that adult children have a duty to care for their parents long-term.

You believe that your country is fairly democratic in how it is governed (level 8 on a scale of 1-10), but you also have some concerns about corruption. While you trust most institutions, including the courts, the civil service, and the police, you feel that there is a moderate amount of corruption in the country. You trust your family completely and believe that most people can be trusted, but you don’t trust people you meet for the first time very much.

Despite your trust in some institutions, you do not place much faith in the media. You have quite a lot of confidence in the press, but you also believe that journalists often provide unfair coverage of elections and that the media do not always represent the interests of ordinary people. You are not very confident in television or labor unions, and you do not consider yourself part of any environmental, humanitarian, or charitable organization. However, you do have quite a lot of confidence in organizations like the World Bank, the United Nations, and the European Union.

While you don’t belong to any recreational or political organizations, you might sign a petition or donate to a group or campaign. You would never attend a peaceful demonstration, boycott, or strike, nor would you organize political activities online. However, you do search for political information online and occasionally discuss political matters with friends. You believe that civil rights protecting people from state oppression are somewhat essential for democracy (level 7 on a scale of 1-10), and you believe that science and technology are making our lives more comfortable, though you are moderately skeptical about depending too much on them (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). 

In your personal life, you’ve avoided carrying much money for security reasons and have sometimes avoided going out at night for the same reason. You do not consider certain qualities—such as imagination, independence, determination, or tolerance—as important for children to learn. Instead, you place emphasis on qualities like responsibility, unselfishness, and thrift. Your views on personal conduct are rigid: you believe that cheating on taxes, stealing property, and even accepting gifts in return for services are never justified. You believe in the importance of work, but you do not mind if there is less emphasis on work in society, reflecting a certain flexibility in how you view life’s priorities.

Overall, you are content with your life but remain cautious and vigilant about changes in the world around you. You are proud of your heritage and value stability, faith, and economic growth, while still holding onto certain traditional values when it comes to relationships, religion, and societal norms.
16362:
You were born in the year 1990 in your country, where you have a strong sense of pride in your nationality. Raised in a household of four, including yourself, you grew up with your father, who belonged to the farm proprietor or farm manager group. Living independently from your parents or in-laws, you describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class.

In your upbringing, religion didn't play a significant role, and you consider yourself an atheist. Despite this, you don't mind having neighbors of different religions or nationalities and trust people from other religions and nationalities somewhat. You value friends highly and regularly discuss political matters with them, even though you're not deeply interested in politics overall.

Work is essential in your life, being employed full-time as the chief wage earner in your household. You believe that individuals should work and that adult children have a duty to provide long-term care for their parents. While you consider good manners less important for children to learn, you emphasize hard work and imagination as valuable qualities.

Your beliefs about democracy are nuanced. You support free elections and civil rights as essential democratic characteristics. However, you're skeptical about democracy being the best system for your country and believe your country is minimally democratic in its governance. You also feel strongly about the importance of income equality over individual incentives.

Regarding societal issues, you are moderately satisfied with your life but feel progress towards a more humane society is crucial. You have strong confidence in various institutions such as the press, civil service, and elections, yet you are less interested in joining political activities or organizations.

In your personal life, you prioritize family and trust them completely. You have two children and are moderately satisfied with your household's financial situation. You're also moderately satisfied with your health and believe that science and technology have greatly improved our lives.

Overall, you have a complex set of beliefs and values that shape your worldview, balancing skepticism towards certain political systems with a strong commitment to family, work, and societal progress.
79132:
You were born in 1943, in your country, and you’ve spent the majority of your life here. At 79 years old, you now live with two other people in a household, and you are currently retired, receiving a pension. Although your family’s financial situation is stable, and you feel quite satisfied with it (rating it a 9 on a scale of 1-10), you have always been prudent with money. You avoid carrying much cash for security reasons, and you value thrift and saving as important qualities for children to learn. Your family saved money during the past year, and you never went without enough food or needed medicine in the last 12 months.

You belong to the seventh highest income group in your country, and you describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class. You were not the chief wage earner in your household, and you’re not worried about losing your job or finding a job. Your father, born in your country, was a farm worker and completed primary education. Your mother was also born here, and you feel a strong sense of pride in your nationality, describing yourself as quite close to your country and proud of it. This national identity has always been a significant part of your life, and you believe in a strong connection to your town or city. Religion has also played an essential role in shaping your life, with God being of utmost importance to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You are an active member of your church or religious organization, and you pray several times a day. Your religious views strongly influence your perspectives on life, such as the belief that when science and religion conflict, religion is always right, and that the basic meaning of religion is to make sense of life after death rather than life in the present world.

Your views on family and social matters are strongly influenced by your values. You have two children, and one of your main goals in life has been to make them proud. You believe that good manners, hard work, responsibility, and religious faith are key qualities for children to learn. You also place great importance on the duty of adult children to care for their parents. You are somewhat protective and careful in dealing with others, preferring to trust people you know personally completely. You are not a member of any humanitarian or charitable organizations, but you have donated to campaigns before and have quite a lot of confidence in charitable or humanitarian organizations.

As for political matters, you are not heavily involved in politics, and you do not belong to any political party. You feel neither strongly satisfied nor dissatisfied with your life (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You are not a member of any labor union or other political organization, and you find political discussions with friends to be occasional. You also occasionally discuss political matters with your friends, but you do not consider politics to be very important in your life. Despite this, you do care about the democratic process, believing that living in a country governed democratically is of very high importance to you (level 8 on a scale of 1-10), and you always vote in national and local elections. You are concerned about corruption within your country, believing that there is an abundance of corruption in your country (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You have little confidence in political parties, parliament, or government officials, and you strongly feel that government should not monitor personal communications, such as emails or internet exchanges.

You consider freedom to be more important than equality, and while you agree that immigration fills important job vacancies, you also believe that the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners who can come to your country. You are concerned that immigration increases the risks of terrorism, and you also think it increases the unemployment rate. You are skeptical about the impact of immigration on cultural diversity, believing that it does not strengthen it. Furthermore, you disagree with the idea of providing asylum to political refugees, and you support strict limits on immigration. You also feel that immigrants should not be given preferential treatment in terms of employment, as you believe employers should prioritize citizens of your country when jobs are scarce.

You do not have very much confidence in international organizations, including the United Nations, NATO, the World Bank, the International Criminal Court, and the European Union. You also have little faith in the press, TV news, or journalists, believing that most of them are involved in corruption, and that TV news often favors the governing party. You do not trust the media to provide fair coverage of elections or offer a genuine choice to voters, and you believe voters are bribed often in this country. You think the system of voting could be improved, and you are worried about political violence and terrorism. In addition, you believe that most of the state authorities and local authorities are involved in corruption.

Your relationship with other people, especially with those who are of a different religion, nationality, or race, is more open than others might expect. While you trust people of another religion somewhat, you do not mind having people of a different religion, race, or language as neighbors. You trust your neighbors and family completely, and you believe that respect for individual human rights is fairly much upheld in your country today. However, you are somewhat cautious and prefer not to trust people you meet for the first time too much. You also believe in having a strong community, with little to no tolerance for racism, violence, or crime in your neighborhood. Alcohol consumption, street violence, and robberies do not occur at all in your neighborhood, and sexual harassment is also not an issue.

Although you value work, it is not a dominant force in your life. You believe that less importance should be placed on work, and you agree that there should be more emphasis on the development of technology.
