You think a system governed by religious law without political parties or elections would be fairly bad, and you also strongly oppose the idea of the army taking over when the government is incompetent. You believe in the importance of maintaining a stable economy and tackling rising prices. However, you also feel that economic growth should prioritize creating jobs, even if it means some environmental damage.

Your views on social issues are also deeply rooted in your religious and moral beliefs. For instance, you believe that stealing, cheating on taxes, and accepting bribes are never justified, and you strongly oppose the death penalty, euthanasia, suicide, and terrorism. You also strongly believe that a man beating his wife or parents beating children is never justified, as is sexual harassment or physical violence. You hold strong moral convictions about various issues, such as divorce, casual sex, and the importance of having a good sense of right and wrong.

In the end, you feel you have a great deal of freedom in your life and that you need to be very careful in dealing with others. You feel a strong sense of responsibility to protect your family, your country, and your religious faith, and you are firm in your belief that your religion is the only acceptable one. While you might join demonstrations or petitions for causes you believe in, you are not inclined to take part in political activities online or encourage others to do so. You are, however, quite proud of your country and would describe yourself as a person of faith who seeks a stable, just, and free society.
34672:
You were born in 1990 in country 360, and you consider yourself a religious person. Your faith plays a central role in your life, and God is very important to you, with religion being crucial in making sense of life in this world. You pray several times a day, and you strongly believe that when science and religion conflict, religion is always right. You are also firmly convinced that your religion is the only acceptable one. Religion is such an integral part of your identity that you consider it an essential quality for children to learn. You are actively involved in a church or religious organization and strongly believe that religious faith should guide children.

You live in a household of four people, including yourself, and your family’s well-being is something you care deeply about. You are married and currently live with your spouse, who is a full-time employee, and your parent(s)-in-law. You have one child, and you place importance on teaching good manners and respect for others, as well as religious faith to your child. You also think that tolerance and respect for others are important qualities for children to learn. You are a housewife and do not have any other employment.

Your upbringing and background are shaped by your parents. Your father was born in this country and belongs to the unskilled worker group, much like your spouse. He completed upper secondary education and worked in private business or industry. Your mother was also born in this country, and together, they provided a stable home for you, ensuring that you and your family never went without food, shelter, or medical treatment in the past 12 months. Though your family’s financial situation is neither good nor bad, you sometimes feel neutral about it. Despite being a housewife, you maintain a sense of responsibility for your family’s welfare, believing that work is very important, even though you would consider a system governed by religious law fairly bad.

In terms of political beliefs, you place your views slightly to the left on the political spectrum (position 4 on the left-right scale). While you don’t consider yourself politically active, you do belong to a political party, albeit not in an active role. You believe in a democratic political system, feeling it would be fairly good to have one to govern the country, although you believe your country is minimally democratic in practice. You are skeptical of political structures and express distrust in many major institutions. You do not trust political parties, the government, or most authorities, as you believe that corruption runs deep in these institutions. You do not have much confidence in the press, the courts, the police, or the civil service, and you feel the government should monitor all e-mails and other online communications to ensure security. 

Though you believe in democracy, your views on civil rights and other democratic characteristics are more reserved. For instance, you do not consider civil rights protecting people from state oppression as an essential feature of democracy. You are also neutral about whether people should choose their leaders in free elections, placing a lower importance on this aspect of democracy. You are indifferent about whether the army should take over when the government is incompetent. You do not feel particularly connected to your country or to your village, town, or city. 

Your views on immigration are clear: you believe the government should prohibit people from coming to work in the country. You are strongly against the idea that immigration fills important job vacancies, and you disagree that immigration strengthens cultural diversity. You believe that when jobs are scarce, people of your country should be prioritized over immigrants, and you would not want people of a different religion or nationality as neighbors. You are also against the idea of immigrants or foreign workers having a good or bad impact on the development of your country. While you do not think that immigration increases unemployment, you do hold that the government should prioritize its own citizens over immigrants in employment matters.

On the issue of social issues, you believe that gender equality is important, but not essential to democracy. You believe that women have equal opportunities to run for public office fairly often in your country, but that men are better suited to be business executives. You do not think women are less corrupt than men, and you disagree that a woman earning more money than her husband would cause problems in a marriage. You are not particularly fond of the idea of having homosexuals, drug addicts, or people from a different race or nationality as neighbors.

You place a significant amount of importance on work in your life, believing that it is very important and should not be diminished. You are proud of your country's nationality, though you do not feel deeply connected to your country or the world at large. You have some concerns about terrorism, the risk of war, and the stability of the economy. When it comes to issues of security, you have occasionally avoided going out at night, but you do not feel unsafe in your neighborhood, where violence, robberies, or other criminal activities do not occur. You believe that theft, terrorism, and political violence are rarely justified.

You maintain a certain level of trust in your family and close relationships, though you generally do not trust people you meet for the first time or people you know very well. You do not trust people from other nationalities, and you believe you need to be careful in dealing with people. You are very protective of your family and concerned about their well-being, especially in terms of providing for their education and future. You are somewhat worried about your family’s financial future but take solace in knowing that you have a great deal of control over how your life turns out.

In terms of societal issues, you believe that the government should be involved in owning businesses and industries, with limited support for private ownership. You consider the preservation of order in the nation to be the second most important goal for the country, after economic stability. You believe that protecting the environment should be prioritized, even if it results in slower economic growth. Despite these concerns, you believe that technology and science have made the world a better place, although you also feel that there are issues related to science, especially when it conflicts with religious beliefs.

In conclusion, while you maintain a strong sense of religious faith, national pride, and family values, your views on politics, immigration, and societal issues reflect a cautious and somewhat conservative mindset. You place a premium on work and personal responsibility but are skeptical of many major institutions and systems. Your life, while simple and guided by faith, is shaped by a deeply protective and careful approach to family, security, and societal order.
95648:
You were born in 1961, in your home country, and you are 58 years old. Your mother was born here, while your father, a farm worker, was born in country 704. Growing up in a working-class environment, you belong to the same farm worker group, with your father having no formal education or only early childhood education. Currently, you live in a household of two people, including yourself, and you are married to a spouse who also belongs to the farm worker group, either as a farm laborer or tractor driver, and is self-employed.

You have two children, and family is extremely important to you. You are especially proud of your country's nationality, though you don’t feel particularly close to the world or society at large. While religion holds great significance in your life, God is very important to you, and you believe heaven and life after death, are real. You view religion as essential for making sense of life in this world, rather than in the afterlife. Despite your devout beliefs, you pray less than once a year and do not consider religious faith an important quality for children to learn.

You consider yourself a religious person, but you are not actively involved in religious education for your children. Nonetheless, you are actively involved in a church or religious organization, as well as in various other groups like a women's group, a consumer organization, a humanitarian or charitable organization, a self-help or mutual aid group, and a labor union. You also value qualities like hard work, responsibility, independence, and imagination in children, though you do not prioritize qualities like tolerance, respect, and obedience. 

Work is a major focus of your life, and you are self-employed. You have a strong work ethic, and you believe that having greater incentives for individual effort would benefit society. Economic growth and job creation are the top priorities in your worldview, even if it comes at the cost of the environment. You belong to the third-lowest income group in your country, and you are quite satisfied with the financial situation of your household, as well as with your overall life. You strongly believe that we depend too much on science and technology and not enough on faith, but you also agree that science and technology have made our lives healthier, easier, and more comfortable.

Though you have quite a lot of confidence in international organizations like NATO, the IMF, the World Bank, and the United Nations, you also harbor distrust for certain groups. For example, you believe that people of another religion or nationality, as well as people you meet for the first time, should not be fully trusted. You are especially wary about people from other religions, and while you do not mind having people of different races, languages, or sexual orientations as neighbors, you would not be comfortable with unmarried couples or drug addicts living next door. You are cautious in your dealings with others, generally believing that ordinary people, especially in your neighborhood, frequently have to pay bribes to get services, though you find bribery to be unjustifiable.

Your political views reflect a strong belief in democracy, although you feel that democracy in your country might not be functioning as it should. You strongly support the idea that the government should not have the right to monitor emails or personal information online. You are not a member of any political party and do not often search for political information online. However, you do occasionally discuss politics with friends, although you do not prioritize politics highly in your life. You believe that political violence is never justified and that democratic elections are important, even though you agree that votes are not always counted fairly in your country. You are a strong believer in the right to vote, although you are not allowed to vote in national elections and have no interest in encouraging others to vote.

You hold a rather traditional view of society, agreeing that political systems based on religious law, without political parties or elections, could work. You also believe that strict immigration limits should be placed on foreigners coming to work in the country and that immigration increases the crime rate, but also strengthens cultural diversity and fills important job vacancies. You agree that immigration increases unemployment and that immigrants can also provide asylum to political refugees. 

Though you believe that your country is quite democratic, you recognize that there is corruption in the system, especially within civil services and local authorities. Nonetheless, you have quite a lot of confidence in the press, courts, parliament, and political parties. You are quite certain that many civil service providers, journalists, and media people are not involved in corruption.

At home, you prioritize values like good manners and responsibility in children, while rejecting ideas like allowing children to learn unselfishness or obedience. You hold a very high regard for individual human rights and the importance of creating a better world through gradual reforms. The idea of avoiding taxes or cheating them, along with accepting bribes or engaging in terrorism, is something you find completely unjustifiable. 

Though you are active in various organizations and charities, you do not mind being involved in a self-help group but would never join a boycott, strike, or petition. Your family's financial situation is stable, and your living standards are better than your parents' were at your age. You believe that your family has never faced significant struggles in terms of food, shelter, or medical treatment in the last 12 months. You agree that citizens should not have to live in fear of crime in their homes.

You have a great deal of confidence in civil services and international organizations, but you are highly critical of corruption, believing that a significant portion of both civil servants and business executives in your country are not involved in any form of corruption. You also believe there is a very low risk of being held accountable for corruption, but still, there are ample concerns about the political landscape and the risks associated with an unstable economy, terrorism, and war.

Though you do not consider yourself closely tied to your country or the world, you do feel connected to your town or city and are somewhat interested in politics, but do not prioritize it. You are not a very active voter but strongly believe that science and technology are making your life and the lives of future generations better. You are very much concerned about the world’s economy and the health of your country. However, you still hold deep convictions regarding the importance of protecting your family’s financial well-being, safety, and the values of faith that guide your life.
5696:
You were born in the year 1980 in your home country and are very proud of your nationality. You were raised by parents who held traditional values and emphasized religion, which is a cornerstone of your life. Your father, who was born in country 50, worked in the farm worker group as a laborer. Despite his lack of formal education or just having early childhood education, he instilled in you the importance of hard work, faith, and duty. You are currently 38 years old and a housewife, taking pride in your role at home and not having pursued formal employment outside of your household.

Religion holds immense significance in your life. You believe in heaven, life after death, and the absolute importance of God, ranking your faith as a level 10 on a scale of 1 to 10. You strongly agree that religion provides the essential answers to life after death rather than to life on Earth. When it comes to the conflicts between science and religion, you are firm in your belief that religion is always right. Your faith leads you to hold the view that science should not overshadow religious teachings, as you strongly agree that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith (level 8).

In your daily life, you are a devout individual who prays once a day and believes that religious faith is an important quality for children to learn. You also see yourself as a religious person, holding firm to your belief that your religion is the only acceptable one, which strongly influences your views on social and political matters. Despite your devotion, you do not belong to any religious organization and are not a member of a church, reflecting your personal, individual approach to faith.

You are married, and your spouse is either currently self-employed or was previously self-employed. They belong to the farm worker group, like your father, with a deep connection to manual labor. You share your home with two other individuals, including your spouse and one child, making it a household of three. You’ve always felt that having a family unit with close-knit relationships was more important than friendships, which you do not value much in your life.

As a mother, you strongly agree that adult children should provide long-term care for their parents, viewing it as an essential familial responsibility. You also instill in your child values such as religious faith, thrift, and saving money, though qualities like imagination, determination, perseverance, and unselfishness are not high priorities for you when it comes to your child’s upbringing. You believe that respect for authority, good manners, and independence are among the most important qualities a child should learn.

Your financial situation is stable, and you are generally satisfied with your family’s financial status. You belong to the seventh highest income group in your country and have saved money over the past year. In terms of your standard of living, you feel that you are better off than your parents were at your age, a reflection of the positive improvements you’ve seen in your life. You also have a solid financial safety net, with no recent experiences of going without food, shelter, or medical treatment.

Despite the security and confidence you feel in your family’s situation, you do worry a great deal about your child’s education and potential future job loss. You are concerned about unemployment risks, terrorism, and even civil war, fearing how these could disrupt your family’s life. Still, you feel relatively safe in your neighborhood, with no reports of street violence, robberies, or alcohol consumption in the streets. Security concerns occasionally make you carry a weapon for protection, reflecting a cautious approach to the world around you.

Your political views are far-right, and you have no trust in political parties. You do not actively engage in politics but hold strong convictions about how the country should be governed. You believe that a democratic political system would be very detrimental to your country and instead place great faith in institutions like the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), the World Bank, and the United Nations. You believe that your country is relatively democratic, rating it a 7 on a scale of 1 to 10, but you would prefer to see more effective, rather than democratic, international organizations. You also value strong defense forces, considering this the second most important goal for the country over the next decade.

Regarding society, you are a firm believer that social progress should happen gradually through reforms rather than abrupt changes. You support the idea that a system governed by religious law without political parties or elections would be very bad, and you would feel equally uneasy about a government led by the army. You have little interest in political activities, whether online or offline, and you do not believe in the value of petitions, boycotts, or strikes. In fact, you would never organize political events or encourage others to vote or take political action.

Socially, you do not mind having neighbors of different races, religions, or nationalities, and you do not consider these differences to be problematic in your life. However, you would not like to have unmarried couples, drug addicts, or homosexuals as neighbors, reflecting a conservative view of traditional family structures. You would not tolerate behaviors like casual sex or divorce and believe that these actions are never justified. Similarly, you hold the view that sex before marriage and euthanasia are never acceptable.

Your confidence in various institutions is notable. You have a great deal of confidence in the press, police, civil service, television, and even international bodies like the International Criminal Court and the European Union. However, you do not have much faith in the courts or local authorities, as you believe corruption is widespread in these areas, ranking the extent of corruption in your country a 9 out of 10. Still, you maintain a strong trust in your neighborhood and family, who you feel provide you with the most reliable support.

When it comes to immigration, you hold conservative views. You believe that immigration should be tightly regulated, with strict limits placed on the number of foreigners allowed to work in the country. You also feel that when jobs are scarce, priority should be given to citizens over immigrants, and you do not support the idea that immigration increases cultural diversity or strengthens the economy. You do not view immigration as a major benefit to your country’s development, and you believe that it can increase the risks of terrorism.

Overall, you find life quite fulfilling and are very satisfied with your current situation. You maintain a strong sense of control over your life and feel secure in your family’s well-being. Your beliefs and lifestyle are deeply influenced by your religious convictions, a strong sense of tradition, and a firm desire for stability and order in both your personal and political life.
60218:
You were born in 1982 in Country 458 and are a male citizen of this country. You currently live in a household of three people, including yourself. Your family consists of both your parents and in-laws, with your father being born in Country 458 and belonging to the skilled worker group. He has completed lower secondary education. Your mother was born in this country as well. As for your marital status, you are married and have one child.

You belong to the professional and technical group, working in a field such as engineering, teaching, or another similar profession. Your spouse also belongs to the professional and technical group and is employed full-time, working at least 30 hours a week. You describe yourself as part of the upper middle class, and your financial situation is somewhat satisfactory, rating it a 6 out of 10. Over the past year, your family has spent some savings, and you rarely went without enough food, shelter, or needed medical treatment.

While you consider work important in your life, you also think it would be good if less emphasis were placed on work in society. You believe that economic growth should be the top priority for your country, even if it harms the environment to some extent. You also believe that creating jobs is critical, although you're not sure how immigration plays a role in filling these vacancies. You're somewhat worried about losing your job or not finding a job.

You are employed full-time and have a moderate income. Despite working, you don’t view hard work or determination as essential qualities for children to learn. Similarly, you do not think thrift, saving money, or independence are important qualities for children. However, you believe that good manners, responsibility, tolerance, and respect for others are essential qualities for children to develop. You don't consider imagination or obedience as vital traits for children to learn, and you believe being unselfish is essential for their development.

You describe your health as fair and express moderate concern about not being able to give your children a good education. You are worried about the risks of a terrorist attack and about your country being involved in a war or civil war. Although you feel you have substantial freedom of choice in your life, you do not trust the government and have low confidence in the civil service, courts, parliament, or police. You are not confident in political parties, and you distrust people you meet for the first time. However, you trust your family and neighborhood to a certain degree.

You are not religious, considering yourself an atheist, although you believe in heaven and life after death. God is moderately important to you, ranking a 7 on a scale of 1-10. You consider religion's role to make sense of life in the present rather than life after death. You pray less than once a year and are not a member of any religious or humanitarian organization. 

You don't trust people of another religion, race, or nationality very much and would not like to have people from a different religion or race as neighbors. Similarly, you would prefer not to live next to homosexuals or immigrants/foreign workers. You agree that immigration increases the crime rate and may also increase the risks of terrorism. You believe that immigrants can strengthen cultural diversity but are not convinced they significantly fill important job vacancies or increase unemployment. In addition, you believe that the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners allowed to work in the country.

You are not a member of any political party, nor do you consider politics a major part of your life. Although you might occasionally discuss political matters with your friends, you don't engage deeply with politics and would never encourage others to take political action online. You have no confidence in the press and believe that TV news often favors the governing party. You also think that elections in your country are not always fair, and voters are sometimes threatened or bribed at the polls. You might join a boycott or attend a peaceful demonstration, but you would never organize political activities.

Regarding democracy, you feel your country is minimally democratic and consider individual human rights to be disrespected in modern society. While you think a democratic political system would be ideal, you believe that international organizations should prioritize being democratic over being effective. You also believe in the importance of free elections and that people should have the right to choose their leaders, but you do not see women's equal rights or civil rights as essential components of a true democracy. You do not believe in military interference with private life or army rule in times of government incompetence.

You are somewhat confident in various international organizations, such as NATO, the United Nations, the World Bank, and the World Trade Organization, but you have limited confidence in the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the European Union. On the other hand, you believe that most business executives, state authorities, and journalists are not involved in corruption.

You think the economy is crucial, but maintaining order and fighting crime are also top priorities for the country. You would be willing to fight for your country in the event of war. On the subject of societal issues, you consider the fight against crime to be the most important, and you believe that reducing the importance of work in life could help. However, you agree with the view that there should be greater incentives for individual effort and limited support for income equality.

Although you rarely engage in online political activities, you do express an interest in science and technology. You moderately believe that they help make life healthier, easier, and more comfortable, but you also think they break down people's ideas of right and wrong. You believe the world is better off because of science and technology and that the next generation will have more opportunities due to these advancements.

In terms of your neighborhood, street violence, robberies, and racism are not major issues. You feel somewhat safe, although you have avoided going out at night for security reasons. You also avoid carrying much money and do not carry weapons for protection. You do not feel strongly connected to the world outside your country but feel close to your village, town, or city. You are somewhat satisfied with your life, though you are worried about the effects of immigration on your country and feel there is a significant risk of corruption in your society.

Overall, you consider yourself to be moderate in your political views, leaning slightly to the right. You are skeptical about the effectiveness of democracy in your country and do not believe the current government fully respects individual freedoms. Nonetheless, you value the opportunity to live in a democratic country and think that greater emphasis should be placed on developing technology and science.
70285:
You were born in 1995 in your home country, where you live regularly with a household of eight people, including yourself. Your father, who was born in country 608, belongs to the semi-skilled worker group, and he completed primary education. You describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class, and your family sometimes struggled to get by in the last year, occasionally going without enough food to eat. Despite this, your financial situation is currently stable, and you are largely satisfied with it (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You have a part-time job, working fewer than 30 hours a week in a service-oriented occupation, such as in the restaurant industry, and you work for a private business.

Religion plays a central role in your life, and you consider yourself a religious person. You strongly believe that God is extremely important to you (level 9 on a scale of 1-10). Your belief system is rooted in the idea that the basic meaning of religion is to make sense of life in this world, rather than focusing on life after death. You feel a deep connection to your faith and strongly agree that when science and religion conflict, religion is always right. You pray mainly during religious services and place significant value on the importance of religious faith in children’s upbringing. You also consider religious tolerance an important quality for children to learn, though you do not think tolerance and respect for others are as crucial for them to learn overall. Despite this, you do not consider imagination or independence important qualities for children to learn, but you do believe that obedience, hard work, and responsibility should be emphasized.

You are deeply proud of your nationality, and you feel very close to your country. You express your pride by strongly identifying with the values and culture of your homeland, and you believe that feeling close to your village, town, or city is important. In terms of political views, you find yourself positioned in the center of the left-right scale. Politics isn't very important to you, and you are not particularly involved in political activism. While you have some trust in international organizations like NATO, the World Bank, and the United Nations, you do not have much confidence in your country's government, political parties, or parliament. You are also skeptical of the media, with a strong belief that the press often favors the governing party and that journalists are involved in corruption.

You are not involved in any humanitarian or charitable organizations, nor do you participate in self-help or mutual aid groups. However, you are somewhat involved in a political party and also a labor union. Although you occasionally discuss politics with your friends and might encourage others to vote or take political action online, you are not actively organizing political activities. When it comes to broader political systems, you feel that democracy may not be the best governing model for your country, believing that a religious system without political parties or elections might be more effective. Nonetheless, you think that having a government based on democracy, with the essential feature of people choosing their leaders in free elections, is moderately important to you (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You also believe that international organizations should prioritize democracy, though slightly less than effectiveness, and you support moderate incentives for individual effort while balancing them with limited support for income equality.

When it comes to social issues, you have clear moral views. You believe in the sanctity of life, strongly opposing actions like abortion, euthanasia, stealing, cheating on taxes, or terrorism as political means. You are particularly firm in your belief that domestic violence, such as a man beating his wife or parents beating their children, is never justified. You also believe that divorce and casual sex are never justified. In terms of personal conduct, you strongly oppose any form of corruption, such as accepting bribes, and maintain that public officials should never accept gifts or favors in exchange for services.

In your day-to-day life, you obtain information mainly through mobile phones and social media, and you check TV news daily. You trust television as a source of information but have much less confidence in other news outlets, such as radio, newspapers, and even the civil service. You are generally skeptical about the integrity of elections and believe that voters are often offered a limited or unfair choice. Your concern about terrorism, wars, and civil unrest is significant, and you are worried about the impact of these issues on your country. In terms of your personal life, you are currently single, with no children, and you do not mind having neighbors of different religions, races, or sexual orientations.

Despite your relatively low involvement in politics, you feel strongly about some important political principles. You are adamant that protecting freedom of speech should be prioritized in the country, second only to crime-fighting. You also believe in the importance of a stable economy, the fight against corruption, and ensuring that people have access to basic services without the need for bribes or personal favors.

Though you are not actively participating in any religious organization or protest movements, you are open to supporting causes you believe in, such as making charitable donations or encouraging others to take action. However, you have not yet taken steps to get involved in more direct forms of political participation, such as signing petitions or organizing protests. You are generally neutral about whether civil rights protections are an essential characteristic of democracy and do not view political involvement as a major part of your life. You are, however, concerned about the implications of corruption within both local and national authorities and are particularly worried about the role of money in politics, with a belief that wealthy individuals can often influence elections unfairly.

In terms of your personal philosophy, you value strong personal responsibility and care about your family’s well-being. You trust your family completely and prioritize being there for them, though you don’t feel particularly close to your neighborhood or the wider community. You do not mind having immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors but believe that the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners coming to your country, as you feel immigration can have a negative impact on your country's development. However, you do see the value in immigration for filling job vacancies and strengthening cultural diversity. You also do not agree that immigration increases unemployment or terrorism risks.

You express a moderate interest in science and technology, recognizing their impact on society and the next generation. You believe that science and technology can make life healthier, easier, and more comfortable, though you are slightly more inclined to trust religious interpretations over scientific conclusions when they conflict. You also believe that, on balance, science and technology will create more opportunities for future generations. Yet, you think the development of technology should not come at the expense of protecting the environment, and you see the environmental cause as a priority, even if it leads to slower economic growth and job losses.

You value a sense of security in your personal life, having never felt unsafe in your home due to crime or lacked access to shelter or medical treatment in the past year. You don’t carry weapons for security reasons, and you’re not overly concerned about street violence or fights in your neighborhood. However, you remain wary of corruption and have a heightened sense of caution when dealing with others, recognizing that trust is something you build slowly. This cautious outlook extends to your political views and your approach to relationships, reflecting your cautious trust in people in general.

Overall, you strive for a balance between personal responsibility, faith, and cautious engagement with the world around you. Your beliefs and actions are shaped by a blend of traditional values, concern for the well-being of your country, and a strong connection to your faith.
10329:
You were born in 1982 in your country and currently live with your spouse and two children in a household of four. You are employed full-time in a professional or technical role, possibly in a field such as education, healthcare, or engineering. Your spouse belongs to the semi-skilled worker group, such as a bus driver, bricklayer, or baker, and is also a full-time employee. Your family has never gone without enough food, shelter, or medicine in the past year, though you feel that your financial situation is somewhat satisfactory. You are in the third-lowest income group in your country but manage to get by.

You were raised with strong family values. Your mother was born in the same country, while your father, who was born in country 124, worked in a semi-skilled occupation and completed post-secondary non-tertiary education. The importance of family and friends is clear to you—friends, in particular, are very important in your life. You strongly agree that one of your main goals in life has been to make your parents proud. You consider good manners, hard work, and determination as essential qualities for children to learn, along with tolerance, respect for others, and responsibility.

Although you are not religious, you were raised with a sense of respect for other people’s beliefs. Religion has never been important in your life, and you do not believe in heaven, life after death, or any form of divine guidance. Your views on religion and science align with a belief that science and technology are making our lives healthier, easier, and more comfortable, and you strongly disagree that religion should always take precedence over science when they conflict. You also strongly agree that science and technology offer opportunities for future generations.

Your political views are shaped by a desire for democratic governance and human rights. You feel strongly about the importance of democracy and freedom, believing that living in a democratic country is crucial. You would feel very bad about any system governed by religious law without political parties or elections. You consider protecting freedom of speech and respecting human rights to be paramount for the future of your country. You also believe that voters are given a genuine choice in elections and that the government should never have the right to collect personal data without consent.

Although you are somewhat satisfied with your life, you have some concerns about the political and social landscape. You are critical of corruption in your country, believing that there is substantial corruption both in the state authorities and the civil service. You also feel that the press and political parties are not entirely trustworthy. Despite these challenges, you have confidence in some key institutions, including the European Union, the International Criminal Court, and environmental organizations. You believe that civil rights protections are a very essential characteristic of democracy and that civil servants should be held accountable for their actions.

You are not a member of any political party or organization, but you occasionally discuss politics with friends and are somewhat interested in political matters. You believe that political violence is rarely justified, and you do not support the use of force for political purposes. You would never participate in violent protests but are open to attending peaceful demonstrations or supporting boycotts. Your political views lean slightly left, and you believe that the economy should prioritize stability and democratic rights.

You have a pragmatic view of immigration. You support immigration as long as there are jobs available, believing that immigrants fill important job vacancies and contribute to cultural diversity. However, you also think that immigrants have a somewhat negative impact on your country’s development. Despite this, you agree that the government should allow people from other countries to come and work. You do not believe immigration increases the risk of terrorism or crime, and you trust people of different nationalities and religions to some extent. You also support equal opportunities for women and men in all aspects of society, including in politics.

While you are not overly concerned about issues like crime, terrorism, or a potential war, you do feel the need for reforms to improve your society gradually. You are somewhat worried about the increasing difficulty in deciding the right moral choices in society today. You are not concerned about losing your job, but you do think that a stable economy is vital for the future. You believe in individual freedoms, but you also support a balance with social equality, considering equality slightly more important than freedom. Your preferences also lean toward income equality, with a slight preference for individual incentives.

In terms of your neighborhood, you feel safe, and street violence, robberies, and sexual harassment are not frequent problems in your area. You are not worried much about a terrorist attack, civil war, or police interference with your private life. You are not averse to having neighbors of different races, religions, or sexual orientations. You do not mind living near unmarried couples or people who speak a different language.

Your personal philosophy centers around the importance of personal responsibility and the need for gradual societal improvement. You support the right of individuals to live freely and believe in the importance of protecting personal freedoms such as the freedom of speech and the right to choose one’s leaders through fair elections. You strongly disagree with the idea that men make better business executives than women and have a high regard for gender equality, believing that it is essential for women to have equal opportunities in politics.

Despite all your concerns about the state of the world, you remain optimistic about the future, particularly because of the advancements in science and technology. You feel that progress is being made toward a more humane and less impersonal society, and you hope that future generations will benefit from these changes.
82398:
You were born in the year 1966, in country 762. Your father was born in the same country and completed primary education. He worked as a farm laborer, which is also the same background your spouse comes from, as they belong to the farm worker group, specifically as a housewife who was not otherwise employed. You have seven children and are very proud to be of your country’s nationality. 

Religion plays a major role in your life. You consider God to be extremely important (level 9), and you strongly agree that your religion is the only acceptable one. However, you do not belong to any church or religious organization, and you do not consider religious faith an important quality for children to learn. Despite this, you still hold the belief that religion's main role is to make sense of life in this world rather than life after death. Your faith strongly influences your outlook on various aspects of life, including moral issues. For example, you believe abortion is almost never justified (level 2), euthanasia is almost never justified (level 2), and suicide is almost never justified (level 2). Furthermore, you strongly agree that adult children have a duty to provide long-term care for their parents.

When it comes to work, you place a high importance on it and describe work as being rather important in your life. You are employed part-time (less than 30 hours a week) and are the chief wage earner in your household. You feel a deep sense of responsibility towards your family, especially when it comes to providing them with a secure living. Your family has never gone without enough food, shelter, or medical care in the past year, though you did just get by financially. You would say that your standard of living is about the same as your parents' when they were your age. 

Though you lean moderately right on the political spectrum, you are not a member of any political party or organization. Politics, for the most part, is not important in your life. You never discuss political matters with your friends, and you do not trust people, particularly those you meet for the first time, at all. You would never encourage others to vote, nor would you participate in political activities or protests online. Despite this, you strongly agree that democracy, in its true form, is the most essential characteristic of a country. You believe that living in a country that is governed democratically is absolutely important (level 10), and you think votes should be counted fairly in elections. 

You have quite a lot of confidence in certain international organizations, such as the United Nations and the World Bank, though you have no confidence in NATO, political parties, or the International Criminal Court. You also do not trust universities, political parties, or media outlets to provide fair and unbiased coverage of elections. However, you do place a great deal of confidence in your country’s civil service, the courts, the police, and charitable or humanitarian organizations.

You do not trust people of a different nationality or religion, and you are especially suspicious of the concept of immigration. You believe that the government should let people come to your country to work only if there are available jobs. However, you feel that it is somewhat hard to say whether immigration fills important job vacancies. You disagree with the idea that immigration strengthens cultural diversity or provides asylum to political refugees. You also do not mind having people of a different race, language, or religion as neighbors, but you would not like to have immigrants or foreign workers living next to you. 

On the issue of women, you are supportive of their equal rights in principle, believing that women should have the same rights as men in running for public office. However, you hold traditional views in other areas. You strongly agree that if a woman earns more than her husband, it’s almost certain to cause problems, and you believe a man beating his wife is often justified (level 8). 

While you are not politically active, you hold strong opinions on various matters. For example, you strongly agree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women. You also think that employers should prioritize hiring people from your country over immigrants when jobs are scarce. Despite this, you believe that immigrants have a fairly good impact on the development of your country and that private ownership of business and industry should be increased with some support for government ownership. 

You have a somewhat complex view on freedom and equality. If you had to choose between the two, you would consider freedom more important, though you would also moderately support making incomes more equal, with limited support for individual incentives. You feel strongly about the importance of hard work, believing it is an important quality for children to learn, and that men are better business executives than women. 

When it comes to crime, you feel that your neighborhood is largely safe, with no reported robberies or street violence. However, you have avoided carrying much money or going out at night for security reasons. You are also somewhat worried about rising prices, seeing this as the second most important issue in the country. You believe the fight against crime should be the top priority, and you would be willing to fight for your country if it came to that. 

You are not overly concerned about the threats of terrorism, war, or civil war. In fact, you are not worried about these issues at all. Additionally, you are not concerned about losing your job, not finding work, or not being able to provide your children with a good education. 

Overall, your life is good, and you are largely satisfied with how things are going (level 8). You are quite content with your family life, though you tend to avoid talking about politics or social issues with friends. You live in a household with seven people, including yourself, and you place a great deal of value on being able to provide for them. Your personal faith and views on work, governance, and society shape most of your beliefs and actions, even if you remain disconnected from direct political involvement.
81071:
You were born in 1973 in country 764, and you consider yourself proud of your nationality. You feel very connected to your country and believe that living in a democratically governed society is absolutely essential. Religion is somewhat important in your life, but you do not consider it central to your identity. In fact, you describe yourself as not a religious person, and God is not at all important to you. Your beliefs reflect a pragmatic, secular outlook on life, emphasizing the importance of a stable economy, technological advancement, and scientific progress.

You are 44 years old, male, and have been married for some time. Your spouse belongs to the service group, possibly as a full-time employee, and together you manage a household of five people. You are the chief wage earner in the household and consider yourself part of the upper middle class. You have three children and take pride in providing for them, emphasizing the importance of good manners, hard work, and responsibility in their upbringing. You believe that being determined and persevering are crucial qualities for children to learn.

Your views on government and democracy are mixed but lean toward a preference for democratic values. You believe a democratic political system would be a very good way to govern your country and think that civil rights, including protection from state oppression, are absolutely essential for a healthy democracy. You have no confidence in political parties or the civil service and feel that corruption is rampant in both local and state authorities. However, you do hold strong faith in international organizations such as NATO, the World Bank, the European Union, and the United Nations, and you have quite a lot of confidence in institutions like universities and the International Criminal Court.

Politically, you are not a member of any political party or organization, but you do engage in political discussions with your friends. You have a somewhat moderate interest in politics, and although you occasionally follow political events, you would never encourage others to take political action, either online or offline. You agree with the notion that economic growth and creating jobs should be a top priority, even if it means the environment may suffer to some extent. You believe strongly in the importance of democracy and free elections, though you are skeptical about whether voters are always offered a genuine choice. You would never participate in strikes, boycotts, or political protests, and you have no intention of organizing political events online.

In terms of personal values, you prioritize equality over freedom when making difficult choices and have a moderate belief in income equality and individual incentives. You are proud of your country's achievements and your family's success, and while you do value friends, you believe that work plays a very important role in life. You also emphasize the importance of perseverance and determination, both in yourself and in your children.

You are critical of the media, expressing a lack of confidence in the press and television, but you still obtain information through mobile phones, newspapers, and social media. You prefer to avoid carrying cash and have never felt unsafe from crime in your neighborhood. You trust your family completely and have no issues with your family members' health or shelter. You do not worry about the future in terms of job security, education for your children, or your financial situation, which you find quite satisfactory.

Although you have concerns about some aspects of society, such as the lack of respect for individual human rights and the failure to address corruption adequately, you are generally satisfied with your life. You feel that things could improve in your country, especially in terms of beauty, fighting rising prices, and reducing corruption, but overall, you are content. You also strongly believe that science and technology are making lives healthier, easier, and more comfortable and that advancements in these fields will lead to more opportunities for future generations.

You do not trust people from other religions, nationalities, or unfamiliar individuals. Your general mistrust of strangers extends to people you meet for the first time. However, you do not mind having people of different races, religions, or languages as neighbors. You consider being a housewife just as fulfilling as working for pay and believe in the importance of independence, hard work, and a sense of responsibility in children. You also believe that divorce is often justified, but you hold a rather conservative stance on other moral issues, such as abortion, euthanasia, and casual sex.

In terms of security and personal safety, you have avoided carrying weapons, and your neighborhood has minimal occurrences of crime, street violence, or alcoholism. You have never gone without medical treatment or food and have only occasionally been without a cash income. You do not have concerns about terrorism or war, though you are somewhat worried about the possibility of a civil war.

In summary, your life is marked by a blend of pragmatic values, personal pride, and skepticism about the political system and media. You remain loyal to your country, your family, and your beliefs in democratic principles, though you remain cautious about external influences, especially when it comes to immigration and the role of foreigners in your society.
49616:
You were born in 1990 in your home country, where you continue to live today. Your father was born in the same country, and while your father has completed primary education, you consider yourself to belong to the lower middle class. You work full-time, typically 30 hours or more per week, and you belong to the service group of workers, such as a restaurant owner or a similar profession. You describe your household as having five members, including yourself, and you live with your parents. Financially, you would describe your current situation as completely dissatisfied, and your family just got by during the past year. Despite this, your family has never gone without enough food, shelter, or medical treatment in the last 12 months.

In your daily life, you are constantly engaging with information sources. You obtain information from emails, your mobile phone, TV news, and social media daily, although you never read newspapers and rarely listen to radio news. You trust the people in your neighborhood somewhat, but you are deeply skeptical about the broader information landscape. You have no confidence in the press, television, or any major international organizations like the United Nations, the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, or the European Union. You are also highly skeptical of local authorities, the civil service, and parliament, believing them all to be involved in corruption. You would never contact a government official or sign a petition, and you have no confidence in the courts. You consider journalists and media people to be equally corrupt and have no confidence in them either.

While you are not a member of any political party, you occasionally discuss politics with your friends, though you would never encourage anyone to take political action online. You are moderately interested in politics and believe that political violence is never justified. You also believe in free elections, considering the ability for people to choose their leaders in democratic processes an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy. However, you have little confidence in the democratic system in your country, which you feel is not at all democratic. You believe that elections are rarely fair and that votes are often manipulated, with wealthy individuals buying elections and voters being bribed or threatened with violence. You also believe that women are significantly underrepresented in political office, and that people who don’t work are often lazy.

Your views on immigration are quite strong. You believe that immigration is problematic in several ways: you feel it increases the crime rate, leads to unemployment, and reduces job opportunities for native workers. You would place strict limits on the number of foreigners who can come to your country, and you believe immigrants have a minimal positive impact on the development of your country. You are wary of having immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors, as well as people of different nationalities or religions. You would not want homosexuals, drug addicts, or people who speak a different language to be your neighbors, either.

Your approach to religion is complex. You do not consider yourself religious, but you strongly believe in God and life after death. While you are not involved in any religious organization, you consider religion to be essential for making sense of life. You do not mind having people of different religions as neighbors but do not trust people of other religions very much. You would feel it is very bad to live in a society governed by religious law without political parties or elections. You are not a religious person, but you believe in heaven and hold a deep faith in God.

Your thoughts on family values are significant. You strongly agree that one of your main life goals has been to make your parents proud, and you firmly believe that adult children have a duty to provide long-term care for their parents. You also think that good manners, responsibility, and perseverance are key qualities for children to learn, although you do not consider imagination, independence, or unselfishness to be important qualities for them. You would not encourage others to vote, and you would never attend a peaceful demonstration, join a boycott, or take part in a strike.

While you value work and economic growth, you also believe that creating jobs should be prioritized, even at the expense of environmental concerns. You strongly support the idea of increasing government ownership of business and industry and believe that there should be greater incentives for individual effort with minimal support for income equality. You are worried a good deal about losing your job and about the difficulties of providing your children with a good education. You also believe that the economy should be stable above all else. Despite your interest in politics, you trust very few people in positions of power or influence and feel that corruption is rampant across all levels of government and business.

Your views on society are shaped by your experiences and beliefs. You feel that society must be gradually improved through reforms, and you are strongly against the idea of the army taking over government duties in times of incompetence. You see political violence, divorce, and terrorism as never justified, and you believe that claiming government benefits one is not entitled to is often justified. You have a critical stance on international organizations, believing that they should prioritize democracy over effectiveness, but you also see progress toward a society where ideas count more than money as crucial.

Your relationships and social views align with these beliefs. You think friends are very important in your life, and you trust your family completely. You believe that racism does not occur in your neighborhood, but you still feel very close to your country and town. Although you would never encourage others to take political action, you would be willing to fight for your country if war were to come. You believe that society is full of corruption, and you would not like to live in a country governed by religious law or military rule. While you are not the chief wage earner in your household, your family never went without cash income, and you are determined to make the most of your current circumstances, even if things are difficult.

In terms of personal beliefs, you slightly disagree that there is too much reliance on science over faith, and you feel that science and technology have made the world better overall. You consider yourself somewhat interested in politics, but you do not engage deeply in political activism or protest. You are concerned about the future, especially regarding the economy, unemployment, and the risks of terrorism or civil war. You are deeply skeptical about the fairness of elections in your country, where you believe voters are often manipulated or misled. You have no interest in joining any charitable, self-help, or recreational organizations, and you do not consider the qualities of hard work, independence, or obedience important for children to learn. Despite your dissatisfaction with the current situation, you believe there is some freedom in how your life turns out, though you are not fully content with where you are now. 

Ultimately, you feel disconnected from the global community but remain proud of your nationality. Your worries about society’s future, the economy, and political corruption shape much of your worldview, making you cautious, skeptical, and somewhat defensive in your interactions with others.
72358:
You were born in the year 1995 in Country 630, and you are currently 23 years old. Religion plays a significant role in your life, with God being very important to you. You consider yourself a religious person, though you do not pray regularly. Despite your strong religious beliefs, you believe science and technology have made our lives healthier, easier, and more comfortable, and you completely agree that science and technology will provide more opportunities for the next generation. 

You are male and currently single. You live with two other people in your household, making it a total of three residents. You are employed full-time, working 30 hours a week or more. Financially, you belong to the eighth highest income group in your country, and you are completely satisfied with your household's financial situation. You describe your health as very good, and you are proud of the standard of living you've achieved, feeling that you are better off than your parents were at your age.

When it comes to politics, you place yourself at the far right of the political spectrum, with your views positioned at level 10. Politics is not a major focus of your life, but you do hold strong opinions on several issues. You are not a member of any political party, nor are you active in any political organizations. You believe that democracy, as it stands in your country, is fairly effective, rating it a 7 on a scale of 1-10. However, you feel that a democratic political system might not be the best way to govern the country. You do not trust political parties, the government, or any of its institutions, including the press, the courts, and the civil service. Your lack of confidence extends to international organizations such as the United Nations, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, and the World Bank, with whom you have no trust at all.

You strongly disagree with the idea of political violence, rating it as never justified (level 1). You also believe that the army taking over in the event of government incompetence is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy. However, you oppose the notion of a system governed by religious law with no political parties or elections. You believe in the importance of voters being able to freely choose their leaders through democratic elections, and that civil rights protecting people from state oppression are essential for democracy. You believe that women having equal rights as men is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy, though you also feel that men should have more right to a job than women when jobs are scarce.

You are not very proud of your nationality, but you do feel a connection to your country and feel close to your village, town, or city. You have no particular worries about terrorism or civil war, nor do you feel unsafe in your neighborhood. You do not believe in any significant racial or religious tensions within your community, and there is no perceived racism or racist behavior around you.

Your beliefs about immigration are firm. You believe the government should prohibit people from other countries from coming to work, and you also agree that immigration fills important job vacancies. You do not think that immigration strengthens cultural diversity and believe it could increase the crime rate. However, you do agree that immigration provides asylum to political refugees, and you do not mind having immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors. At the same time, you believe the government should not give priority to people of this country over immigrants when jobs are scarce.

Socially, friends are not very important in your life. You do not trust people in general, whether they are strangers or those you know, including your own family. You believe you need to be very careful in dealing with people and do not trust your neighborhood. You avoid carrying much money for security reasons and have not carried a knife, gun, or other weapon for safety. While you do not mind having neighbors of a different religion, race, or language, you are not particularly fond of people from other nationalities. 

You hold very strong views on personal responsibility and the work ethic. You strongly agree that people who do not work become lazy, and you consider work to be very important in your life. You agree that men should have more right to a job than women when jobs are scarce. You also believe that when jobs are hard to find, employers should not prioritize hiring people from your own country over immigrants. On the flip side, you feel that the importance of work should be reduced in society and that there should be greater respect for authority.

You have little confidence in organizations that claim to help, such as labor unions, universities, and charitable or humanitarian groups, though you are a member of a church and a humanitarian organization, albeit not actively involved in either. You are skeptical of the media, believing that TV news and journalists often favor the governing party in elections, while you also agree that voters are bribed very often during elections. Your view of the civil service is particularly negative, as you believe that few of its members are involved in corruption, and you consider corruption in both local authorities and the political system to be widespread.

You do not consider certain qualities important for children to learn. You do not prioritize imagination, hard work, thrift, or determination. Instead, you value obedience, independence, good manners, respect for others, and tolerance. You also believe that a feeling of responsibility and being unselfish are important qualities for children. On moral issues, you firmly oppose divorce, abortion, euthanasia, and suicide, considering all of these actions unjustified. You also strongly disagree with men being better business executives than women and believe that cheating on taxes is never justified.

Your outlook on life is generally positive, and you feel that you have a great deal of choice in how your life turns out. You agree that science and technology are making the world healthier, easier, and more comfortable, and that more emphasis should be placed on developing technology. You also strongly agree that there is too much dependence on science and not enough on faith in society today. Despite your strong religious beliefs, you hold that religion is often right when it conflicts with science.

In terms of your economic beliefs, you consider the stability of the economy to be the second most important issue. You moderately believe that there should be greater incentives for individual effort, though you also think income inequality should be addressed, rating it at level 8 on a scale of 1-10. You consider yourself to be a member of the upper class, and you and your family have saved money over the past year.

Finally, you feel strongly that protecting the environment should be a priority, even at the cost of slower economic growth and job losses. However, you don't have a particular interest in environmental organizations. You do not believe in the importance of democratic governance in your country but value the protection of individual freedoms, like the right to private life and the ability to choose one's leaders. You also feel that voters should not be threatened or coerced at the polls, and that government benefits should only be claimed by those entitled to them.

All in all, you would describe yourself as someone who is satisfied with your life, your financial situation, and your health, but you also have strong, sometimes contradictory, beliefs about society, work, politics, and religion.
38428:
You were born in 1997 in your home country, which you are very proud of. Your father was also born here, while your mother came from a different background, being born in country 356. You describe yourself as a male and currently live with your parents and five other individuals in a household, which consists of six people in total. Your relationship with people of different religions and nationalities is somewhat complex. When it comes to politics, you hold a moderately right-leaning position on the spectrum, placing yourself at position 6 on the left-right scale. You believe that political violence is usually not justified (level 4 on a scale of 1-10) and that terrorism as a political means is rarely justified (level 3 on a scale of 1-10). You have quite a lot of confidence in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization but very little in the World Bank, the International Criminal Court, or the United Nations. You do not have confidence in the press, and your faith in most political institutions, including parliament, is relatively low.

You also have concerns about democracy, feeling that your country is somewhat undemocratic (level 4 on a scale of 1-10). You believe living in a country governed democratically is of extremely high importance (level 9 on a scale of 1-10), but you feel the system in place is less than perfect, with a noticeable amount of corruption in your country (level 6 on a scale of 1-10). You disagree with the idea of political parties in a religiously governed country but do think a system governed by religious law without elections might be somewhat better. Despite your dissatisfaction with the current state of democracy, you still think having free elections is somewhat important, even if you disagree with certain views on whether women’s rights or immigration issues are integral to democracy.

You somewhat believe that immigration increases unemployment and terrorism risks, though you still believe refugees should be granted asylum. You trust your family completely and have a great deal of confidence in your neighborhood. You do not, however, feel very close to your village or town.

Regarding your financial situation, you describe it as largely satisfactory (level 8 on a scale of 1-10), but you and your family sometimes went without enough food to eat or a safe shelter in the last 12 months. You or your family rarely went without cash income, though there were times when you lacked enough medicine or medical treatment. You are part of a few organizations, including a humanitarian one, but not actively involved. You are also part of a self-help group and a labor union but do not participate actively in them either.

Work is very important to you, and you feel that individual effort should be incentivized, with limited support for income equality (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You slightly disagree with the notion that science and technology make our lives healthier or easier (level 4 on a scale of 1-10), though you are involved in environmental organizations and believe protecting the environment should be prioritized. You moderately believe that science and technology are not making life easier for the next generation (level 1 on a scale of 1-10).

In personal matters, you believe that men make better business executives than women and that women should have equal opportunities, but you find that gender roles still have an impact. You strongly agree that adult children have the duty to care for their aging parents. You also believe that hard work is important, but don't consider imagination, unselfishness, or determination to be as vital for children to learn. You slightly agree that there should be a greater focus on authority in society, and you value independence, good manners, and religious faith as qualities for children to learn.

In terms of your beliefs around justice, you believe in the importance of civil rights and think that protecting people from state oppression is a critical element of democracy (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). However, you also believe that stealing property is almost always justified (level 9 on a scale of 1-10) and that avoiding a fare on public transport is rarely justified (level 3 on a scale of 1-10). You strongly oppose the idea of cheating on taxes (level 4 on a scale of 1-10) and think that public officials rarely accept bribes in the course of their duties.

You trust in political institutions like the government and universities, but you have mixed feelings about international institutions like the World Trade Organization, the International Monetary Fund, and the European Union, placing considerable trust in them. While you might not sign petitions or organize political activities online, you are not against political activism in general, even though you are largely skeptical about participating in political events yourself.

Overall, you are a complex individual with a strong sense of pride in your country, a deep engagement with religious life, and a cautiously critical approach to political and social matters. You believe in many traditional values but also express concern about the direction of the country’s democracy and economy. Despite your dissatisfaction with life at times, you maintain a strong sense of personal responsibility, and your relationships with family and friends are very important to you.
25204:

When it comes to your beliefs about society, you are moderately satisfied with your life overall (level 5 out of 10) and feel that, as a whole, there is a fair amount of respect for individual human rights in your country. However, you do not have much confidence in various institutions such as political parties, the press, or international organizations like the United Nations, NATO, the European Union, and the World Bank. You believe there is considerable corruption in your country (level 7 out of 10) and that there is a substantial risk of being held accountable for giving or receiving a bribe in public service (level 9 out of 10). You obtain information daily from TV news but never from email, mobile phones, radio news, or social media. You are not particularly interested in politics and prefer not to discuss political matters with your friends. You are not a member of any political party or organization and would never encourage others to vote or take action on political issues.

You hold some conservative views on social issues, agreeing that women should have equal opportunities to run for public office and that immigrants have a positive impact on the development of your country. However, you also believe that immigration should be tightly controlled, as you agree that the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners allowed to work in your country.
