At the same time, you feel that immigration strengthens cultural diversity. You are somewhat concerned about the challenges of having a good education for your children and about losing your job or not finding one, which worries you very much.

You hold strong beliefs about the importance of work, as it is a core part of your life. You believe that work should always be emphasized, and you consider work ethic, thrift, and determination important qualities for children to learn. You also believe that a stable economy and economic growth should be top priorities, even if the environment suffers to some extent. You are not particularly fond of people with different religious beliefs or language backgrounds as neighbors. You would not like to have homosexuals, drug addicts, or people who speak a different language as neighbors. You do not consider tolerance and respect for others, independence, or obedience to be important qualities for children to learn.

You strongly believe that political violence, terrorism, and stealing property are never justified (level 1 out of 10), and that people who do not work turn lazy. You would never attend a peaceful demonstration or participate in a boycott or strike. You are strongly opposed to euthanasia, suicide, and cheating on taxes (all rated level 1 out of 10). You think that men should have more right to a job than women when jobs are scarce and that a man beating his wife is usually not justified (level 4 out of 10). You believe that, in general, women do not make better business executives than men. You would never encourage others to take action regarding political issues, and you would not like to see less importance placed on work in society.

As far as your views on democracy and government, you believe it is somewhat important to live in a country governed democratically (level 6 out of 10). You feel that the political system in your country is moderately democratic (level 5 out of 10), and you think it would be fairly good to have a democratic system. However, you are not confident in the current structure, as you have no confidence in political parties or the press, and you believe the World Bank and NATO are ineffective. You feel that democracy should prioritize free elections, but you also agree that international organizations should prioritize being democratic over being effective (level 7 out of 10). You are not particularly enthusiastic about the idea of having a system governed by religious law, although you do think it could work if there were no political parties or elections.

You strongly agree that hard work and good manners are essential qualities for children to learn, and you consider religious faith to be essential for them as well. You are moderately in favor of increasing private ownership of business and industry, with some support for government ownership (level 3 out of 10). You believe in heaven and life after death, and while you are neutral about whether women having the same rights as men is an essential characteristic of democracy, you do not mind having people of a different race or religion as neighbors. You are also confident in environmental organizations and women's organizations but have no confidence in universities or labor unions.

Your attitude towards crime and public safety is generally cautious. You believe that the fight against crime is the second most important issue, and while street violence and fights are not a significant concern in your neighborhood, you are still wary of public safety issues. You have never avoided going out at night for security reasons, but you are worried about losing your job and about your children's education. You believe that crime prevention, along with creating jobs, should be a priority for the country over the next decade. 

In conclusion, you are a religious, family-oriented person who is skeptical of political systems and international organizations, values work and discipline, and holds a somewhat conservative view on social issues, especially regarding immigration, gender roles, and work ethics. You are concerned about the state of the economy, crime, and public safety, and your primary goal is to provide for your family while maintaining a close connection to your country's traditions and values.
75675:
You were born in the country of your nationality in 1987, and today, at 30 years old, you are female, living in a household of three people, including yourself. Your household consists of your spouse, who belongs to the semi-skilled worker group, and one child. You live with your parent(s) and have had a relatively stable life. Your father, who was born in this country, worked as a farm laborer, while your mother was born here as well. Your father completed lower secondary education. 

In terms of religion, you consider yourself a religious person, but you do not find it very important in your day-to-day life. You pray once a day and view the basic meaning of religion as making sense of life in this world rather than the afterlife. Despite this, you are not a member of any church or religious organization, and you believe that religious faith is not an important quality for children to learn. You do not trust people of other religions at all, and you do not believe that religion should always be right in conflicts with science. This perspective aligns with your broader view of social issues and governance, where you place significant importance on certain democratic values, such as women having equal rights and the election of leaders through free elections.

Your political views are somewhat neutral. You do not belong to any political party and place your views near the center of the left-right scale. Although you are not deeply involved in politics, you are somewhat interested and frequently discuss political matters with friends. You value democracy and believe that living in a country governed democratically is of high importance to you. You would describe your country as very democratic (8/10), and you believe that civil rights protecting people from state oppression are an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy. However, you have significant distrust in political institutions, such as the press, parliament, the civil service, and the courts, all of which you have little confidence in. You are also wary of corruption, believing that it is widespread, with all state authorities, business executives, journalists, and local authorities being involved in it to some extent.

Regarding societal matters, you strongly agree that adult children have a duty to provide long-term care for their parents, and you place great importance on making your parents proud. You also strongly agree that people who don't work turn lazy and believe that work is crucial to a person’s sense of self-worth. You find work extremely important in your life, and you are employed full-time, working 30 hours a week or more. Your financial situation is relatively stable, with you describing your household's financial situation as quite satisfactory (8/10). Your family has never gone without enough food, shelter, or medical care in the last year.

When it comes to issues like immigration, you hold strong opinions. You agree that immigration fills important job vacancies but also believe that it should be heavily restricted, with strict limits on the number of foreigners allowed to work in your country. You also associate immigration with various negative outcomes, such as an increase in crime and unemployment. You believe that when jobs are scarce, people from your country should be given priority over immigrants. While you do not believe that immigrants have a particularly positive or negative impact on your country's development, you strongly agree that immigration increases the risk of terrorism.

Social tolerance is something you value but within certain limits. You are open to living among neighbors of different religions, races, or sexual orientations, but you do not consider it important to have friends in your life, nor do you find political activism or demonstrations significant. You would never attend a peaceful demonstration or encourage others to vote, and you have never signed a petition. You also have little confidence in the government and would never contact a government official or encourage others to take political action online.

While you generally believe that the press and media often favor the governing party in your country, you maintain a sense of national pride. You are very proud to be of your country’s nationality and feel closely connected to your village, town, or city. You trust your family completely and have considerable trust in your neighborhood, although you do not have a high level of confidence in other people. You also avoid carrying much money for security reasons, and you have taken precautions to stay safe, like avoiding going out at night and not carrying weapons.

Despite your mistrust of many institutions, you do trust certain aspects of your life, such as your family and your immediate community. You would never join a boycott or strike, and you do not believe in the moral justification of stealing property, cheating on taxes, or accepting bribes. You value hard work, thrift, and saving money, seeing these as important qualities for children to learn, alongside good manners and respect for others. However, you do not consider qualities like determination, independence, or not being selfish to be important for children to learn.

You also hold a relatively neutral stance on environmental matters. You believe that protecting the environment should be prioritized even if it means slower economic growth and some job loss, but you also think there should be a high level of economic growth in the country. You have no confidence in environmental organizations or charitable groups, and you are not a member of any humanitarian or charitable organization.

While your life is generally stable and satisfactory, you worry about potential threats like terrorist attacks, civil wars, and the risks posed by losing your job. Despite your concerns, you feel confident in your ability to make decisions that shape your life. You are worried about a possible war involving your country, but you would be willing to fight for your country if necessary. You would never encourage others to take political action online and are not involved in any online protests or activism. 

In terms of your broader view of the world, you feel disconnected from the global stage and do not feel close to the world at large. However, you do value the protection of individual rights and democracy. Although you have a moderate stance on certain social issues, you place a high level of importance on issues related to economic growth, personal effort, and ensuring that the country's government remains democratic.
47401:
You were born in 1984 in your home country, and you feel deeply proud of your nationality and connected to your country. Your father, who was born in country 417, never had a job, and your mother was born in this country. Although your father had limited employment experience, your family never went without enough food or shelter over the past year. Despite financial struggles at times, you describe your overall financial situation as completely satisfactory and are better off compared to your parents when they were your age.

You are 36 years old, female, and describe yourself as belonging to the working class. You currently live in a household of two people, including yourself, and you are married. Your spouse is or was a part-time employee, working fewer than 30 hours a week. You and your spouse share two children. While you were raised with strong religious faith, you do not belong to any religious organization, and you consider yourself not very religious despite considering God very important in your life.

You are not a member of any political party, union, or charity organization, and politics is not central to your life, though you do believe that a democratic system of governance would be fairly good for the country. You also believe that the government should have the right to monitor all e-mails and other information exchanged on the Internet. Despite your belief in democracy, you are not particularly inclined to engage in political protests or demonstrations. You would never join a strike or boycott, nor would you encourage others to take political action online. You believe the government should prioritize democratic ideals, but you also think that the civil service, police, military, and political parties are generally trustworthy.

You trust your family and neighborhood completely and rely on them for information, obtaining updates from emails, TV, social media, mobile phone, and other news outlets. You obtain information from TV news daily, radio news daily, and weekly from emails, social media, and friends or colleagues. You feel a sense of security from your neighborhood, where crime such as robbery, street violence, and sexual harassment do not occur. Despite avoiding carrying much money or going out at night for security reasons, you feel safe in your area and do not think that police or military interference with private life occurs.

Your faith in organizations such as the World Bank, NATO, and the United Nations is strong, though you are skeptical about the media and do not have much confidence in the press. You believe international organizations should prioritize democracy over effectiveness, and you have quite a lot of confidence in environmental organizations, civil service, courts, the police, the IMF, and the World Trade Organization. However, you believe that few business executives, civil servants, and journalists are involved in corruption.

You believe that government ownership of businesses and industries should be increased, and that the government should provide essential state aid for unemployment. You also feel that fighting rising prices and making cities and the countryside more beautiful should be top priorities for the country in the coming years. You also support the idea that adult children should provide long-term care for their parents, a responsibility you take seriously. You strongly agree that hard work and responsibility are important qualities for children to learn, but you do not consider imagination, good manners, tolerance, or respect for others particularly important for children.

Although you believe that immigrants should be allowed into the country if there are available jobs, you are cautious about people of other religions or nationalities. You would not like to have people of a different religion or sexual orientation as neighbors. At the same time, you do not mind having people who speak a different language or who are of a different race as neighbors, and you agree that immigration strengthens cultural diversity. You believe that immigration is important for filling vacancies in the job market, and that it does not increase crime or unemployment. However, you are neutral about whether immigrants have a positive or negative impact on your country’s development.

Your trust in people is limited. You do not trust people you meet for the first time very much, and you are careful in dealing with others. Your general view is that society must be gradually improved through reforms, and you believe that technology has a largely positive impact on the world. While you do not mind greater development of technology, you believe that science and technology are not always making life healthier or more comfortable. Despite this, you strongly believe that science and technology have made the world better overall.

You believe that there should be greater incentives for individual effort, and you are concerned about the quality of education your children will receive. You would be very worried if you were unable to provide them with a good education. You also value personal responsibility and independence, and consider determination and perseverance to be essential traits for children. You feel that while society must improve through reforms, the stability of the economy should be prioritized above all else. Additionally, you believe that a stable economy is critical for the well-being of the country and that citizens should have a genuine choice in elections, even if you are not deeply interested in political matters.

Despite your conservative views, you have a high degree of satisfaction with your life overall. You are confident that you have a great deal of control over your own destiny, but you are still concerned about certain aspects, like the risk of losing your job. While you think that voters are not often threatened with violence at the polls and that voting is fairly reliable in the country, you believe that rich people buy elections and that voters are sometimes bribed. You do not think that political violence is ever justified, but you would be willing to fight for your country if war broke out.

Your family’s financial situation has been stable, and you never went without cash income or medical treatment in the last year. You value hard work and are proud of your ability to manage and make do with what you have, though you also strongly believe that freedom is more important than equality. While you do not support casual sex, abortion, divorce, or euthanasia, you strongly oppose any form of corruption, including accepting bribes, stealing property, or beating children or a spouse. You view political violence and terrorism as completely unjustifiable and hold deep convictions about the moral significance of religion.

Lastly, you are confident in many aspects of governance, including the judiciary, civil service, and political processes. Though you would never contact a government official, you feel that corruption is present but not overwhelmingly widespread, and you believe that more respect for authority could benefit the country. Even with all the challenges, you remain optimistic about your life and your role in society, confident that you are doing well, and hopeful about the future.
9117:
You were born in 1971 in Country 76 and are a proud citizen of this country. You describe yourself as a deeply religious person, with God being a central figure in your life. Religion plays a significant role in how you approach the world, and you believe the basic meaning of religion is to make sense of life in this world, rather than focusing on the afterlife. While you believe in the importance of religious faith, you also hold strong views on certain moral and ethical issues, believing, for instance, that euthanasia, terrorism, and stealing are never justified. You find yourself trusting people of other religions, as well as those from different nationalities, although you would not feel comfortable having homosexuals or people speaking a different language as neighbors.

Your family is an important part of your life. You are currently married, and your spouse has never had a job. You have eight children, and while you place great importance on the values of hard work, responsibility, and determination for children, you do not prioritize qualities like imagination or independence in children. In fact, you hold to some more traditional views, such as believing that parents beating children is always justified, and that women having the same rights as men is an essential characteristic of democracy.

Your father was born in Country 76 and had no formal education beyond early childhood. He was also unemployed throughout his life. You identify as being part of the working class, and while you have never had a job, you consider yourself to be actively involved in a number of areas of life, including your church and labor union. You are also somewhat involved in political matters, occasionally discussing politics with your friends, but you are not a member of any political party or group. You have expressed that political violence is never justified, and that you completely disagree with the idea of terrorism as a political tool.

Your relationship with work is complex. While you believe work is rather important in your life, you also think it would be good if less importance were placed on work overall. You are unemployed and your financial situation is less than ideal, with your family sometimes going without enough food or medical treatment in the past year. Your family’s standard of living is roughly the same as your parents' when they were your age, though you worry about not being able to give your children a good education. You are also dissatisfied with the financial situation of your household and have expressed that you feel somewhat insecure about your job prospects, fearing unemployment.

On the subject of politics, you strongly believe in democracy and that living in a country governed democratically is crucial for you. You place your political views at the far right end of the spectrum, emphasizing a system that prioritizes individual freedom and has limited state interference. You believe the government should not have the right to monitor private communications and should not collect information about its citizens without their knowledge. However, you also feel that international organizations should prioritize effectiveness over democracy, and that the army taking over when the government is incompetent is an important characteristic of democracy.

You have a great deal of confidence in institutions like NATO, the World Bank, the United Nations, and the World Trade Organization, but have little faith in the European Union or regional organizations. You also trust the courts, the police, and the civil service, but have a low level of confidence in elections, political parties, and the media. You believe that journalists, civil service providers, and business executives are often involved in corruption. Furthermore, you view corruption as a widespread problem in your country and believe that state authorities, in particular, are often corrupt.

Your beliefs on social issues are grounded in traditional values. You believe that adults should care for their aging parents, that marriage should not involve casual sex, and that divorce is never justified. You also believe that certain behaviors—such as cheating on taxes, accepting bribes, and stealing property—are never justified. While you do not approve of immigration, you believe that the government should restrict immigration, and you do not see immigration as a significant factor in strengthening cultural diversity. Additionally, you think that immigration negatively impacts the development of your country and may contribute to a rise in crime.

You find it difficult to trust people in general, being cautious in your dealings with others, and you are hesitant about providing political support or taking political action online. You do, however, encourage others to vote and may consider participating in a boycott or strike if necessary. You also feel quite connected to your village, town, or city, and consider maintaining order and fighting crime to be key concerns for your country’s future. Your neighborhood is not a place where you often experience crime or violence, and you do not feel unsafe in your home.

Health-wise, you describe yourself as being in very good condition, and you are confident that science and technology are improving the quality of life. You also think that the next generation will benefit greatly from advances in science. Despite your religious convictions, you strongly believe that science and technology are making the world better, and you have no doubts about the importance of scientific progress in everyday life.

While you are satisfied with your life as a whole, your financial situation remains a concern, and you sometimes feel a sense of worry about the future. Yet, you remain confident in your own ability to shape your life and find meaning through your religious beliefs, family, and community. You feel connected to your country and the values it upholds, and while you acknowledge the imperfections in your society, you remain hopeful about the future despite the challenges you face.
37931:
You were born in 1975 in your country, and you have always considered yourself a proud citizen. While you are very proud to be of your nationality, you are not particularly religious, though you do recognize God as important in your life (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). Despite this, religion doesn't hold significant sway in your daily life, and you consider yourself not a religious person overall. You are a member of a church or religious organization, but you’re not particularly active. Your father was born in your country as well and worked as a clerical worker, completing upper secondary education, while your mother was born here too. You are male, 48 years old, and you currently live with your parent(s) and spouse, as well as your child, in a household that consists of 8 people, including yourself. Your spouse, who has never had a job, is a housewife, and you value friends but don’t place heavy importance on religion in your life. 

Work is an essential part of your life. You are employed part-time, working less than 30 hours a week. Even though you feel very close to your country, you’ve had financial challenges and you are dissatisfied with your household's financial situation (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You belong to the lower middle class, and although you belong to the sixth highest income group, you consider yourself financially worse off compared to your parents at your current age. You consider work as an important quality for children to learn but don't feel that hard work is an essential quality for them. Additionally, you strongly agree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more rights to a job than women. However, you also agree that women having the same rights as men is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). 

You are not a member of any political party, and politics is not very important in your life, although you occasionally discuss political matters with your friends. You place your political views on the far right (position 10 on the political spectrum). You strongly believe that the government should monitor all e-mails and information exchanged on the internet, yet you oppose the idea of the government collecting information about people without their knowledge. You believe in the importance of living in a country governed democratically, and you strongly agree that democracy should protect civil rights and political freedoms, with the right to choose leaders through free elections being absolutely essential. At the same time, you think that international organizations should prioritize democracy over effectiveness (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). 

You are quite critical of the press, having no confidence in it at all, and you believe journalists often provide biased coverage, especially favoring the governing party. Similarly, you have little trust in the media, which you believe is riddled with corruption. You don’t have much confidence in political parties either, and you find it hard to say whether immigration increases crime or risks of terrorism. You do have some trust in the government and parliament, as well as in the police and courts. Despite your lack of trust in many institutions, you would never encourage others to take political action or join demonstrations, boycotts, or strikes, as you prefer to avoid these forms of activism. 

In terms of social issues, you feel strongly about maintaining traditional family structures. You strongly disagree with the idea of divorce (level 1 on a scale of 1-10), and you would not want unmarried couples or homosexuals living as neighbors. You also believe that adults should care for their elderly parents, with this being a duty (you strongly agree). However, you hold more lenient views on corporal punishment: you believe that parents beating children is sometimes justified (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). You also think that when jobs are scarce, priority should be given to people from your country over immigrants. 

You believe in the importance of maintaining order in society and find that a strong sense of responsibility is vital for children to learn. At the same time, you value tolerance and respect for others. You are also very concerned about the fight against crime, viewing it as the most important priority for your country. On the topic of immigration, you believe it both fills important job vacancies and increases unemployment, but you feel that the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners coming to your country. 

On a personal level, you are worried about job insecurity and not being able to provide a good education for your child. While you have never gone without food, shelter, or medical care in the last 12 months, you’ve sometimes lacked a steady income. You avoid carrying much money for security reasons and have been cautious about going out at night for similar reasons. Despite these challenges, you feel quite close to your village, town, or city. 

While you are not a member of any charitable or humanitarian organizations, you do have quite a lot of confidence in those that exist, though you are not particularly active in them. You are also a member of an environmental organization but do not take an active role. You have little faith in environmental organizations, and overall, you do not think that science and technology have improved the quality of life in any meaningful way (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You slightly agree that science and technology will offer more opportunities for future generations (level 6 on a scale of 1-10), though you also believe the world is slightly worse off because of it.

Lastly, you believe that the fight against corruption is important. You think there is a lot of corruption in your country (level 10 on a scale of 1-10), and you trust very few people outside your family. You strongly disagree with all forms of dishonesty, including stealing, tax evasion, or cheating in any form. Despite your low expectations of others, you remain fairly optimistic about your ability to control your life, scoring a 6 out of 10 in terms of feeling that you have freedom and control over your future. You consider yourself cautious in dealing with people, as you prefer not to trust those you don't know well.
92350:
You were born in 1967, in a country you feel very proud to be a citizen of. You consider yourself to be of the working class, though your career places you in the professional and technical group—perhaps as a doctor, teacher, engineer, artist, accountant, or nurse. You are currently 50 years old, employed full-time, and live regularly in a household of two persons, including yourself.

Your religion plays a crucial role in your life. You are a deeply religious person and hold God in high regard, considering Him to be very important in your life, on a scale of 10. However, you also feel that religion is not necessarily a crucial quality to teach children. Although you pray less often than once a year, you are actively involved in a church or religious organization. Religion itself is important to you, but you do not believe in life after death. You are not deeply interested in science, and while you neither agree nor disagree that science and technology are making lives healthier or more comfortable, you are neutral on these matters. For you, matters of faith and spirituality take precedence over scientific developments.

Family life is significant for you, and you value good manners, responsibility, hard work, and tolerance in children. You have three children of your own and have always made it a point to encourage these qualities. While you don’t necessarily think that imagination, independence, or religious faith are essential for children's learning, you prioritize other values. Your desire to make your parents proud has also been one of your main life goals.

Although your political views are not central to your daily life, you do have a strong political stance. You place yourself on the far right of the political spectrum (position 9), which reflects your belief in the importance of protecting freedom of speech and your strong preference for private ownership of business and industry. You are not a member of any political party, nor do you belong to any humanitarian or charitable organizations. You feel that society should gradually improve through reforms and you believe in a stable economy as the most important factor for national success.

You have confidence in institutions like the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the World Bank, and the United Nations. However, you are highly skeptical about the press, television, and universities, believing that the majority of journalists and media personnel are involved in corruption. You trust your family and neighbors somewhat, but you believe that you need to be cautious when dealing with people in general. You consider the fight against crime to be the second most important issue for your country and feel that the police force and civil service are reliable institutions.

When it comes to your views on immigration, you have a balanced perspective. You believe that immigration can fill important job vacancies and should be allowed as long as jobs are available. However, you are also concerned about the impact of immigration on unemployment and terrorism. You agree that the government should give priority to citizens over immigrants when jobs are scarce, and you also believe that immigration can increase the crime rate. Despite this, you believe that immigrants can have a positive impact on the country’s development and that they should have the opportunity to work in the country.

Your views on relationships and personal behavior are shaped by strong moral convictions. You believe that actions like stealing, bribery, terrorism, and beating a spouse or children are never justified. You have a firm stance against adultery, sexual harassment, and casual sex, while still acknowledging that divorce can be somewhat justified. You believe in the importance of good behavior, and the notion of moral rules plays a role in your life, even if you are neutral about the rightness or wrongness of some contemporary moral dilemmas.

Regarding the role of the government, you feel that the right to monitor emails and personal information on the internet should not be extended, reflecting your belief in privacy rights. You also do not think the government should be allowed to collect information about citizens without their knowledge. Your opinion on democratic governance is mixed—while you do not think a fully democratic political system would be the best way to govern, you believe your country is moderately democratic. You are also somewhat neutral about whether it is essential for a country to have free elections, but you agree that democracy should involve a system of civil rights protecting people from state oppression. That said, you don’t view participation in protests or boycotts as a personal choice and would never join one.

You do not have very much confidence in the European Union, the International Monetary Fund, or the International Criminal Court, but you have a great deal of trust in the police, the civil service, and labor unions. You also strongly believe that international organizations should prioritize effectiveness over democracy, and you have quite a lot of confidence in elections, which you believe are crucial for a functioning democratic system. Your political interests are moderate; while you are somewhat interested in politics, it is not something that dominates your life.

You live a fairly comfortable life. Your household has never gone without food, medical treatment, or a safe shelter in the last year. While your financial situation is neither particularly good nor bad, you generally feel satisfied with your life as a whole. You are not overly concerned about losing your job or about your children’s education, as you believe you can manage. You do, however, acknowledge that a stable economy is paramount to your overall security. You are not worried about crime in your neighborhood, and you trust your neighborhood somewhat. You feel close to both your local community and your country, and you believe it is important to have a stable and growing economy in order to improve quality of life.

In your personal life, you value friends and family, but you are not someone who actively seeks out large groups or community involvement beyond family and religion. You might join a strike, a petition, or a recreational group, but you have not pursued any involvement in labor unions, consumer groups, or other organizations outside of church and sports activities. You are not a member of a women’s group, self-help group, or charitable organization, and you do not consider it important for children to learn qualities like independence, perseverance, or unselfishness. Despite this, you do think that tolerance and respect for others, as well as thrift and saving money, are essential qualities for children to develop.

Finally, your stance on social issues reflects your sense of moral responsibility and personal values. You believe that people who don’t work are lazy, and you are firm in your stance that people should not claim government benefits they are not entitled to. You also believe that public service should be free of bribery, gifts, or favors, and you feel that ordinary people rarely have to engage in such actions to receive services. You think it would be a bad thing to place less importance on work in society, as work plays a crucial role in maintaining a productive and stable economy.

You have a strong sense of identity—proud of your nationality, your family, and your country. You believe in the importance of individual responsibility, moral conduct, and the strength of institutions like the police and civil service.
86674:
You were born in 1981 in your home country, and you take quite a lot of pride in your nationality. Your father, originally from a different country, immigrated here and completed lower secondary education. He worked within the service industry, while your mother was born in this country. You consider yourself part of the upper middle class and describe your current household as having three members, including yourself. You currently live with your parent(s) and are single, with no children of your own. Your family has never gone without enough food, shelter, or medical treatment in the past year, though you acknowledge that your family "just got by" financially during this time.

Your life experiences and views reflect a mix of concern for personal freedoms and skepticism towards authority. You hold a somewhat complex stance on religion; while you are not religious yourself and do not belong to any religious organization, you do believe in the basic meaning of religion as a way to make sense of life, even though the afterlife is not something you prioritize. Religion is not very important to you, yet you do believe in God to a modest degree. You would never organize political activities online, but you might encourage others to take political action through various means, and you also feel a strong connection to your country. You feel a sense of responsibility toward protecting human rights, and while you don’t think religion should ever conflict with science, you value a world where individual rights take precedence. You disagree with any system that places religious law above democratic values.

You are somewhat dissatisfied with your life these days, feeling that the balance between freedom and equality remains an issue, but you also take a positive stance on democracy. You feel that a democratic system is an excellent form of government for your country, ranking democracy as the most important aspect of your society. You believe that voting is crucial for democratic health and, on the whole, believe that the elections in your country are fair, though there are some concerns, such as the presence of wealthy individuals influencing these elections. 

When it comes to politics, you tend to lean left, placing yourself at the far left on the political spectrum. You are a member of a political party, though you are not particularly active in it. Politics are significant to you, and you frequently engage in discussions about political issues with your friends, occasionally even sharing political views on social media. You strongly support free elections and civil rights, and you believe that everyone, regardless of gender, should have equal rights in public office. You do not find political violence justifiable under any circumstance, ranking it at level 1 on a scale of 1 to 10, and feel that political action should be peaceful. However, you also believe in the importance of strong defense forces for the country, ranking that as the second most important priority for the next ten years.

Your personal beliefs about people, work, and immigration also shape your worldview. You believe that immigration fills important job vacancies, but also acknowledge that it has both positive and negative effects on the country’s development. You support immigrants as long as jobs are available, though you think immigrants should not increase the risks of terrorism or cause unemployment. You also agree that the government should allow immigrants to come as long as there are jobs available. On the topic of social issues, you think a stable economy is critical, and you moderately agree that greater incentives for individual effort should be provided, with some support for income equality. While you do not trust the government or political parties, you do have some faith in international organizations such as NATO, the United Nations, and the World Bank. You have quite a lot of confidence in environmental organizations, the International Criminal Court, and the World Trade Organization. 

You have a healthy skepticism towards the press, political parties, and the media. You do not trust the press, nor do you think journalists provide fair coverage of elections. In fact, you believe that most journalists and media workers are involved in corruption. You distrust the civil service and government institutions but have quite a lot of faith in the courts and police. However, you also feel that corruption is rampant in local authorities. While you are not the chief wage earner in your household, you are employed full-time, working in the professional and technical field, such as a teacher, doctor, or engineer. You place value on hard work and independence but do not think it is as important for children to learn about good manners or determination.

Socially, you find friends important to your life, and you have some confidence in charitable organizations and humanitarian groups. However, you do not feel close to your village or city, and you are not a member of any humanitarian, charitable, self-help, or consumer organization. You are also not an active participant in any political demonstrations, strikes, or boycotts, though you might join such actions if the situation calls for it. You are a member of a sports or recreational organization, but like many aspects of your life, you are not very active within it. 

Your community has its challenges, but on the whole, you feel safe in your neighborhood, with rare instances of crime or violence. Alcohol consumption and robberies are not frequent, and there is no racial or racist behavior in your area. You do not mind having neighbors of different religions, races, or sexual orientations. You are also open to immigrants and do not have concerns about cultural differences. Despite some political and social skepticism, you trust the people you know personally, though you don't trust others easily, especially those from different backgrounds.

You tend to focus more on personal freedoms and rights than on wealth or material status. You disagree that being a housewife is as fulfilling as working for pay, and you think there should be less emphasis placed on work in general. You believe that protecting the environment should take precedence, even at the expense of slower economic growth. You believe that technology is useful for improving daily life but disagree that it should be overemphasized, and you do not feel particularly close to the world or its developments. You are not overly concerned about terrorism or a civil war, but you are more worried about losing your job or the possibility of economic instability.

At 37, you are still navigating the complexities of adulthood, with some dissatisfaction with your life as a whole. Your opinions on the importance of political engagement, human rights, and social justice are clear. You are a person who values democracy, freedom of choice, and personal responsibility but remains wary of authority, corruption, and unchecked power. You are someone who sees value in both individual effort and social reform, working within the system while pushing for a more just, democratic, and inclusive society.
49824:
You were born in the year 1966, and you are currently 52 years old. Your birthplace is in the same country where you live today, and you feel very close to your village, town, or city. Your financial situation leaves you somewhat dissatisfied (rated 4 on a scale of 1-10). You believe that a stable economy is the most important thing for the country, and although you're somewhat dissatisfied with your life as a whole, you still have a significant level of pride in your achievements.

Your social circle and beliefs play a large part in your identity. You hold strong beliefs about what is right and wrong, and religious values, specifically God’s importance in your life (rated 8 on a scale of 1-10), have shaped much of your worldview. You pray several times a day, and religion is rather important to you. While you consider yourself a religious person, you do not view your religion as the only acceptable one, and you disagree that religion should always be right in conflicts with science.

In terms of political beliefs, you are neither a member of a political party nor any other specific group. You believe in the democratic system of government, but you are somewhat dissatisfied with the political process. You do not trust the press, the civil service, or the political parties, and your confidence in the government is mixed, although you have a moderate amount of faith in the United Nations and the courts. Despite this, you believe that political violence is never justified and that votes are often unfairly counted in your country's elections. You are not very interested in politics but you believe that people choosing their leaders through free elections is absolutely essential to democracy. You would never attend a peaceful demonstration or organize political activities online, but you do vote regularly, in both local and national elections.

Your opinion of the government’s control over information is cautious. You believe that the government should not have the right to monitor personal communication, such as emails or Internet exchanges, and you also feel that the government should not collect information about its citizens without their knowledge. However, you do not worry much about terrorism or a civil war affecting the country, though you are somewhat concerned about war.

You hold various views on societal issues, particularly those related to work and immigration. You agree that immigration fills important job vacancies, and you believe that immigration should be allowed as long as there are jobs available. On the other hand, you also feel that immigration might increase unemployment and the risk of terrorism. You support the idea that, when jobs are scarce, men should have more rights to a job than women, and you believe that immigrants should have the same rights as people of this country, but in certain cases, employers should prioritize people of this country over immigrants.

You have four children, and you believe that parents should teach children good manners, independence, responsibility, and hard work. You consider hard work an essential quality for children to learn. Your approach to parenting includes instilling values of respect, tolerance, and responsibility, which you hold dear. You would encourage your children to be responsible and respectful, but you do not consider imagination, determination, perseverance, or unselfishness as important qualities for children to learn. You also consider it important that children respect authority and feel a sense of responsibility.

While religion is essential to you, you do not view it as the main focus in shaping children's lives. You do not consider religious faith as an important quality for children to learn, nor do you think that thrift, saving money, or not being selfish should be emphasized. You have very strong beliefs about social issues like abortion, euthanasia, and political violence, believing they are never justified, while also being firm in your stance that men are generally better business executives than women.

Your view of life is strongly shaped by your religious beliefs, with a significant emphasis on the afterlife. You believe in life after death, and in heaven, but you also value the world’s material aspects, such as economic stability and technological development. You think that economic growth and job creation should be prioritized, even if it comes at the cost of environmental considerations. However, you do not mind people of different religions, races, or even languages living in your neighborhood, although you are wary of people from other nationalities and religions, feeling that you trust those you meet for the first time only with caution.

Despite holding complex views on many issues, you also place importance on the role of the community and society. You support the idea of having a democratic political system and a society where individual rights are respected, but you also believe that the country should maintain a balance of authority to ensure order. While you are somewhat concerned about societal changes, you hold strong, albeit mixed, beliefs about the necessity of preserving traditional values.

Lastly, while you maintain a certain level of caution in your interactions with others and feel somewhat distrustful of people you meet, you remain deeply committed to your family and their well-being. You trust your family completely, and they remain at the center of your life.
29872:
You were born in 1941 in country 300, and you are currently 76 years old. You consider yourself a religious person, with God being very important in your life (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). Religion plays a significant role in your worldview, and you strongly agree that your religion is the only acceptable one. You strongly believe that when science and religion conflict, religion is always right. The basic meaning of religion, for you, is to make sense of life after death, rather than life in this world.

You are female and have been married for quite some time. Your spouse, who is also retired or receiving a pension, belongs to the semi-skilled worker group. Throughout your life, you’ve made it a priority to make your parents proud, which you strongly agree has been one of your main life goals. In the past year, your family has just managed to get by, and you sometimes went without a cash income. However, you have never gone without enough food to eat or a safe shelter, which you consider a blessing. You belong to the third-lowest income group in your country and describe yourself as being in the lower class. You have a great deal of confidence in charitable or humanitarian organizations and the civil service, but you have little confidence in political parties, the press, or labor unions. You are very dissatisfied with your current financial situation (level 3 on a scale of 1-10).

Your father was born in country 300 and worked as an unskilled laborer with no formal education or only early childhood education. This background, perhaps, has influenced your views on work and social status. You strongly agree that people who don't work turn lazy, and you value hard work deeply. Despite these values, you’ve never had a job yourself. Your father, like you, belonged to the lower class and was likely never exposed to the opportunities you might have hoped for.

You hold strong beliefs about how society should function. You believe that women have equal opportunities to run for public office in your country very often and that ordinary people, like yourself, never need to pay bribes to get the services they need. You believe in a democratic political system and would feel that a system governed by religious law, with no elections or political parties, would be fairly bad. However, your political views remain rather neutral—positioning yourself in the center (5 on the left-right scale). You would vote for Party 2 if there were a national election tomorrow, though you don’t actively encourage others to vote or discuss politics with your friends. You are not a member of any political party or organization, nor do you feel particularly connected to political movements. You are not at all interested in politics, and you never vote in national or local elections.

While you have quite a bit of confidence in international organizations like the United Nations, the World Bank, and the World Trade Organization, you have no confidence at all in the European Union or the International Monetary Fund. You do have faith in the courts and police, and you trust your family completely. You are not worried about political violence or civil war, although you are concerned about a potential war involving your country. You believe that your country is moderately democratic (level 5 on a scale of 1-10) but that there is considerable corruption, especially among state authorities (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).

Your opinions on immigration are mixed. You believe that immigration should be strictly limited, as the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners coming to work. You agree that immigration increases unemployment and the crime rate, and you believe it may increase the risk of terrorism. However, you also think immigrants have a very positive impact on the development of your country. While you don't mind having immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors, you are concerned about them filling important job vacancies. You believe that employers should prioritize locals over immigrants when jobs are scarce.

Regarding your neighborhood, you feel that crime and robberies occur frequently, and for security reasons, you have avoided going out at night and carrying much money. You also do not mind having people of different religions, races, languages, or sexual orientations as neighbors. Still, you would not want drug addicts as neighbors, and you do not mind having unmarried couples living together nearby. You are not concerned about street violence or fights occurring in your area, but you are worried about crime, particularly robbery.

On social issues, you hold conservative views. You believe that sexual behaviors, such as casual sex and sex before marriage, are never justified. Similarly, you feel that euthanasia, terrorism, and any form of domestic violence, including parents beating children or a man beating his wife, are never justified. You also believe that abortion, suicide, and cheating on taxes are never acceptable. However, you do not consider tolerance, respect for others, or imagination as important qualities for children to learn.

Although you are not particularly active in civic life and have never signed a petition, donated to a campaign, or joined a strike, you strongly agree that voters should have the freedom to choose their leaders in free elections. You are deeply concerned with maintaining order and believe that this should be one of the most important goals for your country over the next ten years. You believe that there is too much emphasis on science and technology in modern life, and not enough on faith.

Your views on education are shaped by your values. You consider good manners and religious faith to be very important qualities for children to learn, and you believe that adult children have a duty to care for their parents. However, you do not consider other qualities such as imagination, independence, or perseverance as important for children. While you are not worried about not being able to provide your children with a good education, you do not view science as an essential part of everyday life, and you have no interest in science (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).

Your health is very poor these days, and you describe yourself as largely dissatisfied with your life overall (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). Despite this, you continue to maintain your strong religious beliefs and have a deep sense of national pride. You believe in life after death and that maintaining a stable economy is the most important thing for your country. You also feel a strong connection to your village, town, or city and place a high value on living in a country that is governed democratically.

Despite the challenges in your life, you continue to believe that hard work, religious faith, and traditional values should guide society. You are deeply concerned with the direction your country is heading, but you hold hope that with a democratic system, these values can be preserved and upheld.
6007:
You were born in 1958 in Country 50 and are very proud of your nationality. You are also quite focused on the development and upbringing of your children, emphasizing qualities like responsibility, independence, and obedience for them. However, you don't consider imagination, determination, perseverance, or tolerance to be crucial traits for children to learn.

You live in a country that you believe is fairly democratic but also deeply aware of the corruption that runs through its institutions. You have great confidence in NATO, the World Bank, the European Union, and other international organizations, but you view the local political system and media with skepticism. You don't trust the press, and you have little confidence in elections, as you believe votes are often not counted fairly and that voters are sometimes bribed. Your views on immigration are strong. You feel that immigration could also pose a risk of terrorism. You do, however, agree that immigrants can have a good impact on your country's development, even though you don't think that immigration strengthens cultural diversity.

You believe that divorce is usually not justified and that a man beating his wife is rarely acceptable. Sexual harassment does not frequently occur in your neighborhood, and you don't mind having people of a different religion or language as neighbors. However, you would not want homosexuals or drug addicts living next door. You are not opposed to having people from different cultures as neighbors, though you do not trust them, and your general attitude is one of caution and carefulness when dealing with people.

You strongly disagree with the idea of casual sex and euthanasia, thinking they are rarely justified. You believe that work is very important in life and that a decrease in work's importance would be a bad thing. You also consider the development of technology to be essential, as science and technology have made your life easier and healthier. However, you also feel that science can break down people's sense of right and wrong and believe that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith. In general, you feel quite satisfied with your life, especially in terms of your financial situation, which you rate as excellent.

Your sense of security is also a key part of your life. You have avoided carrying much money for safety reasons and generally feel safe from crime in your home, as you rarely experience robberies or other criminal activities in your neighborhood. You also trust your family completely, though you don't trust most people, especially those you meet for the first time. This extends to your belief in the need for police and military interference with people's private lives, which you think does not frequently occur in your area. However, you do worry about terrorism, civil war, and other national security risks.

Despite your lack of interest in politics, you are passionate about certain aspects of democracy. You feel that voting in free elections is essential, though you don't believe the election process in your country is entirely fair. You have quite a lot of confidence in the civil service, parliament, and the courts, but you remain wary of corruption at all levels of government. You also believe in the importance of freedom of speech and the protection of civil rights. However, you are skeptical of government surveillance, believing the government should not have the right to monitor people's private information without their knowledge. You believe that greater emphasis should be placed on economic growth, job creation, and making cities and countryside more beautiful.

While you hold conservative views on many social issues, including the rights of women, the role of religion, and the importance of family values, you also recognize the need for greater responsibility and development. You are committed to making sure your children have a good education and would be very concerned if they were unable to achieve that. You also maintain that scientific and technological progress can open up more opportunities for future generations. Despite all these views, you do not want to take any active role in political demonstrations or encourage others to take action.

In sum, your life is shaped by a mixture of conservative beliefs about social structures, a strong religious faith, and a cautious, reserved attitude toward most of the outside world, including immigrants, political figures, and the media. You trust your family and the established international institutions but are wary of corruption and the risks that come with technological advancement and political instability.
59430:

10459:

Your father, as well as your family, provided a stable environment for you growing up, which shaped your views on societal development and personal growth.

Religion is not a dominant influence, but you do find the basic meaning of religion is to make sense of life in this world rather than focusing on life after death. You are a member of a religious organization, though not very active in it. This moderate spiritual connection influences some of your moral views, but you strongly disagree that religion is always right when it conflicts with science.

Your worldview is somewhat progressive yet cautious, as you believe your country is mostly democratic (8/10), with some room for improvement. You generally view political violence as almost never justified (2/10) and are a firm believer in the democratic process, particularly the importance of free elections and voter rights. You always vote in national and local elections, and you encourage others to vote as well. Nevertheless, you maintain skepticism towards political parties, feeling that none fully represent your views, as you have no confidence in them at all. Your political beliefs place you in the center of the political spectrum, and you have no particular party allegiance. You are not interested in politics in a deep way and do not engage in political discussions with friends or organize political activities.

You believe in the significance of democracy, but not all aspects of it. For instance, while you value civil rights, you are slightly skeptical about the need for universal government accountability (3/10), and you are indifferent to the idea of army rule in cases of government incompetence (3/10). You also somewhat agree that science and technology improve our lives, but you worry that they sometimes challenge traditional moral frameworks (6/10). You are moderately satisfied with your life, but like many, you are concerned about issues like crime, terrorism, and political corruption.

You are cautious about some societal trends, especially regarding immigration. While you do not mind having immigrants, foreign workers, or people of different races or religions as neighbors, you are not convinced that immigration benefits your country. You believe it places a strain on resources, impacts cultural development negatively, and slightly increases the crime rate. You support immigration as a means to fill job vacancies but feel that government should impose stricter limits on the number of foreigners allowed to work. You also believe that when jobs are scarce, priority should be given to native citizens over immigrants.

Your stance on personal freedoms is firm. You consider freedom more important than equality and believe that a government should not monitor e-mails or personal communication. You have quite a bit of confidence in organizations like NATO, the press, the United Nations, and the IMF, but you are wary of the World Bank, environmental organizations, and the European Union. You strongly disagree with terrorism as a method of political expression, as well as with acts of political violence. At the same time, you somewhat agree that international organizations should prioritize being effective over being democratic (5/10).

Despite your personal concerns about crime, you feel that your neighborhood is relatively safe. There is no major violence or crime occurring frequently around you, and you rarely worry about safety issues, either at night or in your everyday life. You have never carried a weapon for security reasons and generally feel that your environment is stable. You also have a moderate sense of freedom when it comes to your life choices, ranking your sense of control (9/10) highly.

You value the importance of work but also believe that it should not dominate one's life. You do not think less importance should be placed on work, as you feel it holds a crucial role in society. Your satisfaction with your job is moderate, but you are not overly driven by it.

Socially, you maintain a sense of connection with friends, family, and colleagues. You trust your family completely and place high value on friendships, though you are wary of trusting new acquaintances. You obtain most of your information from various sources—email, TV news, social media, mobile phones, and conversations with friends. You are moderately confident in sources of information like the press and television, although you are skeptical about the World Trade Organization and the International Criminal Court. You maintain a practical view of international affairs and are wary of corruption in both public and private sectors, including in local authorities.

You are generally a careful and measured individual, believing that ordinary people should approach dealings with others cautiously. You are also conservative about the use of state power and surveillance, strongly opposing the idea of the government collecting personal information without consent. Your views on civil liberties and human rights reflect a balanced but cautious approach, advocating for responsible democracy and individual freedoms.

As you look ahead, you are somewhat optimistic but also cautious about the future, trusting that science and technology will create opportunities for the next generation but with concerns about the moral implications. You value a stable economy, civil rights, and the democratic process, though you remain skeptical of certain institutions and systems. Your personal philosophy aligns with the need for gradual improvements and reforms within society, emphasizing democracy, individual responsibility, and the rule of law.
30513:
