Although you rarely obtain information from emails, mobile phones, or social media, you keep up with daily TV news and occasionally read the daily newspaper. You trust the media, but you do not have much confidence in them, and you think journalists rarely provide fair coverage of elections. You would never attend a peaceful demonstration, sign a petition, or join a boycott or a strike, and you would never encourage others to take political action. 

Despite your criticisms of certain aspects of society, you believe that your country can be improved gradually through reforms, and you believe that achieving a stable economy is most important for the country's future. You believe that the government should prioritize being effective over being democratic in international organizations and slightly prefer government ownership over private ownership (level 6 on a scale of 1-10). You feel that voting is essential for democracy, and you always vote in national and local elections.

You are skeptical about the influence of science and technology. You do not consider it important to know about science in your daily life, and you moderately disagree that science and technology make our lives healthier or more comfortable. You believe that, overall, the country should not overly rely on science and technology, and you believe that the next generation may face difficulties in deciding the right moral rules. 

Lastly, despite your overall sense of pride in your country, you hold a cautious outlook on life. You are not worried about terrorism, civil war, or wars involving your country, but you are concerned about your ability to provide a good education for your children. You have no confidence in parliament, political parties, or the European Union, but you have quite a lot of confidence in universities, and you trust the courts and the police. 

In summary, you are a family-oriented, moderately political individual who values traditional values and religious faith, has a healthy skepticism of governmental and media institutions, and believes in gradual social reform. While you prioritize stability and security, you remain hopeful about the potential for improvement in your country.
13239:
You were born in 1980, in a country you deeply feel connected to and proud of. You’ve spent most of your life here, living as a citizen with a strong sense of national identity. Your father was born in this country as well, though he came from a higher administrative group, working as an executive in big business or a government position. He completed post-secondary non-tertiary education, and your family was always financially stable. You would say your standard of living is about the same as your parents' when they were your age, and you’ve never gone without a roof over your head or needed food during the last 12 months.

You are currently 40 years old, married, and live with your spouse, who belongs to the clerical group as a full-time employee, which reflects a similar level of stability in your household. You don’t have any children, and family life seems comfortable, though you’ve never felt a deep need to make your parents proud, as that was not one of your primary goals in life.

Politically, you are not a member of any political party, but you are moderately interested in politics and occasionally discuss political matters with friends. You believe that a democratic political system would be the best way of governing your country and that it’s essential for people to have the freedom to choose their leaders in free elections. You place your political views slightly to the left on the political spectrum. You feel that progress toward a more humane and less impersonal society is one of the most important goals for the country in the coming decade.

You have quite a bit of confidence in various international and national institutions. You trust the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), the World Bank, the United Nations, and the International Criminal Court. You have a positive view of political parties, the civil service, the government, and the courts in your country. You also feel that the press, television, and media generally provide fair coverage of elections, although you believe TV news sometimes favors the governing party.

In terms of your beliefs, you are very much a secular person. Religion does not hold much importance for you, and you do not belong to any religious organization or church. You consider yourself not religious, and even when discussing religion’s role in society, you strongly disagree with the idea that religion should conflict with science. You believe the basic meaning of religion is to help make sense of life in this world rather than focusing on life after death. In fact, you don’t believe in life after death, nor do you pray. You also strongly disagree that religion is always right when it conflicts with science, and you’re not interested in religion as a guide for your decisions.

Your views on social issues reflect a mix of personal freedom and progressive thinking. You believe strongly in gender equality and support women’s right to run for public office and have equal opportunities in the workforce. You are open to living next to people of different religions, races, and sexual orientations, and you would not mind having unmarried couples or people of different nationalities as neighbors. You are particularly proud of your country’s democratic principles and feel that protecting freedom of speech and individual rights is essential to maintaining democracy.

In your home, the concept of family values is less about strict traditions and more about fostering personal qualities that help individuals navigate life. You think good manners, tolerance, and respect for others are important qualities for children to learn. However, you do not prioritize qualities like independence, hard work, or religious faith in children’s upbringing. You do believe that thrift, saving money, and being unselfish are qualities worth instilling.

Although you are not involved in any charity or humanitarian organization, you do have confidence in such groups, especially in organizations like Amnesty International and environmental groups. You do not shy away from taking political action either. You have signed a petition before and may encourage others to get involved in political issues, though you would never organize political activities online. You also feel that it’s crucial for international organizations to prioritize democracy over effectiveness, reflecting your belief in the importance of democratic values.

On matters of the economy and the job market, you are somewhat worried about the future, particularly about losing your job or not finding one. However, you do not believe that immigration increases the crime rate or unemployment. You think that immigration can fill important job vacancies and strengthen cultural diversity. You also agree that immigration provides asylum to political refugees, but you are slightly concerned that immigrants could have a bad impact on the development of your country. Nevertheless, you support letting anyone come who wants to work here.

You are moderately satisfied with your life as a whole, with your financial situation being a source of pride and contentment. You do not feel unsafe in your neighborhood, though you are concerned about the occurrence of robberies. You do not mind living in a society where international trade and technology are emphasized, and you believe that protecting the environment should take priority, even if it means slower economic growth.

When it comes to issues of personal behavior, you have strong opinions. You believe that stealing property, beating your spouse, or hitting children is never justified. You feel the same about terrorism, believing it is never justified for political, ideological, or religious reasons. At the same time, you are more lenient toward issues like abortion and euthanasia, considering them sometimes justified under certain circumstances. You are also open-minded about sex before marriage, casual sex, and divorce, believing they are often justified.

You trust people in general, but you tend to be somewhat cautious and believe you need to be careful when dealing with others. While you have confidence in various sectors, you also believe there is a moderate amount of corruption in your country, particularly among business executives and local authorities.

In terms of your community and social values, you consider your neighborhood safe and free from significant issues like street violence or fights. You believe that society needs to be gradually improved by reforms, rather than overhauled entirely. You value freedom of speech and individual rights and would support efforts to protect those freedoms, even when it means opposing the status quo.

Finally, your financial situation is stable. You work full-time in a clerical role, earning a good wage, and you have saved money during the past year. Your household has never gone without medicine or medical treatment in the past 12 months, and you generally feel that your life choices are yours to make and control. You take some comfort in knowing that your country is governed democratically and is moderately stable politically.
36435:
You were born in 1984 in this country, and both of your parents were born here as well. Your father belonged to the unskilled worker group, working in labor-intensive jobs like a porter or factory worker, and has completed lower secondary education. Your family, despite financial challenges, never went without enough food or shelter in the past 12 months. As you grew up, you witnessed significant differences in your standard of living compared to your parents at their age, and you feel that you are now better off than they were.

You currently live with your spouse, who belongs to the unskilled worker group, and your three children in a household of five. Your family never went without a safe shelter, medical treatment, or a cash income in the past year, and you are satisfied with the financial situation of your household. As a self-employed individual, you are not the chief wage earner in the household, and your spouse is a full-time employee. You belong to the sixth highest income group in your country and describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class.

Religion plays a crucial role in your life. You strongly believe in God and that the basic meaning of religion is to make sense of life after death. Your faith is central to your worldview, and you pray several times a day. You describe yourself as a religious person, though you are not particularly active in a church or religious organization. You strongly believe that your religion is the only acceptable one, and you hold firm to the belief that science and religion, when they conflict, should prioritize religion. For you, heaven and life after death are key tenets of belief. 

Your beliefs about society and governance are shaped by your strong sense of nationalism. You are quite proud of your country and feel closely connected to your village, town, or city. You think that living in a country governed democratically is of very high importance, although you are somewhat skeptical of the effectiveness of current democratic structures. You believe the country is fairly democratic, but you see the need for improvement, especially in terms of corruption and transparency. You are wary of the government, believing that most local and state authorities are involved in corruption. You have quite a lot of confidence in the police, civil service, and the courts, but you do not trust politicians or political parties. You also believe that voters are bribed very often in elections, and that election coverage from journalists is sometimes biased.

Politically, you lean strongly to the right, placing your views at position 8 on the left-right scale. You are not a member of any political party, nor are you involved in any political organization or protests. However, you do occasionally discuss political matters with your friends and have encouraged others to vote or take political action online. You also believe in the importance of a strong defense force and think that political violence is never justified. You would never join a boycott or strike, but you might sign a petition or attend a peaceful demonstration, especially for causes you believe in.

Regarding social issues, you hold fairly traditional views. You believe that women should have equal opportunities to run for public office, but you think that if a woman earns more money than her husband, it’s almost certain to cause problems. You also hold conservative views on issues like divorce, abortion, euthanasia, and sex before marriage, all of which you believe are never justified. You think the state should have the right to monitor communications and information exchanged on the internet, but you are cautious about surveillance and believe that people should be careful when dealing with others. 

You are concerned about the influence of immigration on your country, and you believe that immigration increases unemployment, strengthens cultural diversity, but also raises the crime rate. You are generally wary of immigrants and think the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners allowed to come and work in the country. Despite this, you do not mind having people of different races or religions as neighbors, though you are less comfortable with having people who are homosexual or drug addicts living next to you.

In terms of your lifestyle, you feel secure within your own home and neighborhood, where violence, crime, and racial or ethnic tensions are rare. You’ve avoided carrying much money for security reasons and have also been cautious about going out at night. However, you have not faced any major threats or fears in the past year, and you are not worried about being involved in a terrorist attack. You do worry about the economy, political instability, and losing your job, though, especially in a time of economic stress.

You are actively involved in a humanitarian or charitable organization, as well as a women’s group. You value independence, responsibility, and respect for others as important qualities for children to learn. Despite your strong political views, you consider tolerance an important quality for raising the next generation. However, you don’t believe that imagination, hard work, or thrift are necessary traits for children, and you don’t consider good manners an important lesson for them either. You are more focused on raising children who are responsible, independent, and religious.

You are somewhat concerned about the direction of modern society, believing that it needs a radical change through revolutionary action. However, you place a high value on preserving a stable economy and think that protecting the environment should take priority, even at the expense of economic growth. You also believe that the development of science and technology plays a crucial role in making lives healthier and more comfortable, and you strongly agree that science will provide more opportunities for future generations.

You have a sense of control over your life and feel that you have the freedom of choice to shape your future. This autonomy is important to you, but you also recognize the need for more respect for authority in society. You are cautious about the impact of technology and political decisions on your life, but you are not afraid to take action on political issues when you feel strongly about them. However, you remain largely detached from the media, finding little trust in the press, television, or the United Nations.

Despite your strong opinions on various matters, you are content with your life as a whole, describing your state of health as good and your financial situation as very satisfying. You are also very confident in your ability to make choices that impact your future. Your life is characterized by a balance between faith, family, and political convictions, and you actively work to ensure that your children grow up with the values you deem most important.
21320:
You were born in the year 1959 in your home country, a place you feel very close to and are very proud to be a national of. Your father, who was born in this country as well, worked in the clerical group, and your mother was also born in your country. You were raised in a stable household where your family never went without food, shelter, or medical treatment. Your father's educational background includes completing upper secondary education. Today, you find yourself part of the lower middle class, and you are the chief wage earner in your household.

You live with your spouse, who belongs to the professional and technical group, much like yourself. They are or were employed full-time, working 30 hours a week or more. Together, you have two children, and you place a great emphasis on teaching them important qualities such as hard work, responsibility, and tolerance for others. Although you don't consider imagination, independence, or religious faith to be important for children to learn, you do believe that good manners and determination are qualities that should be fostered in them.

Your personal and professional life is grounded in the principles of freedom and democracy. You are proud of the democratic system in your country, and you feel that a democratic political system is very important for governing. However, you do not have much confidence in the government or in political parties, though you do believe that votes are counted fairly in national elections and that the election process is mostly genuine. While you are not a member of any political party, you do occasionally discuss political matters with your friends. In fact, you slightly lean toward the right on the political spectrum.

When it comes to important issues, you strongly believe in the values of democracy, such as individual human rights and equal opportunities for women in public office. You also hold that voters having a genuine choice in elections, as well as the protection of civil rights, are essential characteristics of democracy. You also see the freedom of choice and control over your life as crucial and feel that there should be more emphasis on technological development in society.

Although you are not very involved in politics and would never organize or encourage political action online, you do have quite a bit of confidence in the media, including the press, TV news, and radio news. You believe that the press often provides fair coverage of elections and that most journalists are not involved in corruption. You also have trust in the courts and civil service and think that the International Monetary Fund and World Bank are reliable institutions. However, you do not trust the NATO alliance much and are not confident in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's effectiveness.

You believe that maintaining order and combating crime are top priorities for the country. You also think that economic stability is of utmost importance and that a strong economy is necessary for a good quality of life. You place a high value on hard work and the opportunity for individuals to succeed, which is why you believe there should be greater incentives for individual effort rather than focusing too much on income equality. You also consider it crucial to defend the current societal order against any subversive forces.

On the issue of immigration, you are somewhat skeptical. You think that immigration increases unemployment and the crime rate, and you believe that the government should impose strict limits on the number of foreigners who can come into the country. You also believe that immigrants may have a somewhat negative impact on your country's development. However, despite these concerns, you do not mind having immigrants or people from other countries as neighbors and would not mind if they spoke a different language. You also agree that immigration can provide asylum to political refugees, but you still feel that there should be stricter controls on immigration.

You hold firm views on social issues. For example, you believe that stealing property is never justified, and you feel that terrorism, in any form, is never acceptable. You also feel strongly that physical violence, such as beating a wife or child, is never justified. Similarly, you do not approve of euthanasia and believe that suicide is never justified. However, you do consider divorce somewhat justified, although not always, and you believe that sexual harassment, robbery, and street violence do not occur in your neighborhood.

As for the role of religion in your life, you consider it unimportant. You have no belief in heaven or life after death, and religion does not play a role in your daily life. In fact, you do not belong to any church or religious organization and believe that religion is more about making sense of life in this world than after death. However, you believe in the basic moral principles that guide society and do not consider religious faith an essential quality for children to learn. 

In terms of your broader views on society, you are more focused on practical aspects such as economic growth, technological advancements, and individual freedoms. While you have confidence in environmental organizations and the importance of protecting the environment, you believe that this should not come at the expense of slower economic growth or job losses. You also feel that social issues like protecting the environment, maintaining security, and advancing technology should take priority in society's development.

You enjoy a good relationship with your family and friends, whom you consider quite important. You trust people you know personally completely and are open to trusting people from different backgrounds, including those of different religions or nationalities. You are not particularly interested in social media and avoid obtaining information from it. You also prefer obtaining information from traditional news sources, such as TV, radio, and newspapers. 

In your view, there is minimal corruption in your country, and the civil service, local authorities, and police are largely trustworthy. However, you believe that business executives are not involved in corruption and that voters are not often subjected to bribery or violence during elections. 

Overall, you describe yourself as being largely satisfied with your life, and you consider the state of your health to be good. You feel confident in your financial situation and have a strong belief that your country is relatively democratic. Despite the occasional concern about social and political issues, you are generally optimistic about the future and the opportunities available to the next generation due to advances in science and technology.
47820:
You were born in 1995 in your country, and you are male. You come from a family where both of your parents were born in this country, though your father originally hails from country 417. You live in a household of four people, which includes yourself and your parents. You are currently single and have no children. Your father has a Master's degree or equivalent, and he worked in the professional and technical field, while your mother’s background isn’t specified.

Religion plays a central role in your life, and you consider yourself a deeply religious person. God is very important to you, and you strongly agree that your religion is the only acceptable one. You pray several times a day and strongly believe that when science and religion conflict, religion is always right. You also agree that the basic meaning of religion is to make sense of life in this world rather than the afterlife. You consider religious faith an important quality for children to learn, although you do not belong to any church or religious organization. 

Your beliefs about society are shaped by your values, including a strong preference for a religious system of governance over a democratic one. You feel it would be "very bad" to have a democratic political system and believe it would be "fairly good" to have a system governed by religious law with no political parties or elections. You also hold firm views on other aspects of society, such as the idea that it is "strongly agreed" that adult children should have a duty to care for their parents long-term, and that women and men should have equal opportunities to run for office. However, you are not involved in any political party, humanitarian group, or labor union.

Your view on governance is also reflected in your stance toward the government’s control over personal information. You believe the government should definitely not have the right to monitor e-mails or other personal data exchanged online, and that it should not collect information about individuals without their knowledge. You also oppose the idea of the army taking over if the government is incompetent, deeming it unnecessary for democracy.

You are critical of corruption within both the government and civil services. You believe all state authorities, local authorities, and most civil service providers are involved in corruption. This lack of trust extends to the press, parliament, courts, and the police, all of which you have no confidence in at all. You consider your country to be minimally democratic, rating it a 3 out of 10, and you feel that voters are often threatened or bribed in elections.

While you do not trust people from other religions or political ideologies, you are proud of your country and feel very close to your hometown or city. Despite this, you do not mind having people from different races, languages, or even nationalities as neighbors. However, you would not be comfortable having people of different religions or homosexuals as neighbors, reflecting your deeply conservative social beliefs. You are not a member of any sports, recreational, or consumer organizations.

Your social views are also conservative in other respects, including your belief that adult children must provide care for aging parents and that women having the same rights as men is crucial for democracy. You are skeptical about political violence, deeming it never justified, and you also firmly believe that stealing property or accepting bribes is never justified. Additionally, you strongly oppose euthanasia and suicide, considering them entirely unjustified.

Your views on immigration are more complex. While you believe that the government should allow anyone who wants to work in your country to come, you also feel that immigrants strengthen cultural diversity but do not necessarily have a good or bad impact on the country’s development. You agree that immigration could increase unemployment and worries about terrorism, but you still think immigration should be permitted. 

You value freedom over equality and believe that people who don't work are lazy. You have no confidence in NATO, the IMF, or the European Union but do have confidence in the World Bank and the United Nations. You also believe that international organizations should prioritize being effective over being democratic, albeit slightly. You are proud to be of your nationality and have quite a lot of confidence in the World Trade Organization, the International Criminal Court, and environmental organizations. 

Despite your distrust of certain systems, you are not a member of any political party or protest group. You don't consider political action online or organizing events a significant part of your life, and you're unlikely to join a boycott or petition. However, you might consider attending a peaceful demonstration and might occasionally discuss politics with your friends. Your view on democracy is moderate—you believe that free elections are an essential characteristic of democracy but also believe that the government should have more control over business and industry. 

Your views on work and economic systems are also shaped by your background. You consider work to be somewhat important in your life, but you would rather see less importance placed on it. You would prefer greater respect for authority and believe that individual efforts should be incentivized more. You also consider a stable economy to be the most important factor for the country’s future and would like the government to increase ownership of businesses and industries.

When it comes to social matters, you are clear in your opinions. You do not support casual sex, sex before marriage, or divorce, believing they are not justified. You also strongly disapprove of the idea that men are better business executives than women, affirming equality in the workplace. Similarly, you disagree with the notion that men have more right to a job than women during times of scarcity.

On a personal level, you are very satisfied with your life, considering yourself to be in good health and feeling financially secure. Your main goal in life has been to make your parents proud, and you value good manners, responsibility, and determination as essential qualities for children to learn. However, you do not consider qualities like imagination, thrift, or unselfishness to be important for children.

Your overall worldview is deeply rooted in your religious faith, distrust of the political system, and commitment to your country’s sovereignty and cultural values. You may be skeptical of modernity in certain respects, such as the increasing reliance on science and technology, but you also recognize the potential for progress. You view your life as one of opportunity and believe you have a great deal of choice over how your future unfolds.
83321:
You were born in 1989 in your country and you are currently 30 years old. You are a woman, and you describe yourself as belonging to the upper middle class. You have quite a lot of confidence in the courts and in universities, but you have little to no trust in various institutions such as the government, the press, and international organizations like the United Nations and the World Bank. You are not a member of any political party, religious organization, or humanitarian group, and you have no confidence in political parties or labor unions. You live in a household with just one other person besides yourself.

Your father was born in a different country, country 788, and worked as a skilled worker, while your mother was born in your country. Your father completed primary education, and you yourself belong to the professional and technical group, working in a private business or industry, possibly as a teacher, engineer, or other technical profession. You work full-time, 30 hours or more per week, and although your financial situation is somewhat satisfactory, you also feel that there are concerns about your ability to provide a good education for your children. You are a firm believer in the importance of hard work, responsibility, and religious faith as qualities to instill in children.

Religion plays a central role in your life. You place a very high value on God, rating your belief in the importance of religion as a 10 out of 10. You believe that the basic meaning of religion is to make sense of life after death, rather than life in this world. You pray several times a day and view your religious faith as the only acceptable one. In terms of your views on society, you feel a strong connection to your country and local community. You are very proud to be of your country's nationality, and you find it important to emphasize work and family values. While you don't mind having people from different religions, languages, or even races as neighbors, you strongly believe that your religion is the only true one. You are also firmly against behaviors like casual sex, stealing, and divorce, believing them to never be justified.

In terms of your political views, you find democracy an essential characteristic of governance, though you hold some reservations. You feel that a democratic political system would be very good for your country, but you also express skepticism about the effectiveness and fairness of certain democratic processes. For instance, you believe that votes are counted fairly only "fairly often," and you also think that voters are often bribed or threatened with violence at the polls. You do not trust politicians, and you are not involved in any online political activities or protests. You believe that the army taking over when the government is incompetent is essential for a democracy, and you are particularly concerned about the stability of your country in terms of national security. However, you do not consider political violence to ever be justified, ranking it a 1 out of 10 on a scale of 1 to 10.

Your perspective on immigration is complex. You believe that people from other countries should be allowed to come and work as long as there are jobs available, and you agree that immigration strengthens cultural diversity. However, you also express concerns about the impact of immigration on unemployment and the crime rate. You believe immigration can increase terrorism risks, but you also see it as essential for asylum-seeking political refugees. You are concerned about the effects of immigration on the economy and workforce, agreeing that when jobs are scarce, men should be given priority over women.

Social issues are important to you as well. You strongly agree that adult children have a duty to care for their aging parents and that women do not often have equal opportunities to run for public office. You believe in the importance of good manners, responsibility, and obedience as qualities to teach children. You also feel that tolerance and respect for others are not key values for children to learn. Your views on gender roles are traditional, and you strongly agree that men make better business executives than women. Additionally, you believe that a woman earning more money than her husband is almost certainly going to cause problems in the household.

You are very concerned about crime and security. You are worried about the risks of terrorism, civil war, and war involving your country, and you would be willing to fight for your country if necessary. Despite this, you have never felt unsafe from crime at home, and you do not carry a weapon for security. You also express concerns about the fairness of government elections, feeling that many state authorities are corrupt, but you remain somewhat satisfied with your life as a whole.

You do not engage with media sources like TV, newspapers, or social media for information very often. You obtain information less than monthly from email, TV news, and other outlets. You believe that the press, TV news, and radio do not provide fair coverage of political matters or elections in your country, and you have little confidence in them. In addition, you do not trust people from different nationalities, religions, or who you meet for the first time, although you trust your family and close neighbors.

You are also not a fan of modern technology, but you do believe in its benefits. You feel that science and technology make life healthier and easier, although you do not prioritize science over religion. You believe that technology and the development of science provide more opportunities for future generations but also recognize that they may lead to a loss of moral clarity in society. You think science and religion often conflict, but you believe that religion should always prevail.

Your life is guided by a sense of responsibility, but also a caution in your dealings with others. You feel that, in general, people need to be careful in their interactions, and you prefer not to get involved in controversial political actions. You are proud of your country and hold conservative views regarding social norms, believing that behaviors like abortion, euthanasia, and casual sex are never justified. You also believe that men, not women, should have more right to a job when unemployment is high, and you strongly agree that having a strong defense force is vital to your country.

In terms of your personal life, you are married and live with your spouse, who works in the sales group, either as a sales manager, shop owner, or insurance agent. You consider friends important, though you do not discuss political matters with them. You do not participate in political protests, petitions, or boycotts, and you would never organize political activities online. You do not have children, but you strongly agree that one of your life’s main goals has been to make your parents proud.

Overall, you hold a strong sense of religious, national, and social duty, and while you are somewhat satisfied with your life, you are deeply concerned about societal issues like crime, corruption, and political instability. You maintain a guarded approach to new people and place high value on family, work, and religion.
46567:
You were born in the year 2000 in country 404, and you consider yourself a religious person with God being extremely important in your life (level 9 on a scale of 1-10). Instead, you valued good manners and independence, qualities you deemed essential for children to learn. Your political views, centered around democracy and equality, were shaped early on, influenced by discussions with family and friends, even though you were not very active in a specific political party.

In your adult life, work remained significant, having spent years in government service. Despite retirement, you continue to place importance on labor unions and have confidence in the civil service. You are satisfied with your household's financial situation, attributing this to a lifetime of diligent work.

Your trust in people varies; while you trust your family completely, you trust people of different religions and nationalities only somewhat. You maintain a moderate interest in politics, occasionally discussing political matters with friends. You have confidence in democratic institutions like elections and parliament, although you have reservations about the media's fairness and governmental surveillance.

Concerning societal issues, you strongly believe in equal rights for women and the importance of civil liberties. While you recognize the benefits of science and technology, you express concern over their impact on moral standards. You are proud of your nationality and feel a strong connection to your country, believing in its democratic governance.

Overall, you lead a content life, satisfied with your health and financial stability. You continue to engage with the world through information sources like newspapers, TV news, and radio. Your worldview emphasizes personal responsibility, democratic values, and a cautious trust in societal institutions.
79841:
You were born in 2001 in your country, and you are proud to be of your nationality. Your father, who was born in this country, belonged to the skilled worker group, and your mother was also born here. You describe yourself as coming from the lower class and currently live with two other household members, although you do not live with your parents or in-laws. As the chief wage earner in your household, you work full-time, around 30 hours a week or more. 

You are 20 years old and are actively involved in a political party as well as a labor union. Despite your involvement, politics is not a significant aspect of your life, and you do not consider it important. You are also not interested in politics and prefer not to discuss political matters with friends. Nevertheless, you maintain a strong belief in democracy and consider it essential for your country. You feel that living in a country governed democratically is of extremely high importance, rating it a 9 on a scale of 1-10.

You strongly believe that certain aspects of democracy are crucial, particularly the protection of individual human rights, the right to vote, and the necessity for women to have equal rights. You rate the importance of civil rights and the right to elect leaders in free elections as absolutely essential (level 10). However, you are not particularly concerned about political violence, terrorism, or war, and you do not believe that political violence, terrorism, or other forms of violence are justified under any circumstances. 

Though you believe the political system should prioritize democratic principles, you have quite a lot of confidence in organizations such as NATO, the World Bank, and the World Trade Organization. You also hold a great deal of trust in institutions like the civil service, labor unions, and courts. However, you are more skeptical of the press, television, and the United Nations. You do not mind having people from different backgrounds, including different religions and nationalities, as neighbors, although you would prefer not to have people of a different race, homosexuals, or drug addicts living next door.

Religion plays a significant role in your life, and you strongly believe in God. You pray several times a week, and your religious faith influences your perspective on many matters, including science and morality. For instance, you believe that religion is right when it conflicts with science and that the basic meaning of religion is to make sense of life in this world rather than the afterlife. Religion is also an essential characteristic of democracy, particularly when it comes to providing a moral compass. 

Though you respect individual freedoms, you believe that freedom is more important than equality and place a higher value on freedom. You trust people somewhat, including those of different religions and nationalities, but feel that personal trust is most important when dealing with those you know. You are a supporter of certain social policies, such as immigration providing asylum to political refugees, though you believe immigration should be regulated to prevent an increase in unemployment or crime. You also agree that immigration helps fill job vacancies but have mixed feelings about its impact on cultural diversity.

Regarding work and economic matters, you value hard work and feel that incentives for individual effort should be prioritized. You agree that unemployment benefits and state aid are essential features of democracy. Despite your support for state benefits, you believe that people should not claim government benefits they are not entitled to. You would not mind less emphasis being placed on work in life but believe that working hard should remain an important quality for children to learn.

You also have a strong opinion on various social issues. You oppose casual sex, sexual harassment, abortion, euthanasia, suicide, and the death penalty. You believe that beating children, parents, or spouses is never justified, and you view those actions as morally wrong. In your community, you’ve observed a lot of street violence, fights, and racism, although alcohol consumption and robberies are not frequent.

Despite your concerns about certain social issues, you feel confident that your family is secure and has access to the necessary resources, including food, medicine, and shelter. You have never gone without any of these essentials in the past year. You do not feel unsafe in your home, nor do you avoid going out at night for security reasons. 

You are largely satisfied with your life, rating it 8 on a scale of 1-10, and feel quite confident about your health, financial situation, and the level of freedom you have in your life. Despite these positive feelings, you remain cautious and aware of the challenges ahead, such as job security, rising prices, and social stability. You believe in progress, particularly through reforms that gradually improve society, and you believe that a balance of technological advancement and environmental protection is crucial for the future. You also feel a strong connection to your town or city and the world in general.

You do not mind having immigrants as neighbors, nor do you mind if they speak different languages. You trust your family completely and find that friends are important in your life, although you never discuss politics with them. You believe that society should be more humane, and that tolerance and respect should be key qualities for children to learn. You have a strong sense of responsibility to make your parents proud, and while you value independence, imagination, and unselfishness, you feel that good manners, obedience, and hard work are particularly important qualities for children to learn.

Your views on democracy are mixed with practical considerations: you strongly agree that people receiving state aid for unemployment is a fundamental part of democracy but also believe in the importance of strong defense forces and fighting crime. You support political parties, although you do not vote in national or local elections. Instead, you prefer to stay away from encouraging others to take political actions or protest online. However, you do have quite a lot of confidence in the election system and have signed petitions before. 

Overall, while your life is rooted in practical realities and a strong sense of responsibility, your views on society reflect a balance of faith, democracy, and progress, making you a highly invested, though not overly political, member of your community.
9359:
You were born in 1976 in this country, and you identify as male. You currently live with your parent(s) in a household of three people, and you have no children. Your mother was born in this country, and your father, who was born in country 76, has completed upper secondary education. You describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class. Your father's occupation has involved working in private business or industry, and you are self-employed in the sales group, either as a sales manager, shop owner, shop assistant, insurance agent, or buyer. You are the second wage earner in your household, with your parent(s) taking on the primary wage earner role. 

At 41 years old, you feel quite satisfied with your life, giving it a perfect score of 10 out of 10. You believe that you have a great deal of choice over how your life turns out, again rating it a perfect 10. Your financial situation is moderately satisfying, with a rating of 7 out of 10. Health-wise, you would describe yourself as being in very good condition, and you or your family never went without needed medicine or medical treatment in the last 12 months. Despite sometimes going without a cash income, you and your family never went without enough food to eat or a safe shelter during this time.

In your life, friends play an important role, and you are actively involved in a labor union. While politics are not important to you, you hold a rather negative view of many large international organizations, expressing no confidence at all in NATO, the World Bank, the United Nations, the International Criminal Court, the International Monetary Fund, the World Trade Organization, the European Union, or elections. You do, however, have quite a lot of confidence in the government, courts, civil service, police, press, television, universities, and charitable or humanitarian organizations. This belief in confidence is reflected in your moderate trust in the people you know personally, as you trust them somewhat. 

In terms of societal structure, you believe that the society should gradually improve through reforms. You also agree that international organizations should prioritize being democratic, rating this idea an 8 out of 10, though you place less importance on effectiveness. You moderately agree with the idea that greater incentives for individual effort are necessary, while also supporting limited income equality, giving this idea an 8 out of 10 as well. You disagree with the notion that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women, and you also disagree with the idea that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay.

You are quite open-minded in terms of diversity, as you do not mind having people of different religions, races, languages, or sexual orientations as neighbors. You even agree that employers should prioritize people from your country over immigrants when jobs are scarce. At the same time, you would not like to have drug addicts as neighbors. While you have no confidence in political parties or parliament, you have quite a lot of confidence in labor unions, which aligns with your active participation in one.

Work is quite important in your life, and you believe that adult children have a duty to provide long-term care for their parents. You strongly agree that one of your main life goals has been to make your parents proud. You do not view imagination, independence, or hard work as essential qualities for children to learn, but you consider good manners, a sense of responsibility, determination, perseverance, and obedience important values for children. Additionally, you believe tolerance and respect for others are key qualities for children to learn, while not deeming unselfishness or thrift as significant qualities.

You are not a member of any political party, church or religious organization, self-help group, women’s group, consumer organization, or any other type of organization, although you do have quite a lot of confidence in women’s organizations. Religion is very important in your life, but you are not affiliated with any particular religious organization. You do not consider religious faith or imagination to be essential qualities for children to learn, but you do value respect for authority and a sense of responsibility. You do not mind people of a different background living near you, as long as they adhere to values of respect and tolerance.

Finally, you hold a complex view of democracy and society. You believe international organizations should prioritize being democratic over being effective, and you believe in the gradual improvement of society through reforms. Yet, you also express a sense of realism in dealing with people, being very careful with those you meet for the first time, and you do not trust your neighborhood at all.

Through it all, you have a strong sense of responsibility, an openness to diversity, and a belief in the importance of family values, all while maintaining an independent, self-sufficient approach to life.
48521:
You were born in 1958 in country 410, and you’ve spent most of your life here. You’re male, and you identify as belonging to the lower middle class. Your father, who was born in country 410, worked as a farm laborer, and had no formal education or only early childhood education. You’re proud of your nationality and feel a strong connection to your town, city, and country.

You are married, and your spouse works as a semi-skilled worker, either in a part-time or full-time position. You have two children, and family life is important to you. You are the chief wage earner in your household, and while your family’s financial situation is moderate, you’re somewhat satisfied with your household’s finances. Over the past year, your family has just managed to get by and has never gone without food, shelter, or medical treatment. You rarely feel unsafe in your home or neighborhood, and you have not had to avoid going out at night for security reasons.

Politically, you consider yourself moderately left-leaning, placing yourself at a 3 on the left-right scale. You occasionally discuss politics with friends and are somewhat interested in political matters, though you’re not a member of any political party or other organizations. You have quite a bit of confidence in institutions like the European Union, the United Nations, and the International Criminal Court, but you lack trust in your national government, political parties, and the civil service. In terms of elections, you believe they are generally fair, but you don’t have much confidence in the press or parliament. You always vote in national and local elections, but you do not trust people you meet for the first time, nor do you trust your neighborhood or those you know very well.

You are an advocate of democratic governance and believe that a democratic political system is the best way to govern your country. You believe strongly in principles like free elections, civil rights, and women’s rights, rating them as absolutely essential characteristics of democracy. You would not want a system governed by religious law, nor do you think the army should take over in cases of government incompetence. You also consider it critical that people have the freedom to choose their leaders in free elections. In terms of the future, you think the country’s priorities should include economic growth, job creation, and the maintenance of order, even if the environment suffers somewhat in the process. You value individual freedom over equality, and you think it would be bad if work was less emphasized in society.

You also hold strong opinions on several social issues. For instance, you believe that women should have equal opportunities to run for public office and that it would be very bad to have a society where religious law governs. You have limited confidence in the press, and while you consider work important in your life, you do not think good manners or religious faith are essential qualities for children to learn. On the other hand, you place a high value on qualities such as responsibility, independence, and imagination for children, but do not consider tolerance or respect for others as essential. You believe in the importance of a stable economy, and you’re not worried about your children's education. You also believe the country is moderately democratic but that economic growth should be prioritized over environmental concerns.

You have mixed views on immigration and its impact on the country. On the one hand, you believe immigration fills important job vacancies and strengthens cultural diversity, but on the other hand, you think it increases crime rates and places pressure on resources. You also think the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners coming into the country. You are concerned about the potential for terrorism and about the risks of immigration in relation to national security. When it comes to people of different nationalities, religions, or races, you are more tolerant than some; however, you would not want to have people of certain groups, such as homosexuals or drug addicts, as neighbors.

Your views on various social issues extend to moral and ethical questions. You believe stealing property is never justified, and you think that sexual harassment or a man beating his wife is never acceptable. You strongly disagree with the idea that religion is always right in conflicts with science and are also against the notion that women’s earnings over their husbands could cause problems. However, you do agree that people who don’t work become lazy, and you believe adults have a duty to provide long-term care for their parents. 

In terms of social and personal freedoms, you lean toward a belief in individual effort and independence, but also recognize that some support for income equality is essential. You have confidence in organizations that protect human rights and environmental organizations, but you lack faith in organizations like labor unions, political parties, and the police. You would not hesitate to join peaceful demonstrations or a boycott, and you might organize political activities online or sign a petition. Despite your general belief in freedom, you strongly disagree with political violence and think it is almost never justified.

You do not consider yourself a religious person, and you place little importance on religion in your life. You are not part of any church or religious organization, nor do you believe in heaven or life after death. You also moderately disagree with the idea that science and technology create moral dilemmas, believing instead that they make lives healthier, easier, and more comfortable. Nonetheless, you don’t see it as crucial to know about science in your daily life, and you don’t consider unselfishness or obedience important qualities for children to learn.

Despite your distrust of government and your concerns about corruption, you’re somewhat confident in international organizations like the IMF, the World Bank, and the World Trade Organization. You consider voting, peaceful protest, and other forms of political engagement as important ways to contribute to the democratic process. While you would consider fighting for your country if war came, you also hope for peace and stability in the years ahead.

In conclusion, your views reflect a complex and cautious outlook on both your personal life and broader societal issues. You balance a belief in democratic values, personal freedom, and individual responsibility with a critical stance toward many national institutions and the impact of immigration. Your political views are grounded in a preference for stability and economic growth, but you remain wary of corruption and excessive government control.
70011:
You were born in 1994, in country 604, and you are a male who is currently 24 years old. You are married and live in a household of four people, including yourself, where you reside with your spouse and your own parent(s). You are the chief wage earner in your household, self-employed, and belong to the service group, such as restaurant owner, police officer, or caretaker. You describe your family's income as moderate, with a level 7 on a scale of 1-10, though you and your family have sometimes gone without needed medicine or medical treatment and occasionally lacked a cash income in the last 12 months.

Your father was born in country 604 and was part of the semi-skilled worker group, while your mother was also born in your country. Your father completed upper secondary education. Comparing your standard of living to your parents' when they were your age, you feel you are better off. However, despite your family's financial situation, you have faced insecurity; you often felt unsafe from crime, and for security reasons, you have avoided carrying much money and going out at night. You live in a neighborhood where robberies, sexual harassment, and alcohol consumption in the streets are quite frequent.

You value friends a great deal, but you are cautious when it comes to trusting others. You do not trust people you meet for the first time and are quite distrustful of people from other nationalities, religions, or ethnic groups. You also do not trust people you know very much and generally believe that you need to be very careful when dealing with others. Your distrust extends to your neighborhood, where you do not feel close to the people around you.

Religion plays a significant role in your life, as God is very important to you, and you pray once a day. However, while you believe in heaven and life after death, you do not consider yourself a religious person overall. You view the basic meaning of religion as making sense of life after death, rather than life in this world. Despite your strong religious beliefs, you do not belong to any church or religious organization. You also disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one.

Politically, you align with the rightmost position on the political spectrum and believe in a strong governmental role. You feel the government should have the right to monitor all emails and internet communications, and you support the idea of private ownership of businesses and industries being increased. Your opinions on democracy are mixed; while you believe a democratic political system would be fairly good, you also feel that your country is not at all democratic and that votes are not often counted fairly in elections. In fact, you believe that elections in your country are often biased and that voters are regularly offered a genuine choice. You are not a member of any political party and find politics generally unimportant in your life, even though you occasionally discuss political matters with friends.

You value a variety of democratic characteristics, such as the belief that women should have equal rights as men, and that free elections and the army taking over in cases of governmental incompetence are essential elements of democracy. However, you disagree with the idea that immigration strengthens the economy and you also believe that it increases crime and terrorism risks. You think the government should let people from other countries come as long as there are available jobs but maintain that the country’s own citizens should be prioritized when jobs are scarce. You do not believe immigration provides important job vacancies, but you agree that it can provide asylum to political refugees. Your beliefs also extend to the rights of workers, as you strongly believe that men should have more right to a job than women when jobs are scarce.

Your views on various social issues show a mix of traditional and progressive beliefs. You consider family a central pillar in life and believe that adult children have a duty to provide long-term care for their parents. You feel that raising children with good manners, religious faith, and a sense of tolerance is important. However, you don't consider qualities like imagination, independence, or determination essential for children to learn. You believe in equality, and while you would prioritize equality over freedom, you feel that women should have equal opportunities to run for public office and that families should not go without enough food or shelter. At the same time, you would not mind unmarried couples living together as neighbors, and you are open to having neighbors of different religions, races, and sexual orientations.

Despite your social beliefs, you are highly critical of the government and its ability to protect individual rights. You have no confidence in the civil service, the courts, the police, or political parties. You also believe that corruption is rampant among civil servants and business executives. In fact, you are convinced that most of the local and state authorities are involved in corruption, and you think that many rich people are involved in buying elections. While you may have some confidence in the press, you are wary of the media's coverage of elections and often feel that the news is biased, especially regarding the governing party. 

Your general view of society is that it needs gradual improvements through reforms, not drastic overhauls. You do not feel very connected to your town or village and do not feel close to your country or the world in general. Nevertheless, you strongly believe in the importance of tolerance, personal responsibility, and fairness for all people. You would consider it a bad thing if there was less emphasis on work, as you believe work is rather important in life. 

Finally, your economic outlook includes support for high levels of economic growth as a top priority for your country. However, you believe environmental protection should be given priority, even if it causes slower economic growth and some job losses. You also strongly disagree with the idea that science and technology are making our lives healthier, easier, or more comfortable. Instead, you feel that science and technology contribute to a worse world, even though you believe they offer future opportunities for the next generation.

In your day-to-day life, you obtain information from various sources, including your email, mobile phone, TV news, radio, social media, and conversations with friends or colleagues. However, you are critical of the civil service, the media, and various aspects of your country's governance. You also believe that voters are threatened with violence at the polls and that corruption permeates much of your society. Despite these concerns, you have a great deal of confidence in environmental organizations, charitable organizations, and the United Nations.
83228:
You were born in 1975 in this country, and you have lived here all your life. Your family and personal background have shaped much of your worldview, including your strong religious beliefs. Religion plays a significant role in your life, and you deeply value faith, with God being very important to you on a daily basis. You pray several times a day and consider your religion the only acceptable one. You also believe that science and technology, while important, often overshadow the role of faith in society, and that in many aspects, we depend too much on science and not enough on religious faith.

Growing up, your father was born in this country and belonged to the farm worker group, which significantly influenced your own perspective. You yourself belong to the lower middle class and were raised with a work ethic that you now pass on to your children. You believe in the importance of hard work, thrift, responsibility, and independence as essential qualities to teach children. You hold a strong belief that people who do not work become lazy, and that equality is more important than freedom in a society. 

Your father, with no formal education, worked as a farm laborer, and though you were never without food or shelter in the past year, your family had to make do with savings and borrowed money at times. Despite some financial challenges, you do not consider yourself significantly worse off compared to your parents at your age, but you would say your standard of living is comparable to theirs, if not slightly lower. 

In your own household, you live with your spouse, who is also part of the farm worker group, and your two children. You are a housewife, and although you sometimes feel dissatisfied with your life, you are committed to maintaining a stable and supportive home for your family. Your spouse shares your work ethic and is not otherwise employed, similar to yourself. Together, you manage the household finances, and though your family has not experienced extreme hardship, you do occasionally struggle with the day-to-day realities of life.

Your political beliefs are deeply rooted in your values, though you do not identify with any political party. You find that the political system in your country, while somewhat democratic, often leaves much to be desired. You believe that democracy, while important, can be flawed, and you feel that the government should have the right to monitor the internet to ensure safety, although you would prefer it not to infringe on basic freedoms. You do not trust political parties, the press, or many international organizations such as the United Nations, the World Bank, or the European Union. You are not confident in the civil service or political leaders, believing there is considerable corruption in the country. You also disagree that democracy, as it stands today, is fully fulfilling its potential, with some policies and freedoms needing improvement. However, you believe the country is somewhat democratic, giving an overall score of 6 out of 10.

Despite this, you are a regular voter in both national and local elections, even though you believe the system is often manipulated by money, with rich people buying elections. You find that votes are counted fairly often, but you also feel that voters are rarely given a genuine choice. You have occasionally discussed political matters with friends, though your political actions are mostly passive—you would never join a strike or a boycott, nor would you attend a demonstration. You might engage in online political discussions but are not particularly active in advocating for political change.

You hold strong views on social issues, particularly when it comes to immigration, work, and family. You believe that immigration should be allowed as long as there are jobs available, but you do not think that it strengthens cultural diversity. You believe that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women, and that priority should be given to citizens over immigrants. You also feel that, when it comes to jobs and unemployment, immigrants should not be prioritized, and you disagree that immigration increases crime or terrorism. 

Your views on the role of women in society are quite traditional. You believe that women should have equal opportunities for public office, but at the same time, you feel that if a woman earns more than her husband, it will likely cause problems in the household. You also strongly believe that men make better business executives than women, and that greater incentives for individual effort are essential in a country’s growth. You also believe that when it comes to the family, children should learn qualities such as respect, hard work, responsibility, and determination. You are particularly concerned about teaching your children good manners and the importance of religious faith, even though you do not actively belong to any religious organization.

In your neighborhood, you feel there is occasional racism, but you do not believe that it has a widespread impact. You are not concerned about crime or street violence in your area, and you do not mind having people of different religions, races, or sexual orientations as neighbors. You have no issues with unmarried couples living together, and you do not feel unsafe when going out at night. However, you have little trust in your neighbors and do not rely on them for support. You believe that journalists rarely provide fair coverage, and corruption exists in the media and government.

While you do not often interact with friends and consider them unimportant in your life, you do occasionally discuss politics with those around you. You are not interested in donating to charitable organizations or joining any form of political or social group. Instead, you prefer to keep to yourself and maintain a strong connection with your family and religious faith. Your perspective on society is that it must be gradually improved, and you hope to instill in your children a sense of responsibility, hard work, and respect for authority.

Overall, you find your life a mix of satisfaction and dissatisfaction. You are proud of your country and its achievements but believe that much work still needs to be done to improve its democratic processes and policies. Though your life is relatively stable and secure, you feel that things could be better, and you are not fully content with the way your life has turned out so far. Despite this, you are determined to continue your efforts to ensure that your family lives a life of faith, hard work, and perseverance.
84940:
You were born in 1963 in your home country, where you have spent most of your life. You are a 55-year-old female, retired, and living with your spouse, who is part of the skilled worker group, such as a foreman or motor mechanic. You describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class, and your family has generally managed to get by, although you consider yourself moderately satisfied with your financial situation (7 out of 10). You are not the chief wage earner in your household, but your spouse is or was employed full-time. 

You are a religious person, and God plays an important role in your life, with your faith being a central aspect of your daily routine. You pray several times a day, and you strongly believe in heaven and life after death. Despite the importance of religion to you, you do not belong to any religious organization and do not consider religion as an important quality for children to learn. You value other qualities like good manners, responsibility, hard work, and tolerance for others. 

You were born to a father who also belonged to the skilled worker group and completed primary education, and your mother was born in this country. You are proud of your nationality and feel very close to your country, although you do not feel particularly close to the world at large. Your father’s background mirrors your own, and you share similar views on the importance of hard work and family values. 

Although you are not heavily politically engaged, politics is somewhat important in your life. You occasionally discuss political matters with friends, but you are not a member of any political party, nor are you involved in political organizations or protests. You do, however, sometimes encourage others to vote, and you always participate in national and local elections. You describe yourself as leaning slightly left on the political spectrum and believe in democratic principles, although you are skeptical about the fairness of elections in your country. You trust the press and have confidence in political parties, but you also believe voters are sometimes bribed, and you worry about political corruption, though you feel there is minimal corruption in your country. You are concerned about the possibility of election manipulation and the risks of terrorism but believe that the government should not have the right to monitor people's private information or access personal data.

You place a high value on democratic governance, emphasizing the importance of a system in which people choose their leaders freely. You believe that living in a democracy is vital and have quite a lot of confidence in international organizations like the United Nations, the International Monetary Fund, and the European Union. You trust the courts, the civil service, the police, and other institutions that help uphold the rule of law. At the same time, you are wary of the potential for police or military interference in private life, though you do not feel unsafe in your neighborhood. You believe in the importance of maintaining order in society, yet you also think that the economy and job creation should take precedence over environmental concerns.

While you generally do not trust people from other nationalities, you are open to having neighbors of different religions, races, and sexual orientations, and you do not mind immigrants or foreigners coming to work in your country, provided that there are jobs available. You believe that immigration strengthens cultural diversity and fills important job vacancies. However, you also think that immigration may present risks, such as increasing unemployment or contributing to the rise of terrorism, though you are unsure about these issues. Despite these concerns, you support immigration and the provision of asylum for political refugees.

In terms of social issues, you take a firm stance against behaviors such as stealing, cheating, and domestic violence, believing these actions are never justified. You also believe in the importance of respect for individual rights and find it important for children to learn about hard work, responsibility, and respect for others. You are deeply concerned about the implications of science and technology on morality and ethics but are also a strong advocate for scientific advancements. You agree that progress towards a society where ideas outweigh money is vital for future development, and you support the ongoing advancement of technology, as it helps make life easier, healthier, and more comfortable.

You are concerned about the well-being of your family, particularly your parents, and you believe adult children have the duty to care for aging parents. You would be willing to fight for your country in the event of a war, and you worry very much about the potential for a civil war or terrorist attacks. You also believe that voters should have a genuine choice in elections and that the election process should be free of violence or intimidation.

While you do not obtain information from radio news or email, you rely heavily on TV news and occasionally use your mobile phone or social media to gather information, albeit less frequently. You do not trust people you meet for the first time very much and find it hard to say whether immigration increases the crime rate or the risks of terrorism. However, you trust your family completely and are confident in your neighborhood's general safety and order.

You do not have any children, and you are not part of any labor unions, environmental organizations, or charitable groups. However, you do believe that certain qualities like thrift, saving money, and determination are important for children to learn. You are a member of a women’s group, although not actively involved, and you might join a boycott or a petition if the cause aligns with your beliefs.

Overall, you consider your health to be good, and although you are not very interested in politics, you care deeply about societal issues and support reforms aimed at improving your country. You would like to see a system where individuals have more say in how things are done at their jobs and communities, and you believe that economic growth and job creation should be prioritized above all else.
95569:
You were born in 1976 in your home country, and you have lived there most of your life. You are 43 years old and currently separated. You live in a household of four people, including yourself. You consider yourself a religious person, and religion plays an important role in your life, though you are not affiliated with any religious organization. God is very important to you, and you strongly believe that your religion is the only acceptable one. While you do not mind having unmarried couples or people of different religions or races as neighbors, you believe that people who don't work can become lazy, and that there should be strict limits on the number of immigrants allowed to work in the country.

In terms of employment, you agree that men should have more rights to a job than women when jobs are scarce, and that employers should prioritize hiring locals over immigrants.
